story:
Dear Friend,  

We truly hope you’ll be able to join iLAND for the annual Benefit + Soiree! 

On Tuesday, October 23rd from 6-8 pm, we'll gather at The Bowery Electric to celebrate seven years of iLAB residencies with food, drinks, dancing, performances, live & silent auctions and iLANDing!

Please join us for an evening of interdisciplinary collaboration hosted by Carmelita Tropicana with performances by Paloma McGregor (2012 iLAB Resident), Jeremiah Lockwood (The Sway Machinery), and Ajay (Urban Word Poets).  

_______________________________________________________________

Purchase your tickets to the Benefit + Soiree TODAY! 

For $35, you'll receive 1 free drink ticket at the Benefit. 

For $50, you'll receive a Garmin compass from Jennifer Monson's 2004 BIRDBRAIN TOUR and a free drink ticket at the Benefit. 

For $150, you'll receive 1 free drink ticket at the Benefit and one of the following incentive packages:

Tickets to Brooklyn Academy of Music

Tickets to New York Live Arts

Tickets to Danspace Project

Tickets to the Bronx Zoo

Tickets to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden

Tickets to the New York Aquarium

Movement Research Class Card

All donations are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law. ________________________________________________________________

There will be a live + silent auction at the event. Auction item details are soon to come!

We can't wait to see you there. Thank you for your support!

-Jennifer + the iLAND Board

story:
Who are these crazy people?

Hooray! You’ve found our page! We are Raving Theatre, a long running Vancouver non-profit company  We are committed to encouraging and developing new works by local gay and lesbian playwrights and supporting all aspects of live theatre including theatre, dance ,music, video, film and performance art.

Most importantly, we have been running for 10 years!!! A real achievement for any small theatre company. To celebrate hitting our double digits we are producing two amazing plays for our 2013-2014 season.

Raving Theatre has been involved with artistic community in many ways. Founding member David Blue has written many terrific plays that have been produced in Vancouver, Montreal and Ottawa. In 2010 " Memoirs of a Single Gay White Male" swept the Greater Vancouver Zone Awards. As best production it was sent to Kamloops to compete in the Mainstage competition where we won the "Comedic Spirit" award. In 2012 we returned to the Zone festival with David's play " Home Again' where we recieved nominations and wins in the Best Actor?Actress, Best Supporting Actor, Best Director and Best Emsemble

 

What’s our Story?

 Coming up October 24- November 3, 2013 we have My Big Gay Italian Wedding by Anthony J Wilkinson. A hilarious play that uses larger than life gay and italian characters to satirize the controversy surrounding same-sex marriage.

Andrew and Anthony are getting married, and everyone wants to “help”. Matters spin into hysterical fiasco as everyone tries to have their way. From a sabateur ex, to a  loud, opinionated and outspoken mother, personalities and culture collide in a music and dance-filled extravaganza! 

Next, in the spring 2014, we will be producing Larry Kramer’s The Normal Heart.A searing drama about public and private indifference to the AIDS plague and one man's lonely fight to awaken the world to the crisis. Produced to acclaim in New York, London and Los Angeles, The Normal Heart follows Ned Weeks, a gay activist enraged at the indifference of public officials and the gay community. While trying to save the world from itself, he confronts the personal toll of AIDS when his lover dies of the disease.

 

What's in it for you? 

"The artists must be sacrificed to their art. Like the bees, they must put their lives into the sting they give."-  Ralph Waldo Emmerson

As artists we give a voice to those who may not know how to speak up. We provide a safe forum for free-speech where the rights and lifestyles of all people may be discussed. By donating you are not only supporting the arts but you get to be a part of something bigger. You get to help give our communties a voice!

 

So what do we want?

Money! Well, your support and money! In order to do these plays justice we need a proper budgets. Theatre is expensive to produce in this city and while the emotional and creative gains are fantastic, the financial ones kinda suck. In order to do to put these plays on we need money for:

Costumes/Makeup

Props

Set Construction

Posters/Printing

Rehearsal space

Rights to the plays

Venue

Lights and sound

Crew

 Your support allows us to provide a forum for new and emerging talents to show off their skills. Without these shows local actors are forced to wander the streets, mumbling lines from plays in exchange for small change or scraps of food and spontaneous applause. Your support keeps these actors off the streets and off your couch.

 

So, How can you help us?

All forms of support are appreciated, whether it’s a large wad of cash or merely passing word along about these shows. Help support local theatre by going to see independent shows, spreading the word and tipping your wait staff. We need your donations to keep theatre alive.

story:
Short Summary

I've been a professional belly dance instructor and performer for over nine years. Belly dance has not only been a great source of joy and fun for me, it has also been a profound and powerful medium for helping me to effectively cope with the challenges of life by increasing my confidence, self-esteem and ability to stay grounded and centered. 

Because belly dance has been such a powerful positive force in my life I am passionate about sharing it with everyone I can- but especially the people who need it most. As a volunteer teaching belly dance to underprivileged sixth-grade girls at a middle school in East Oakland, I saw how belly dance transformed them by increasing their self-esteem and helping them to tap into a source of strength within themselves. The program that I will receive training in is “Pomegranate SEEDs” which is an after school program that presents to youth the finest instruction in Middle Eastern Arts along with programming that promotes self-discovery and self-actualization, provides mentorship at a very high level and prepares young women for independence.

On completion of the SEEDs Teacher Training Certification Program I will bring this program back to Oakland and implement its twelve year successful track record mentoring young women to be healthy and strong individuals who are socially and fiscally responsible to themselves and their community. The program I will create in Oakland will accept teen girls for a full academic year and will include after-school classes 1 ½ hours each three days per week. The program will include Middle Eastern Dance instruction, specifically American Tribal Style (ATS) dance, talking circles, journal writing and presentations.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I need $1500 to cover my expenses of the teaching certification program fee and for travel expenses.

In exchange for your donation I am offering some great perks!

$40- Receive a beautiful hip scarf coin belt. I will mail to you for free (in US only) and will do my best to get you your requested color. These hip scarves are high-quality, made to last and fun to wear!

$100-Receive a one-hour private belly dance lesson, in person or on Skype AND also receive a beautiful belly dance hip scarf or Bellydancewear T-shirt. 

$250-Live belly dance performance for your next special event

The Impact

Every community needs a program for this and I am excited and grateful to have the opportunity to bring it to the young women who need it most in our community. This program has hundreds of success stories of young women that were on a path of destructive behavior who transformed their lives The young women in our community need to know that we care about them and give them the knowledge and tools which we so often take for granted. If we want to change our community and our world then we need to powerfully impact women from an early age so that they can use these strategies for a lifetime.

This program has already been proven successful for over twelve years, so it will be easy to implement this program here with equal success and impact for years to come. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time but would still love to help then please share my campaign with anyone that you know that is passionate about dance and helping young women to become strong and empowered women and giving them the tools to lead healthy and fulfilling lives.

It's easy when you use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Why do we need your help?

Stage Left Players has a 21-year history in northeast Ohio. What started as a group of nomad actors has become an organization that prides itself on producing and performing high-quality children's and adult's shows.

A few years ago Stage Left acquired the Trinity Play House in Lisbon, Ohio, an old Presbyterian church with a 100-year history.

Since then, the costs of maintaining the building has strained Stage Left's budget.

We're looking for some help fund our 21st season!

The Impact

Every year Stage Left produces 4-5 adult shows and 3 children's shows, not including Stage Left's musical theater summer camp.

Your contributions will go towards subsidizing the cost of performing those shows including theatrical rights, set construction, costumes and more!

That allows ticket money to go towards some necessary maintenance around the play house including repaving and finishing the parking lot, having the roof inspected and repaired and other must-haves. 

Ticket money will also pay for the improvements we've already made like the new drapes, carpet and cushions we've added prior to our season opener, "Young Frankenstein the Musical."

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate your money, please donate your time! Please share this fundraising campaign on social media! Make sure to visit our website and "like" our Facebook page.

Also, if you're looking to volunteer at Stage Left, we'd be happy to have you! We always need volunteers to help with set construction, set painting, tickets, promotion and many other things!


Perks

$1 - Every Dollar Counts!

Thanks so much for doing your part to support Stage Left Players!

$5 - A Word of Thanks!

If you donate $5 to Stage Left, we’ll give you a shout out on our Facebook page. You will also be listed as a supporter on our website.

$15 - Show Off Your Support!

Donating $15 will get you the perks above, but you’ll also receive a nifty Stage Left Players bumper sticker to show off to all your friends.

$25 - Be One of the Team!

If you donate $25, you’ll get all of the perks above plus a signed cast photo and a ticket to Stage Left’s production of “Belles.”

$50 - Get Your Name in Print!

We know $50 is a lot of money, so we’re giving you some ink (in our program that is). You’ll receive all of the perks above plus an additional ticket to “Belles,” and your name will be listed in our program all season!

$100 - Act I Patron

Get all of the awesome perks above plus one season ticket and one, super-cool, Stage Left Players t-shirt!

$150 - Act I Patron + 

This level of donation gets you a Stage Left embroidered hoodie instead of a t-shirt. Winter is coming!

$250 - Act I Patron ++ 

This is our most popular option! Donate $250 to Stage Left and you’ll receive all of the perks above (including the t-shirt) plus:

  • A Stage Left Mug

  • A Stage Left 2013-2014 Calendar

  • One ticket to Stage Left’s Christmas Spectacular, “Jingle My Bell 2.”

$350 - Act II Patron

Words cannot express our gratitude, but fun thank-you gifts can! Get all of the perks above plus:

  • Your name on our recognition board in the play house

  • An additional ticket to “Jingle My Bell.”

$500 - Spotlight Patron

Woot woot! We dig your support! This level of donation comes with all the great gifts about plus:

  • One additional season ticket (that’s 2 tickets, if you’re counting)

  • A $25 gift card to The Shale Restaurant

  • A full-page ad in our program (for the season?)

$1000 - Curtain Call

You love us! You really REALLY love us! When you donate $1000 you’ll get all of the the previous perks AND:

  • A special recognition plaque for your home or office

  • 4 friend passes that can be used for any of our regular season shows

  • A warm Stage Left fleece blanket

$2000+ Superstar!

We’re going to see your name in lights! Not really, but we’re going to do our best to make it happen! You get all of the above perks AND the following:

  • A private preview show for up to 150 people, including appetizers and beverages

  • A personal phone call from Stage Left’s resident artistic director, Kandace Cleland

  • Dinner at Chef’s Table

story:
Summary

Inspired by the April 1999 massacre at Columbine High School, columbinus illuminates the dark realities of teenage popularity through its exploration of eight adolescent characters, each of whom faces his or her own difficulties, and culminates in the deadliest high school shooting in American history.

Written by Stephen Karam and PJ Paparelli

Directed by Drew Guerra

Produced by Alana Basil and Sam Freedman

Performances will be on April 12 and 13

 

What We Need!

We need more money in order to make this year's Struble Project the best show that it can be.

Any amount counts!

Money will go towards

  • costumes
  • programs
  • posters
  • lighting
  • and more

We are willing to give incentives such as

  • posters signed by the cast
  • a Columbinus signed T-Shirt
  • a meet and greet with the cast

Please donate any amount of money to our cause!

 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR HELP!

story:
Frank Sent Me Edinburgh Fringe Campaign!

Please help Writer's Avenue take the new play, Frank Sent Me, to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival!

Frank Sent Me shall be held at The Diary Room in The Underbelly, one of Edinburgh Fringe Festival's largest venue operations! 

ABOUT THE PLAY

 Frank Sent Me by Julian Poidevin.

Blake wants to complete his first day of "work experience".

Wallace doesn't want blood on his clean carpet. 

Howe wants to be "taken out" by a professional.

Frank wants the job done by noon.

If you mess up, you gracefully accept the punishment. East End gangster, Howe, waits patiently in his flat with his prim and proper “partner” in crime but things take an unexpected turn when Frank sends an inexperienced boy to do a man’s job.

(A dark comedy)


Frank Sent Me is a winning play of Writer's Avenue's, The First 20 Minutes competition and Julian Poidevin's first play. He has since gone on to write for BBC Radio. 

ABOUT THE DIRECTOR

Frank Sent Me shall be directed Peter Darney who has had success at Edinburgh Fringe Festival with 4 star reviews.


Peter Darney is an award winning director of theatre and radio, with ten years industry experience.

Peter directed  Githa (C-Nova, Edinburgh Festival, 2012), which  transferred to York Theatre Royal and The St James Theatre in London’s West End for critically acclaimed sell-out runs 

“What art should be” the Scotsman ****

“See the fine revival of Githa” Lynn Gardner, the Guardian 

His production of Mysterious Skin played the Gilded balloon(2011) and achieved 8 5 star reviews, and was shortlisted for numerous awards.It transferred for sell out runs at the Drill Hall and the Teachers Club In Dublin“

"Devastatingly simple..played perfectly under Peter Darney's nuanced direction. One of the best Pieces of writing on the fringe. This is theatre for grown ups. Stunning" Broadway Baby *****

He recently directed Julian’s BBC Radio Drama Kindness, which was pick of the week in the Telegraph and the Radio Times 

“Compelling and excellent phycological drama” The DailyMail, ***** 

Other credits include Tom’s Midnight Garden (Open Air, Oxfordshire), Edward II (Rose Theatre Bankside), 6 Degrees (Writers Avenue/Soho Theatre) Arden of Faversham (Rose Theatre Bankside)  Promises Promises (Theatre On the Hill) and Beautiful Thing (BAC)  

Help us give Frank Sent Me the exposure it deserves!


ABOUT WRITER'S AVENUE THEATRE COMPANY

Writer's Avenue Theatre Company is a London based producer of new writing with a mission to discover, develop and showcase new exciting writing talent.

The company is best known for its consistent sell out, unique and entertaining Unleashed Showcases: new writing events and competitions that showcase emerging talent (writers, actors and directors) in front of top industry professionals. Showcases take place at Soho Theatre and The Pleasance in London. 

Writer's Avenue is run by Artistic Director & Producer Sandra Thompson-Quartey.

Writer's Avenue has launched a £5 campaign to raise money towards taking a play to Edinburgh Fringe for the very first time!


IMPACT


Your support is valuable to us. The success of the play would allow us to do the following:

  1. Give exposure to a fantastic play we have proven audiences want to see
  2. Bring our work to new audiences
  3. A possibility of a London run in 2015


What We Need 

We need to raise at least £15,000 to enable us to take Frank Sent Me for a 4 week run at the Edinburgh festival. We plan to raise funds through a combination of funding applications, events and crowd funding, which is where you come in! Your generosity will go towards:

  1. Artists (writer, director, actors)
  2. Production and creative team
  3. Theatre venue hire
  4. Rehearsal space hire
  5. Set, props and costume
  6. Travel to Edinburgh
  7. Accommodation in Edinburgh
  8. Marketing materials

If we do not reach our target we shall have a shorter run at the Edinburgh Fringe

Successes and Achievements

  • Successfully running sell out new writing events as Soho Theatre and The Pleasance for four years.

  • Showcases are attended by top industry professionals. Artists have gained agent representation, work and/or valuable contacts from shows.

  • Hundreds of scripts are submitted for each project from all over the UK

  • High standard of talented actors who performed in our shows can be seen as regulars on shows such as YOUNGERS (Channel 4) and HOLLYOAKS (Channel 4), others have gone to work at The Globe or The National Theatre. Writers have had scripts requested by companies such as BBC Writersroom or have gone on to have work presented at the Royal Court to name a few.

Feel free to get in touch by emailing info@writersavenue.co.uk for the attention of Sandra Thompson-Quartey.


Note from the Artistic Director-Sandra Thompson-Quartey

" Writer's Avenue progresses every year. 

Raising a good percentage of the budget for Frank Sent Me will increase the chances of successful funding applications.

I would like to say a massive thanks to all who have taken part in the shows and everyone who have been attending them. Please support us and donate £5 (or more if you like) so we can head to Edinburgh with a great play and produce more in the future."



Other Ways You Can Help

We know that times are tough and not everyone can contribute but you can still help us in other ways:

  • Use social networking to spread the news about our campaign
  • Talk to people about our campaign and the work we do

Howe wants to be "taken out" by a professional.
Frank wants the job done by noon.
If you mess up, you gracefully accept the
punishment. East End gangster, Howe, waits patiently in his flat with his prim
and proper “partner” in crime but things take an unexpected turn when Frank sends
an inexperienced boy to do a man’s job.
(A dark comedy)





Frank Sent Me is a winning play of Writer's Avenue's, The First 20 Minutes competition and Julian Poidevin's first play. He has since gone on to write for BBC Radio. ABOUT THE DIRECTORFrank Sent Me shall be directed Peter Darney who has had success at Edinburgh Fringe Festival with 4 star reviews.




Peter Darney is an award winning director of theatre and radio, with ten years industry experience. Peter directed  Githa (C-Nova, Edinburgh Festival, 2012), which  transferred to York Theatre Royal and The St James Theatre in London’s West End for critically acclaimed sell-out runs “What art should be” the Scotsman ****“See the fine revival of Githa” Lynn Gardner, the Guardian His production of Mysterious Skin played the Gilded balloon(2011) and achieved 8 5 star reviews, and was shortlisted for numerous awards.It transferred for sell out runs at the Drill Hall and the Teachers Club In Dublin“"Devastatingly simple..played perfectly under Peter Darney's nuanced direction. One of the best Pieces of writing on the fringe. This is theatre for grown ups. Stunning" Broadway Baby *****He recently directed Julian’s BBC Radio Drama Kindness, which was pick of the week in the Telegraph and the Radio Times “Compelling and excellent phycological drama” The DailyMail, ***** Other credits include Tom’s Midnight Garden (Open Air, Oxfordshire), Edward II (Rose Theatre Bankside), 6 Degrees (Writers Avenue/Soho Theatre) Arden of Faversham (Rose Theatre Bankside)  Promises Promises (Theatre On the Hill) and Beautiful Thing (BAC)  Help us give Frank Sent Me the exposure it deserves!ABOUT WRITER'S AVENUE THEATRE COMPANYWriter's Avenue Theatre Company is a London based producer of new writing with a mission to discover, develop and showcase new exciting writing talent.The company is best known for its consistent sell out, unique and entertaining Unleashed Showcases: new writing events and competitions that showcase emerging talent (writers, actors and directors) in front of top industry professionals. Showcases take place at Soho Theatre and The Pleasance in London. Writer's Avenue is run by Artistic Director & Producer Sandra Thompson-Quartey.Writer's Avenue has launched a £5 campaign to raise money towards taking a play to Edinburgh Fringe for the very first time!IMPACTYour support is valuable to us. The success of the play would allow us to do the following:

Give exposure to a fantastic play we have proven audiences want to see

Bring our work to new audiences
A possibility of a London run in 2015
What We Need We need to raise at least £15,000 to enable us to take Frank Sent Me for a 4 week run at the Edinburgh festival. We plan to raise funds through a combination of funding applications, events and crowd funding, which is where you come in! Your generosity will go towards:

Artists (writer, director, actors)

Production and creative team
Theatre venue hire

Rehearsal space hire
Set, props and costume
Travel to Edinburgh
Accommodation in Edinburgh
Marketing materials
If we do not reach our target we shall have a shorter run at the Edinburgh FringeSuccesses and Achievements
Successfully running sell out new writing events as Soho Theatre and The Pleasance for four years.
Showcases are attended by top industry professionals. Artists have gained agent representation, work and/or valuable contacts from shows. 
Hundreds of scripts are submitted for each project from all over the UK
High standard of talented actors who performed in our shows can be seen as regulars on shows such as YOUNGERS (Channel 4) and HOLLYOAKS (Channel 4), others have gone to work at The Globe or The National Theatre. Writers have had scripts requested by companies such as BBC Writersroom or have gone on to have work presented at the Royal Court to name a few.
Feel free to get in touch by emailing 
info@writersavenue.co.uk for the attention of Sandra Thompson-Quartey.Note from the Artistic Director-Sandra Thompson-Quartey" Writer's Avenue progresses every year. Raising a good percentage of the budget for Frank Sent Me will increase the chances of successful funding applications.I would like to say a massive thanks to all who have taken part in the shows and everyone who have been attending them. Please support us and donate £5 (or more if you like) so we can head to Edinburgh with a great play and produce more in the future."Other Ways You Can HelpWe know that times are tough and not everyone can contribute but you can still help us in other ways:
Use social networking to spread the news about our campaign
Talk to people about our campaign and the work we do

story:
Trolley Dances Riverside is a trade-marked event that mirrors the 15 year running San Diego Trolley Dances committed to providing opportunities to local dancers and choreographers while simultaneously bringing the art of dance literally into the streets. Community engagement is at the crux of this project. Each year the event in Riverside will occur along a different RTA bus route reaching out to different neighborhoods. This fundraising campaign is a follow up to try and reach the original goal. We are extremely grateful to those who contributed in the summer!

Hope to see you in 2014.

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/trolley-dances-riverside/x/3656729

Visit http://www.trolleydancesriverside.com for more information...

photography: Michael J Elderman

story:
We are PearlArts Studios / STAYCEE PEARL dance project and Tuff Sound Recording. We humbly ask for your help in raising $15,000 in support of our youth programming, which we provide at no charge to our high-school students, our movement residency program, and meaningful pay for our dancers time, energy and expertise as we begin work on our new project UNTITLED: I’d rather not say.

In addition, we will host THE HOUSE PARTY

DJ Soy Sos is breaking out the throwback beats that we remember dancing to all night long with no cares in sight and the promise of waking up the next day just to do it all again. It's a party in signature PearlArts style that blends awesome music mixes, great-looking dance, and contagious energy. We'll transport you from our Point Breeze studio to a classic Brooklyn loft party. 

8 PM - 2 AM | VIP LOUNGE and DANCE PARTY: $60
10 PM - 2 AM | DANCE PARTY TICKETS: $20

VIP LOUNGE includes drinks and hors d'oeuvres, exclusive performances, and dance party

DANCE PARTY TICKET includes a special midnight performance and dance party all night!!!

PearlArts Studios/STAYCEE PEARL dance project (PAS/SPdp) exists to interpret and mirror culture and community through dance and dance centered multi-media experiences. With diverse casting and programing, PAS/SPdp explores innovative and often juxtaposed conceptual possibilities while participating in meaningful collaborations with artists, educators, musicians, choreographers, and activists. PAS/SPdp is a single-choreographer driven, professional organization, that produces dynamic dance performances, layered visual and sonic artistic presentation, and programming around compelling concepts and themes relevant to current social/political and community issues. PAS/SPdp often illuminates and interprets the works of celebrated legendary and contemporary figures of the African Diaspora. Examples of such projects include OCTAVIA, which explores the life and work of famed African American Science Fiction novelist, Octavia Butler, and  ...on being..., where we focus on ideas around identity, most specifically Post-Blackness. 

We started out as PearlArts: movement and sound in 2006 when asked to participate in a couples exhibition, EQUIPOISE, for the ArtUP Gallery. Since then, we have collaborated on several multi-media projects including RECOIL, a fantastical narrative installation incorporating sculpture, dance, and animated illustration, and  Named-Unnamed: the sound-installation, conceived of  boldly recognizing slain Iraqi civilians.  STAYCEE PEARL dance project (SPdp) began as an informal incubator for movement exploration in the Fall of 2009 with ten dance students. The group then settled into a cohesive six, and the new ensemble debuted its first official concert, PUPA, in 2010 at the Kelly-Strayhorn Theater. In the Fall of 2010, the Kelly-Strayhorn Theater extended a season-long residency into a longer opportunity, naming SPdp the resident dance company for the theater.

PAS/SPdp now resides in a beautiful 2000 square foot studio with a 27x32 foot sprung dance floor, office, and space to create sound and visual art. We enjoy sharing this space with our community by offering classes and workshops lead by local, national and international artists. We also provide residency opportunities especially for movement artists who are interested in exploring collaboration with other art forms.

Our  youth programming includes going into area schools daily, bringing dance and dance composition to K -8th graders, while we conduct workshops and provide performance opportunities for 9 - 12 graders in our studios. We pretty much have our in-school programs covered, thankfully, but we could use support of our youth activities including instructor pay, snacks, and expenses related to our space.

PearlArts offers 2 - 3 movement residency opportunities per year, which cost $8000 for us to manage and produce. Our residencies have given emerging choreographers space and time in our studio to work on choreography, collaborate with musicians and visual artists, then produce a showing of their work at our studio. We engage peers and mentors, by inviting them to a preview where residency artists are provided feedback, then we assist in marketing and provide resources and information to move their projects forward. 

Finally, UNTITLED: I’d rather not say,  represents new artistic inspiration for our creative team. After two very heady concept-driven seasons, we are in a place to truly enjoy using movement as our conceptual focus. We will still create interesting sound, and juxtapose spacial installation and video, however, these elements will respond to the generated blocking, gestures, and vocabulary of our choreography. We are excited about the challenge of eliminating the narrative, and abstract conceptual idea, to explore  pure movement. We are then interested in why and how people move. What gestures and mannerisms are culturally inspired? Historically and culturally, how does the idea of movement and line making with the body take shape, and how does improvisation fit into this picture?

We are at the very beginning stages of this project, and will have a couple of work-in-progress viewing sessions over the next year including October 26th, 9 pm at PearlArts Studios, May 2nd 2014 at the Alloy Studios, both in Pittsburgh. UNTITLED is scheduled to premier in January of 2015.

Thank you in advance for any level of support!

Please spread the word about our HOUSE PARTY!!!

Sincerely,

Staycee and Herman / PearlArts Studios

<3

story:
“To thine own self be true” is a quote from “Hamlet” that Shakespeare in Detroit founder, Sam White, holds close to her heart. Living an authentic life, built from your passions to impact the lives of others was the motivation for her to produce her first full-fledged Shakespeare production, “Othello” at Grand Circus Park in August 2013.

It was a prototype, of sorts, to see if there is an audience in her hometown that would be interested in a Shakespeare company in the city. There are, of course, universities and other theater groups in the area that perform the works of The Bard. But, the mission of Shakespeare in Detroit was to explore the possibility of creating a company that would perform his work season after season.

To the surprise and delight of the entire SiD team, more than 500 people showed up for the company’s debut production of “Othello.” This motivated four more productions the following year and in 2014 they performed “Antony and Cleopatra” at Recycle Here, “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at New Center Park (Grand Circus Park and The Whitney), “Romeo and Juliet” at Grand Circus Park and Mumford High School, and “The Tempest” at the YMCA’s Marlene Boll Theatre in downtown Detroit. 

To date, the company has engaged with nearly 3, 000 residents in the city, surrounding areas and more.

SiD has been supported through some community donations such as a Detroit SOUP grant, other small community donations, some ticket sales and summer sponsorships. It has also been funded through its founder’s personal investment in the company that aims to produce one free, summer show a year. This year, that show will be “Macbeth” at New Center Park. The show runs July 16 -19, 2015 and has been partially funded through a grant from the Michigan Council for Arts and Cultural Affairs for $2400.00. However, SiD needs to match this grant and raise additional funding for the rest of its 2015 endeavors which also includes a ticketed performance of “King Lear” at Marygrove College in Detroit, Mich. April 9-19, 2015.

The funds raised through this crowdfunding campaign will be used to pay actors — all of whom are Michigan-based talent — as well as pay our crew members which range from costume design to stage management.

Please note: The gifts included in this campaign are also included in the goal as we have to pay for the items and ship them out to our supporters.

What began as a grassroots project to bring more Shakespeare to Detroit has evolved into much more than what our founder and our other members could have ever dreamed of. From receiving a great deal of media support from local residents and our friends across the globe to having patrons express interest in more shows, there is more work to do and we hope you can help.

If you have any more questions about SiD, please, visit the FAQ (http://www.shakespeareindetroit.com/#!faq/cheg) section of our website where you can find the answer to most questions. You can also email us at TeamShakespeareinDetroit@gmail.com if you have any questions or you just want to say hello.

Thank you in advance for your support and we hope to see you at a show, soon!

~ Team SiD

story:
New Fortune Theatre is proud to be a registered 501(c)3 nonprofit.  All contributions are tax-deductible. 

“What's New Fortune?”

New Fortune Theatre Company is an award-winning, critically-acclaimed nonprofit organization. And, we earned this success since our founding in 2014! 

Our inaugural production of Henry V by William Shakespeare was nominated for three Craig Noel awards by the San Diego Theatre Critic’s Circle. The production won two awards for Outstanding Direction and Outstanding Actor in a Lead Role, proud to be standing among the well-respected theatres of San Diego, including the Old Globe, La Jolla Playhouse, and San Diego REP. We were included in every single year-end, critic's-favorite list.  And, that was just our first show!

This initial success would not have been possible without generous donors like you. That first, award-winning, production which saw New Fortune smash onto the scene was entirely funded by crowd-funding right here on IndieGoGo and by your private donations.

"If you're so great, why do you need my gift?"

Good question.

It’s true that our founders, Richard Baird (Artistic Director), Amanda Schaar (Managing Director) and Matt Thompson (Head of New Works), each have a wealth of experience in the theatre, a great work ethic and a dedication to delivering productions of the highest quality. And it’s true that our staff, board of directors and company members all have the same commitment to producing superior works of theatrical art.

But NONE of this success would have been possible without contributions from giving people who want and encourage excellence in the theatre, like YOU. 

No theatre makes in on ticket sales alone. Continued patronage is a tradition as old as theatre itself. However good we are, we're only as good as our consistent contributors.

(Matt Henerson* as Fluellyn- he hopes you give)

We have exciting plans to unveil about our upcoming seasons! And, there’s something else that’s electrifying for us about the future of New Fortune. After we knock our next two seasons out of the park, we will be eligible for major public funding! 

That means:

  • We can find a home where we can produce full seasons and expand our education program!

  • We can pay staff for their full time administration duties. (Currently, we completely donate our time and efforts, which should speak to how highly we value this company's continuance.)

  • We can invest more deeply in the quality of our art, and quality of life for our artists.

But, we have to get there first and we can't do it without you! 

Henry V was produced entirely from crowd-funding and private donations. We raised nearly $15,000 on promises alone. Those were the promises of the talent we had on board and the combined experience of the whole New Fortune team. Now that we can show you the result of your financial faith in us in the form of awards and critical success, we hope you will be proud of your contribution and make another donation today! If you haven’t given yet, we hope that you will join us in building "the most high profile company to go live here in years" (UT San Diego).

And, your gift to New Fortune goes, in turn, goes directly into our local and national arts communities, one show of sparkling quality and intellectual integrity at a time. 

We advocate living wages for working artists, as well as active cross promotion and mutual support between organizations.

That means, the bigger we become the more good we can do. So the bigger your gift, the more good you're doing for the arts community!

(Matt Thompson as Exeter- he hopes you give)

“Tell me more about yourselves”

Gladly.

OUR MISSION:

New Fortune is proudly committed to presenting “Original Classics.”

That is to say, we present classical works as original, new, and relevant to today's society, which is, sadly, too rare in the U.S. these days.  Additionally, we present original works we consider to be (or become) modern classics. Our reading series has so far included the original, unpublished adaptations of Picture of Dorian Gray (adapted from Oscar Wilde by Richard Baird), and Wuthering Heights (adapted from Emily Bronte by Kirsten Brandt), as well as Cellar Door (a new play by Matt Thompson).  Plus, we are always reading new work submissions. (email info@newfortunetheatre.com, ATTN: New Work)

WHO WE ARE:

Prior to forming New Fortune Theatre Company, Richard (our Artistic Director) was the Founding Artistic Director of San Diego's Poor Players Theatre, directing over 20 productions of Shakespeare’s (and his contemporaries’) plays. Richard went on to perform and direct in some of the top theatres around the country, including Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Chicago Shakespeare and The Old Globe Theatre. Henry V was his 48th Shakespearean production, and he has since performed his 49th in Arizona Theatre Company's Romeo and Juliet (Mercutio/Friar Lawrence/Montague). 

Amanda (our Managing Director) met Richard while performing for and serving as Director of Educational Outreach for Southwest Shakespeare Company (where Richard was working as Associate Artistic Director). They suited each other so well, she went on to act in and serve as executive assistant to Richard for two of the final productions of Poor Players (Richard II & Measure for Measure). An accomplished actress, musician, dancer and writer, Amanda has worked widely in both classical and experimental venues nationwide, and has over 10 years of experience in theatre administration, including as founding Co-Artistic Director of her own 501(c)3 Into Theatre, a children's theatre.

Matt (our Head of New Works) met Richard and Amanda while performing at one of our favorite theatres, North Coast Repertory Theatre.  There, Matt served as Artistic Associate, Literary Manager and Director of Education. Matt is also Founding Artistic Director of Compass Theatre and Enterprise Theatre Company. A published playwright, Matt has over twenty titles in print through Dramatic, Heuer, Brooklyn and Eldridge Publishing. 

Together, with their extensive backgrounds spanning centuries and forms, Richard, Amanda and Matt founded New Fortune Theatre Company; committed to presenting Original Classics.


(Richard Baird and Amanda Schaar as Heathcliff and Catherin hope you give)

“Ok, you sound legit. But what exactly does my gift do?”

Another good question!

In a recent Commission of Arts and Culture meeting Amanda met the Managing Director of another small theatre in San Diego. Amanda asked, '”How do you structure your budget to pay your full cast’s union wages?' The other MD replied, “It's hard, you know, we only have a $300,000 annual budget.” Amanda laughed, “Of course it's hard!” What Amanda didn't add is that New Fortune’s annual budget is currently less than $25,000. 

Despite that, New Fortune Theatre employed two union actors above the minimum scale, and paid every single actor and technician. Talent is our product, and we respect that in every way we are able.

Theatre is an expensive proposition: renting the venue for performance, the rehearsal space, the director, the actors, the flights, the housing, the stage manager, the assistant stage managers, the technical director, the set designer, the set itself, the costume designer, the costumes themselves, the lighting designer, the sound designer, marketing, development, box office, front of house, printing, union dues, (& union mandated coffee, yes that's real), insurance, printing costs... even down to the program you hold in your hands which has been painstakingly comparative-price-researched, after being formatted, submitted to a general vote of whether or not to do the inside in color, and double and triple checked by everyone with a bio involved, not to mention advertisers, oh, and of course the graphic artist commissioned to do the art! (We are fortunate to have the amazing Gedimin Bulat on our side www.gedimin.com.)

(Lady Fortune of our logo hopes you give)


Frankly, it's just expensive to produce a show. That's why you see so many productions set in a single-set living room with a cast of 5 or 6 actors, usually addressing one or more “hot button issues”: racism, sexism, sexuality, addiction, violence, politics, religion, or all of the above! 

These sorts of plays are comparatively cheap to produce andthey have a built-in, button-pushed audience. 

That's also the reason why theatres tend to produce shows that THEY know that YOU know like Much Ado About Nothing, South Pacific or Noises Off, to name a few. 

Now, these are great shows! That's why they're so popular! But what about all the other great shows that you may not have heard of? Odds are you won't get to hear of them, because most theatres don't want to take the risk of you not attending. Or, if you're still reading, you may be one of industrious aficionados who has discovered these great, lesser known works and would love to see them produced!

We want to bring them to you! We're not trying to be elitist or mysterious or quirky here. We believe there is great work to be done that most professionals are dying to do, but that most producers feel uncomfortable producing. They don’t trust you to come.

We believe that great work should speak for itself. We trust that you are passionate theatre-goers who are brave enough to go see something new, especially since you’ll know any work we produce will be of tremendous quality. Quality is what we are banking on. We intend to produce work of such consistent and excellent quality that no matter whatthe show may be called, you will know that it's going to be great. 

That iswhat your donation makes possible!

If you look at the acclaim we’ve received with a nearly nonexistent budget, professionally speaking, and if you look at the award-winning company we’ve created from thin air, you’ll know that quality is exactly what you can expect from New Fortune Theatre Company.

Whatever you can contribute, large or small, makes a huge impact. So, “Hie to high Fortune!” Be our Queen Elizabeth! Become our patron today! Your gift is tax-deductible and goes straight through New Fortune into our arts community, which we all know needs a lot of love. So, give a gift to the arts today!

"I'd love to, but I don't have an extra $20,000 lying around. Or $20.00 for that matter..."

If you can't contribute today, contribute another day! And if you can't contribute on any day, it doesn't mean you can't still help! Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word! Join our mailing list! Talk to your friends! Talk to us! See a show! Send cookies backstage, and let artists know you care! We’re all in this together.

Thank you for your continued support!

(Richard Baird* and Matt Henerson*)

(Cast of Henry V)

inaugural production of Henry V by
William Shakespeare was nominated for three Craig Noel awards by the San
Diego Theatre Critic’s Circle. The
production won two awards for Outstanding
Direction and Outstanding Actor in a Lead Role, proud to be standing among the well-respected
theatres of San Diego, including the Old Globe, La Jolla Playhouse, and San Diego REP. We were included in every
single year-end, critic's-favorite list. 
And, that was just our first show!


This
initial success would not have been possible without generous donors like you. That first, award-winning, production which
saw New Fortune smash onto the scene was entirely funded by crowd-funding right here on
IndieGoGo and by your private donations.
"If
you're so great, why do you need my gift?"


Good
question.
It’s
true that our founders, Richard Baird (Artistic Director), Amanda Schaar
(Managing Director) and Matt Thompson (Head of New Works), each have a wealth
of experience in the theatre, a great work ethic and a dedication to delivering
productions of the highest quality. And
it’s true that our staff, board of directors and company members all have the
same commitment to producing superior works of theatrical art. 
But
NONE of this success would have been possible without contributions from giving
people who want and encourage excellence in the theatre, like YOU. 

 No theatre makes in on ticket sales alone. Continued patronage is a tradition as old as theatre
itself. However good we are, we're only as good as our consistent contributors.

(Matt Henerson* as Fluellyn- he hopes you give)


We have
exciting plans to unveil about our upcoming seasons! And, there’s
something else that’s electrifying for us
about the future of New Fortune. After we knock our next two seasons out of the
park, we will be eligible for major
public funding! 
That
means: 

We can find a home where
we can produce full seasons and expand our education program!
We can pay staff for their full time
administration duties. (Currently, we completely donate our time and efforts,
which should speak to how highly we value this company's continuance.)
We can invest more deeply in the
quality of our art, and quality of life for our artists.

But, we
have to get there first and we can't do it without you! 


Henry V was produced entirely from
crowd-funding and private donations. We raised nearly $15,000 on promises
alone. Those were the promises of the talent we had on board and the combined
experience of the whole New Fortune team. Now that we can show you the result
of your financial faith in us in the form of awards and critical success, we
hope you will be proud of your contribution and make another donation
today! If you haven’t given yet, we hope that you will join us in building "the
most high profile company to go live here in years" (UT San Diego).
And,
your gift to New Fortune goes, in turn, goes directly into our local and national arts
communities, one show of sparkling quality and intellectual integrity at a
time. 
We
advocate living wages for working artists, as well as active cross promotion
and mutual support between organizations.
That
means, the bigger we become the more good we can do. So the bigger your gift,
the more good you're doing for the arts community!




(Matt Thompson as Exeter- he hopes you give)


“Tell me
more about yourselves” 
Gladly.
OUR MISSION:
New
Fortune is proudly committed to presenting “Original Classics.”
That is
to say, we present classical works as original, new, and relevant to today's
society, which is, sadly, too rare in the U.S. these days.  Additionally, we present original works we
consider to be (or become) modern classics. Our reading series has so far
included the original, unpublished adaptations of Picture of Dorian Gray (adapted
from Oscar Wilde by Richard Baird), and Wuthering Heights (adapted from
Emily Bronte by Kirsten Brandt), as well as Cellar Door (a new play by
Matt Thompson).  Plus, we are always reading
new work submissions. (email info@newfortunetheatre.com, ATTN: New Work)
WHO WE ARE:
Prior to
forming New Fortune Theatre Company,
Richard (our Artistic Director) was the Founding Artistic Director of San
Diego's Poor Players Theatre, directing over 20 productions of Shakespeare’s
(and his contemporaries’) plays. Richard went on to perform and direct in some
of the top theatres around the country, including Oregon Shakespeare Festival,
Chicago Shakespeare and The Old Globe Theatre. Henry V was his 48th
Shakespearean production, and he has since performed his 49th in Arizona
Theatre Company's Romeo and Juliet (Mercutio/Friar Lawrence/Montague). 
Amanda (our
Managing Director) met Richard while performing for and serving as Director of
Educational Outreach for Southwest Shakespeare Company (where Richard was
working as Associate Artistic Director). They suited each other so well, she
went on to act in and serve as executive assistant to Richard for two of the
final productions of Poor Players (Richard II & Measure for
Measure). An accomplished actress, musician, dancer and writer, Amanda has
worked widely in both classical and experimental venues nationwide, and has
over 10 years of experience in theatre administration, including as founding
Co-Artistic Director of her own 501(c)3 Into Theatre, a children's theatre.
Matt (our
Head of New Works) met Richard and Amanda while performing at one of our
favorite theatres, North Coast Repertory Theatre.  There, Matt served as Artistic Associate,
Literary Manager and Director of Education. Matt is also Founding Artistic
Director of Compass Theatre and Enterprise Theatre Company. A published
playwright, Matt has over twenty titles in print through Dramatic, Heuer,
Brooklyn and Eldridge Publishing. 
Together,
with their extensive backgrounds spanning centuries and forms, Richard, Amanda
and Matt founded New Fortune Theatre Company; committed to presenting Original
Classics.




(Richard Baird and Amanda Schaar as Heathcliff and Catherin hope you give)


“Ok,
you sound legit. But what exactly
does my gift do?”
Another
good question!
In a
recent Commission of Arts and Culture meeting Amanda met the Managing Director
of another small theatre in San Diego. Amanda asked, '”How do you structure your budget to pay your full cast’s union
wages?' The other MD replied, “It's hard, you know, we only have a $300,000
annual budget.” Amanda laughed, “Of course it's hard!” What Amanda didn't add
is that New Fortune’s annual budget is currently less than $25,000. 
Despite
that, New Fortune Theatre employed two union actors above the minimum scale,
and paid every single actor and technician. Talent is our product, and we
respect that in every way we are able.
Theatre is an expensive
proposition: renting
the venue for performance, the rehearsal space, the director, the actors, the
flights, the housing, the stage manager, the assistant stage managers, the
technical director, the set designer, the set itself, the costume designer, the
costumes themselves, the lighting designer, the sound designer, marketing,
development, box office, front of house, printing, union dues, (& union
mandated coffee, yes that's real), insurance, printing costs... even down to
the program you hold in your hands which has been painstakingly comparative-price-researched,
after being formatted, submitted to a general vote of whether or not to do the
inside in color, and double and triple checked by everyone with a bio involved,
not to mention advertisers, oh, and of course the graphic artist commissioned
to do the art! (We are fortunate to have the amazing Gedimin Bulat on our side www.gedimin.com.)

(Lady Fortune of our logo hopes you give)

Frankly,
it's just expensive to produce a show. That's why you see so many productions
set in a single-set living room with a cast of 5 or 6 actors, usually
addressing one or more “hot button issues”: racism, sexism, sexuality,
addiction, violence, politics, religion, or all of the above! 
These
sorts of plays are comparatively cheap to produce andthey have a
built-in, button-pushed audience. 
That's
also the reason why theatres tend to produce shows that THEY know that YOU know
like Much Ado About Nothing, South Pacific or Noises Off, to name a few. 

Now,
these are great shows! That's why they're so popular! But what about all the other great shows that you may not have heard
of? Odds are you won't get to hear of them, because most theatres don't
want to take the risk of you not attending. Or, if you're still reading, you
may be one of industrious aficionados who has discovered these great, lesser
known works and would love to see them produced!
We
want to bring them to you! We're not trying to be elitist or mysterious or
quirky here. We believe there is great work to be done that most professionals are
dying to do, but that most producers feel uncomfortable producing. They
don’t trust you to come.
We believe that great work should speak for
itself. We
trust that you are passionate theatre-goers who are brave enough to go see
something new, especially since you’ll know any work we produce will be of
tremendous quality. Quality is what we
are banking on. We intend to produce work of such consistent and excellent
quality that no matter whatthe
show may be called, you will know that it's going to be great. 
That iswhat
your donation makes possible!
If
you look at the acclaim we’ve received with a nearly nonexistent budget,
professionally speaking, and if you look at the award-winning company we’ve
created from thin air, you’ll know that quality is exactly what you can expect
from New Fortune Theatre Company.
Whatever
you can contribute, large or small, makes a huge impact. So, “Hie to high Fortune!” Be our Queen
Elizabeth! Become our patron today! Your
gift is tax-deductible and goes straight through New Fortune into our arts
community, which we all know needs a lot of love. So, give a gift to the arts
today!

"I'd
love to, but I don't have an extra $20,000 lying around. Or $20.00 for that
matter..."
If you
can't contribute today, contribute another day! And if you can't contribute on any
day, it doesn't mean you can't still help! Get the word out and make some noise
about our campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word! Join our
mailing list! Talk to your friends! Talk to us! See a show! Send cookies
backstage, and let artists know you care! We’re all in this together.
Thank you
for your continued support!



(Richard Baird* and Matt Henerson*)

(Cast of Henry V)

story:
Street Theatre Company is a professional non-profit arts organization dedicated to pioneering innovative modern musical theatre in Nashville.  Our aim is to engage our audience with universal stories that speak to the human experience and challenge conversation, to support local artists, to provide arts education to children of all ages, and to foster a new generation of theatre arts participants and supporters.  

Our typical budget is about $15,000 per production. While we seek individual donations, grant support and corporate sponsorship to help underwrite our shows, we also need your help as a funder.

Arts and culture are frequently the first items in the budget to be cut. We want to make it possible for all to see live theatre regardless of their situation. We believe that the arts are for everyone and that there should be no economic barriers between audience and art.

story:
WHY - The ABRIDGED VERSION if you want to find out what we’re about, but simply don’t have the time to read the whole campaign.  We get it!  Here goes:

We are two one-woman companies teaming together to produce an originally-written work by a female playwright as part of our mutual desire to create our own opportunities in a sometimes lacking environment, as Geena Davis has been quoted, “Yes, we can and will work to tell more women’s stories, listen to more women’s voices and write richer female characters”. 

With your help, we can make our contribution to Vancouver’s independent theatre landscape and expand upon the great companies that are already working so shrewdly to develop and grow independent theatre here in Vancouver. It is at the grass-roots that the true evolution of theatre and the arts takes place. And, in a world where technology rules and human and social interaction is arguably at an all-time low, there is more need now for the arts than there ever has been and theatre is still an accessible venue for discussion and emotion, an outlet for release, and for change.

So if you're able your financial support is invaluable, IN ANY AMOUNT! so that we can actually do what we are setting out to do.   THANK YOU SO MUCH for taking the time to check out our campaign. 

AND...

If you’re not in a position to contribute, please SHARE OUR CAMPAIGN to your social media groups using this short link igg.me/at/after-play

And for more information about the show and it's run, find us on FACEBOOK, https://www.facebook.com/events/500506176737104/  

or follow us on TWITTER @dreamofpassions #AFTERplay to help spread the word!

And now, for THE EXTENDED VERSION

WHY? - THE FINANCIALS

Our original fundraising goal for the play was to raise the cost of the venue, which is $2900.  We have already been raising money the old fashioned way, and had an amazing turnout at our fundraiser, The Pre-AFTER Valentine's Day Party, where we managed to raise $776!  So, in light of this, we are now aiming to raise the difference, which is $2124. 

To go more into budgetary details:

When theatre companies are forecasting possible revenue gained from a production, the general rule is to assume that you will fill 30% of your seating capacity on average.  We have decided to have an early bird ticket price of $17 and a regular ticket price at $20.  Using these numbers and the 60-seat capacity of the Havana Theatre our magic number for average attendance is 18 people per night.  Given that everything is really based on a guesstimate, we’re using the $17 as the ticket price for 33% of the sales of this 30% capacity forecast, and 67% at $20.  All crunched together, our possible revenue from the show equals $3,764. Our expenses for the show, on a VERY modest budget, which includes some honorariums for our crew in the $50-100 range, are $4,955. Yes, that’s correct, you’re seeing and understanding things correctly, we lose money, almost certainly, with the aforementioned projected revenues. If you are at all business-minded, or are a number cruncher at all, like my mathematician friend, you’re probably about to say, “So you don’t make anything?  You don’t even break even...I don’t know how you artists do business!”  

HOWEVER!!! With raising the $776 dollars, we are now theoretically out of the RED!  But, we are still hoping to raise the rest of the cost of the venue, in case people would prefer to go hiking or skiing rather than seeing our fabulous cast scantily-clad dealing with their relationship problems!!!

Which brings us to...

WHY? - THE ARTISTIC WHY and IMPACT

As mentioned in our abridged version above, Geena Davis has been quoted as saying, “Yes, we can and will work to tell more women’s stories, listen to more women’s voices and write richer female characters”. Ironically, when I first decided that I wanted to produce AFTER as my inaugural production, it only partially had to do with the fact that the play was written by a female playwright.  And yes, at least this time around, as an actress working hard at creating a name for herself in the industry, there needed to be a female role appropriate for me. For the better, there are in fact, two roles for women and two roles for men, a fair and equitable, 50:50 split.

Fate as well would play a role in leading me to my FEMALE director.

It didn’t take long for me to think of Jessica Anne Nelson as a directorial option as we had worked together in the past and also remained friends.  Upon reading AFTER, Jessica was very excited to come on board and as an added benefit to me as a producer, Jessica was also interested in coming on board as a co-producer. Suddenly, we realized how cool this project was shaping up to be, with an originally written work by a female playwright, co-produced by two one-woman companies.  

As we moved forward and started involving crew we thought about how much cooler it would be to have a crew of all women, and how we could really be contributing to the independent theatre scene and changing its landscape, following in the footsteps of so many other independent theatre companies in Vancouver that have preceded us and have females at the helm: Staircase XI, Twenty Something Theatre, and delinquent theatre, to name only a few off the top of my head. The high density of females as the heads of these young theatre companies are paving the way to giving women exponentially more opportunities as they start to penetrate the higher echelons of senior theatre management and production in years to come, and we would love to contribute to that!

WHO?

dream of passion productions, created by Stefania Indelicato and Excavation Theatre created by Jessica Anne Nelson.  I, Stefania, am an actress, writer, producer, originally from the West Coast of Vancouver Island, who studied Theatre and Arts & Culture at the University of Toronto and since graduating have been developing a career as an actress in theatre, film and television.  Jessica Anne Nelson is my co-producer, and a director, writer, producer, who graduated from the University of British Columbia. Most notably, she was recently awarded the Onsite Award for her inaugural production of Meanwhile at the 2013 Vancouver Fringe Festival. Martha Herrera-Lasso the playwright of AFTER is a writer and Master’s Graduate of the University of British Columbia who is currently working on her PhD at Berkeley.  This project marks a creative reunion of sorts amongst the three of us.  

In the 2011 Vancouver Fringe Festival all three of us were involved in a presentation of Short and Sweet: Small Plays for Big Ideas.  Martha and I acted in the shows, and Jessica directed one of them. 

WHAT?

So what is this play about and why were we compelled to produce it?  Firstly, it has always been very exciting for me to work on original works, and to get to work on a play that is an originally-written work by a female playwright, is even more exciting when you think of the way that you are contributing to the artistic canon of work produced by female artists.  In addition, Jessica and I felt that this play was highly relatable to both men and women.  

It is a play about four people, a man and woman in their 20s and a man and woman in their 30s, each at different stages in their lives, who get themselves caught up in complicated and sometimes surprisingly emotional and confusing conversations, all taking place after sex.  Struggling to find their paths in life and in their interpersonal romantic relationships, this is an exploration of love and lust, intimacy and miscommunication, in a modern day society that is overwhelmed by choice.

In coming up with this campaign, and thinking about what the play is about, a certain phrase came to my mind #firstworldproblems.  I have never been a fan of this term.  There has always been something flippant about it that didn’t sit right with me, don’t we actually live in the first world....  The matter really did grow of concern to me as time went on and I had to commit to whether or not I wanted to go through with producing this play.  I have always loved being a part of work that is greater than itself, work that is for a cause, or deals with real issues, world issues if you will.  But still, I didn’t feel right about throwing away my problems as essentially being unfounded, or lacking any sort of importance due to the privileged country I’m blessed to have been born into.  

So, after already deciding to produce the play, Jessica and I, on a similar page with this, sought some guidance.   We came across a Huffington Post article written by psychologist Roger Covin, Ph.D., titled Why We Shouldn’t Discount First World Problems.  Covin addresses this phrase stating that, “...the habit of labeling many things as "first world" may compel us to make uninformed judgments of other people, and possibly strengthen existing misanthropic beliefs of people in general.” 

Through further research, I came across another article on The Atlantic Magazine official website, in an article titled, What’s Wrong With #FirstWorldProblems.  Written by Alexis C. Madrigal, the article cites an analysis of #FirstWorldProblems by Teju Cole, a writer, art historian, and photographer who was born in the US but raised in Nigeria.  Madrigal talks about how she was never a fan of the phrase but for some reason could never really put her finger on why.  She sought the same sort of guidance and critique, it seems, that we did and came across Cole.  Cole says, 

"I don't like this expression ‘First World Problems’ it is false and it is condescending. Yes, Nigerians struggle with floods or infant mortality. But these same Nigerians also deal with mundane and seemingly luxurious hassles. Connectivity issues on your BlackBerry, cost of car repair, how to sync your iPad, what brand of noodles to buy: Third World problems. All the silly stuff of life doesn't disappear just because you're black and live in a poorer country. People in the richer nations need a more robust sense of the lives being lived in the darker nations. Here's a First World problem: the inability to see that others are as fully complex and as keen on technology and pleasure as you are...None of this is to deny the existence of social stratification and elite structures [in Nigeria]. There are lifestyles of the rich and famous, sure. But the interesting thing about modern technology is how socially mobile it is--quite literally. Everyone in Lagos has a phone."

Ultimately, then, we hope that by presenting this piece to an audience, that we will help to give society some perspective about the way that we function in relationships today, not hoping to present these #firstworldproblems as the most difficult or complicated problems in the world, but as problems that we all share, all over the world.  Real problems, common even - in this play - problems primarily in miscommunication.

Of AFTER, Herrera-Lasso says, “I think miscommunication is really interesting and fun and also frustrating and inevitable, and this play is kind of about that. About miscommunication and intimacy and it being okay. So maybe by the time we leave the theatre we’ll all be a little more confused and intimate and okay with it than when we got here.”

IN CLOSING, 

Thank you so much for your time and consideration in helping us out!  If you’re not in a position to contribute you can still help out by sharing our campaign to your social media groups using this short link igg.me/at/after-play

Find info about AFTER on FACEBOOK, https://www.facebook.com/events/500506176737104/  

or follow us on TWITTER @dreamofpassions #AFTERplay to help spread the word!

Or, check out our event page http://after.brownpapertickets.com/ if you would like to attend!!!

All the silly stuff of life doesn't disappear just because you're black and live in a poorer country. People in the richer nations need a more robust sense of the lives being lived in the darker nations. Here's a First World problem: the inability to see that others are as fully complex and as keen on technology and pleasure as you are...None of this is to deny the existence of social stratification and elite structures [in Nigeria]. There are lifestyles of the rich and famous, sure. But the interesting thing about modern technology is how socially mobile it is--quite literally. Everyone in Lagos has a phone."
Ultimately, then, we hope that by presenting this piece to an audience, that we will help to give society some perspective about the way that we function in relationships today, not hoping to present these #firstworldproblems as the most difficult or complicated problems in the world, but as problems that we all share, all over the world.  Real problems, common even - in this play - problems primarily in miscommunication. 
Of AFTER, Herrera-Lasso says, “I think miscommunication is really interesting and fun and also frustrating and inevitable, and this play is kind of about that. About miscommunication and intimacy and it being okay. So maybe by the time we leave the theatre we’ll all be a little more confused and intimate and okay with it than when we got here.”IN CLOSING, Thank you so much for your time and consideration in helping us out!  If you’re not in a position to contribute you can still help out by sharing our campaign to your social media groups using this short link igg.me/at/after-play

Find info about AFTER on FACEBOOK, https://www.facebook.com/events/500506176737104/  

or follow us on TWITTER @dreamofpassions #AFTERplay to help spread the word!

Or, check out our event page http://after.brownpapertickets.com/ if you would like to attend!!!

story:
"A Work About Rebirth Is Reborn in a Company's Debut ...Art met reality in charming fashion" -New York Times-  

Greeting. Germaul Barnes/Viewsic Expressions Dance, in association with Kumble Theater, needs A Leg Up - Black Buddha Donations. Black Buddha is our first full-evening length performance premiering on September 21 and 22, 2012 at 7:30pm in the LIU-Kumble Theater. This will be a unique and exciting production featuring seven GB/VED dancers and two guest artists; Miguel Anaya - formerly with White Oak Dance Project and Nejla Yatkin - Director of NY2 Dance. Anchored within Germaul Barnes’ signature action-packed and chroeo-theatrical style, this 90-minute dance theatre piece dramatizes the true stories of an African American man's path towards enlightenment and his struggles against various forms of social prejudice. 

But we need A Leg Up to make Black Buddha possible. This project will provide opportunities & occupation to many NYC artist so we're teaming up with indiegogo.com to ask for contributions.  In exchange, we have rewards for every level of contribution from our “A Leg Up - Black Buddha” campaign.  Find one that excites you the most and jump on the GB/VED Bandwagon. Thanks! 

Budget Breakdown  

  • Your money goes directly to paying our amazing dancers. One-time salary for these 9 amazing dancers adds up to a whopping $8000. We need to raise money to pay them!  
  • Our operating budget is $17,000 for many expenses including Costumes, Set-design, Marketing, Administration fees, Travel/Transportation costs, Photographer, and Videographer.
  • Your contribution will directly aid the transformation of this historical theatre in Downtown Brooklyn to provide a desert backdrop for this journey. 

The estimated budget for this performance is a little over $25,000. We are humbly asking for your help in raising a little more than half of the project expenses. 

The Impact

Black Buddha is a rare blend of storytelling and dance, combining autobiographical solos with collective community issues through choreography. As we share our stories, we encourage others to share their experiences as well, often discovering that we are all telling versions of the same truth. As we face our fears and struggles, there is strength in knowing that we are not alone, and through our unique expressions, we can discover various pathways to healing and choose to become channels of enlightenment. Help us share this experience with our communtiy and ensure that these dancers get paid for their incredible time and talent.  Also, your generous support will invest in the development of GB/VED and support our Outreach Programs like the upcoming "Brown Bag Workshop & Talk"

    Black Buddha-Ch. 1 at City Park's Summer Stages

 

How do you contact us?

Glad you asked! You can contact us directly at info@ViewsicEx.org. We check it. We will get back to you. We promise!

Other ways to help...

Spread the word! Tell everyone you know about BLACK BUDDHA!  Like us on facebook www.facebook.com/pages/GB-VED, blow up Twitter with BLACK BUDDHA, blog it, or promote it any way you can think of. Everything helps! To make it Simple use the Indiegogo share tools!

For those "Technophobes", you can support by simply attending our Show!  

Tickets:

General Admission: $22.00 adult, $16.50 student w/ID, $18.00 seniors (62 & over)

Pre-sale ticket $18 until September 3

To purchase tickets in advance Call: 1-718-488-1624

or go to:  www.kumbletheater.org, buy-tickets

Dancers:

Miguel Anaya, Germaul Barnes, Dozje Brown, Jazmine Dugall, Addison Ector, Leslie Kilpatrick, Igor Konyukhov, Juliana Luna, Renee Settle, Nejla Yatkin 

Scenic Designer: Harry Feiner 

Lighting Designer: Holly Ko

Documentary Video & Projections: Whitney V. Hunter  

For more information about the production of Black Buddha & Germaul Barnes' Viewsic Expressions Dance visit our Website: www.ViewsicEx.org

Thank You!

story:
COBA Collective Of Black Artists is celebrating 20 years of traditionally innovative dance with gala performaces entitled;

“Evoque – Passions deep within”

 4 performances of scintillating choreography by some of Canada’s best featuring the rhythmically riveting “Doun Doun Dance” by Guest choreographer Sis Robin Hibbert

April 11 – 13 2013

What is COBA?

Founded in 1993, COBA (Collective Of Black Artists) is the only professional performance company in Canada dedicated to the preservation of the cultural traditions of Africa and the African Diaspora.

The company presents traditional West African dance, music and folklore; Caribbean indigenous dance, music and rituals; and contemporary works that innovate on African movement aesthetics and express modern social themes.

Rooted in African and Caribbean traditions, COBA’s highly-spirited repertoire illuminates the beauty and spirituality of African and Caribbean dance, and has an inherent universal appeal. Storytelling, music and drama are interwoven with dance in order to share life wisdom with audiences and future generations.

COBA is a fore-runner in dance education. The Collective offers dance classes, lecture demonstrations, workshop seminars, and professional training opportunities, specializing in African and the African Diaspora dance culture and music.

As one of the few pure voices in African and African Diasporic dance culture, COBA has been preserving and innovating on Africanist movement aesthetics for twenty years. COBA also has the notable distinction of being the only company in Canada with the specialized training method - A-Feeree - developed in the 21st century.

What We Need & What You Get

COBA Collective Of Black Artists is funded by three levels of government, however the funding awards barely meets the day to day operations of the organization, and therefore all major artistic programming is often subsidized by fundraising. “Evoque – Passions deep within” is one such program, which is our major 20th anniversary celebration. Hence the theme “Twenties 4 Twentieth”

It costs roughly $127 000.00 to get a production to the stage.

Your contributions will support...

Performance

Artistic                                                         $ 13 000.00

Production                                                    $ 13 300.00

Costumes & Props                                        $  2 000.00

Marketing and Promotion                               $  6 700.00

                                  Total          $35 000.00

And you will receive;

Tax deductible reciept ($20+) (Canadian Donors only)

T-Shirt

Eco Water Bottle

Dance/Drum Classes

Signed Poster from Evoque

Special invite to open rehearsals to preview new creations

Tickets to performances

Pre-Show backstage tour and photo with cast

Special invite to 20th Anniversary Gala Event

 

The Impact

COBA Collective Of Black Artists is one of Canada’s leading professional dance companies and a forerunner in “black” dance.  Critically acclaimed as a “company that makes you sit up and take notice for all the right reasons”.  COBA’s mission is to educate and entertain audiences through public performance and workshops and have successfully achieved this goal for 20 years.

COBA has:

  • Produced 20 home seasons Concerts at notable venues mainly the Fleck Dance Theatre (formerly Premiere Dance Theatre)
  • 350 performances throughout Canada,
  • Toured Canada, UK, United States and the Caribbean
  • Developed and implemented educational programs for Toronto, Peel, Durham, and Thames Valley District School Boards

Other Ways You Can Help

So you do not have the financial means to support right now…hmmmmm…don’t despair you can still help.

 

  1. Refer friends and family to this campaign
  2. Visit us at our www.cobainc.com, facebook, twitter.
  3. Tell people about us.
  4. Become a board member
  5. Volunteer
