story:
The Project:

Beneath all the plotting, the spying, the machinations in the court, while Hamlet is pretending to be mad to get closer to what he wants, a very real tragedy is slowly unfolding right before everyone's eyes, and no one notices. Until it's too late.

Ophelia's story is the key to Hamlet's. Her actions are a direct and stark antithesis to his.

Enter Ophelia, distracted will combine the striking intensity of actor Kimberly Gilbert with the refined and investigative choreography of Erin Mitchell, immersed in a sea of music and sound to expose the inner and outer workings of Ophelia's self. 

Enter Ophelia, distracted will premiere June 20 & 21; 27 & 28 at the Capitol Hill Arts Workshop in Washington, DC.

A non-profit performing arts organization in Washington, DC, Taffety Punk exists to sustain a collection of performing artists who make theatre exciting, meaningful and affordable. We do think of ourselves as a band. A theatre band, if you will, in which acting, dance, and music are intricately linked. Greater resources, professional and artistic development for artists, and the impact we have on our community and audiences are top priorities for us as an organization of artists. With this focus omnipresent in our work, our productions are more relevant, vivid, and meaningful for audiences and artists alike. 

How you can help:

We are highly skilled actors, dancers, and musicians who are passionate and excited about sharing our craft with others. For company member Kimberly Gilbert, this project expresses a long-time love affair and fascination with the character of Ophelia. For company choreographer Erin Mitchell, it is a chance to continue fortifying the foundation of movement and dance for the Taffety Punks. 

But we need your help! This piece is presented as part of the Taffety Punk Generator which provides workshop opportunities for company members to explore their artistic visions. The Generator is a new program for us and is receiving some amazing feedback. While it isn't self-sufficient quite yet, we hope to soon have separate programming expenses set aside for these works. So this is where you come in...

As performing artists there are basic materials needed in order to create and sustain ourselves as artists. To make the best art, we believe in compensation for our artists' time and talent, as well as access to the resources needed to make great art (like space to dance and killer promotional materials). 

This is what your contributions will help us achieve:

  • Compensation for 4 performers, and choreographer during 10 weeks of rehearsal to create and design Enter Ophelia, distracted.
  • Commission of an original score of music, and hopefully live performance of the commissioned work. Creating and performing an original score takes time and money.
  • Compensation for a lighting designer. They can get pricey!
  • Marketing and promotion for the show. Our poster artist is tops, and we like to pay him for his creations. Plus, print jobs take some dough.
  • Theater rental and other basic production costs. 


What you get in return (the good stuff):

We've broken it down to make it easy.

$20- $49: a shout-out in the program

$50- $99: a shout-out in the program + poster from the show

$100- $399: postcard set (designs from previous Taffety Punk posters) + above

$400- $799:  2 comp tickets to Ophelia + Taffety Punk 7 inch record (includes a download code) + above

$800- $1999: 2 comp tickets to Ophelia +  a Taffety Punk t-shirt + above

$2,000- $6,000: 2 comp tickets to Ophelia, 2 tix to Bootleg Shakespeare (July 14th at the Folger Theatre), a shout-out in the program, PLUS EITHER drinks on us OR all the swag above (postcards, 7 inch, t-shirt, poster).

$6,500: 2 comp tickets Ophelia + to every show we do through Bootleg 2015! Plus drinks on us.

Please help us to make this show happen! Share with your friends, plaster it on social media, and use those little icons to spread the word. 

We are so excited to share new works with our audiences. It is a major part of the mission of the Taffety Punks, especially creative endeavors that are as meaningful as this. 

We look forward to your thoughts on the work and will be offering talk-backs or Q&As after certain Enter Ophelia, distracted performances. A dialogue about our work is important to the growth our our company, the nourishment of the performing arts, and in developing relationships with you, our audience and friends. Stay in the loop by liking us on Facebook or following us on Twitter. 

The best part about an Indiegogo campaign is that every little bit counts; if we don't make our goal we still receive what you have donated. For that, we are truly, truly grateful. Something means more than nothing at all. We will make it work!

Thank you so very much! We'll see you at the show!

story:
Who We Are

Simcoe Contemporary Dancers is a dance company by and for the region of Simcoe County.  We work to encourage and showcase the development of local, professional contemporary dance.  We come together to raise the visibility of contemporary dance, create awareness of the art form, build educational opportunities and reach our to our public, sharing our love of dance.  This is our fifth anniversary year!


We tell wild, hilarious, stark, luscious, whimsical, curious stories, gorgeously and courageously, through dance.

We want to grow and show them here, where we live.

We want to continue to make the space and time for local dance artists to work together to grow stronger, wiser and more capable.

We invite people in as audience members and as class or workshop participants, sharing our artwork, which tells the universal story of being human - of trials and triumphs both big and small.  We help people express and recognize their deep stories, the ones beyond words. 


What We Need and What You Get

We had over 2000 audience members in 2013 alone (wheee!) and, as a relatively new company and the only professional contemporary dance initiative in the region, we are still making ourselves known.  2000 is great but there are almost 500,000 people in Simcoe County and your donations will help us to do things like:

  • Develop and distribute promotional material that will help people to connect with our classes and workshop opportunities
  • Support local choreographers and dancers in the development, rehearsal and production of new work
  • Rent studio space
  • Invest in a quality, portable PA system for site-specific work
  • Admin costs – the least glamourous bit - but oh, so integral! Recording, archiving, keeping all of the paperwork in order for contracts, classes, workshops, events, arts grant applications and general marketing is a necessity that takes time and money.
We have many super fun perks for donating - please check them out on the left and learn a little more about our fabulous supporters and perks donors below.

Your Impact

Your donations will help us to grow local contemporary dance.  We are sure that the arts enrich our quality of life and make our communities better places to live so we have worked tirelessly for the past five years to engage with our local community, providing opportunities to create, perform, enjoy, explore and experience contemporary dance.

We have done over 100 performances –  most of them free and family friendly, almost all at regional venues and festivals.  This is an extraordinary feat for so new a company!  We have offered over 400 classes and over 100 education and outreach activities, such as the Adopt-a-Class program, My Moves youth workshops and guest choreography in area schools.  We have created 15 new dance works by local artists and taken on 6 awesome youth apprentices,  providing them training and choreographic opportunities. We frequently work in partnership with area galleries, such as the MacLaren Art Centre and the DIY Collective and often collaborate with local artists, musicians and dance artists. We have hosted guest workshops which brought internationally recognized dance artists to the area, including many who had their start here in Barrie such as Mairead Filgate and Robert Kingsbury.

We can't even begin to express the respect and admiration we have for the dancers, artists, musicians, audience members and students we have been lucky enough to connect with in our first five years. They surprise, delight and challenge us. 

We love, love, love what do and want to keep growing and going.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a donation, there are other ways you can support us:

  • Tell your friends. Share this campaign using the share tools below.
  • Come see us.  Watch a show.  Try out a class.  Find us here: simcoecontemporarydancers.com
  • Volunteer or make an in-kind donation.

Good People - Perks Donors

the Morals:  Thank you to the Morals for graciously giving us permission to use their song "Douglas Snow" in our campaign video.  Half way between Canada’s biggest city and beautiful cottage country, this Barrie, Ontario band has utilized their unique surroundings to create a style of ambient indie folk that combines the peacefulness of the latter with the tension of the former. You can find more of their very fine music here: themorals.ca

Susan Kendal is the artistic director and designer behind Pocket Alchemy. As a textile artist she makes comforting quilts, burp cloths and toy/soother straps and felt toys – including her popular felt matryoshka dolls. Susan trained as contemporary dancer and costume designer in Edmonton and Toronto. She still choreographs, teaches and costumes as Pocket Alchemy and is based in Central Ontario. Her work has been performed and worn at venues and festivals across Canada. pocketalchemy.ca

The sweetness of Susan's tiny matryoshka brooches cannot be denied.  Yours will have a daisy tummy.

Ulana Romanish Our newest company member is a woman of many talents, one of which is creating intricately decorated eggs, known as Pysanka, using traditional Ukrainian wax relief and dip dye methods. 

An example of one of Ulana's eggs.  Gorgeousness.

Williams Farm is owned and run by the fabulous John and Suzanne Williams and family. They produce Maple Syrup from 55 acres of maple bush located on the farm located just south of the Wye Marsh in the hills of Tay Township. In the summer they grow up to 10 acres of Certified Organic Vegetables.  They try to leave our environment enriched by their farming activities.  No pesticides or chemical fertilizers are used on their land. This provides a safer, more nutritious product and they have an abundance of insect and animal life on the farm.  For info on the farm store, farm tours and farmer’s market dates and locations, visit their website:  williamsfarm.ca
story_txt:
Who We Are
Simcoe Contemporary Dancers is a dance company by and
for the region of Simcoe
 County.  We work to encourage and showcase the development of local, professional contemporary dance.  We come together to raise the visibility of contemporary dance, create 
awareness of the art form, build educational opportunities and reach our
 to our public, sharing our love of dance.  This is our fifth 
anniversary year!  We tell wild,
hilarious, stark, luscious, whimsical, curious stories, gorgeously and
courageously, through dance.We want to grow and show them
here, where we live. 
We want to continue to make the space and
time for local dance artists to work together to grow stronger, wiser and more
capable.
We invite people in as audience members and as class or workshop participants, sharing our artwork, which tells the universal story of being human - of trials and triumphs both big and small.  We help people express and recognize their deep stories, the ones beyond words. What We Need and What You Get

We had over 2000 audience members in 2013 alone (wheee!) and, as a relatively new company and the only professional contemporary dance initiative in the region, we are still making ourselves known.  2000 is great but there are almost 500,000 people in Simcoe County and your donations will help us to do things like:

Develop and distribute promotional material that
     will help people to connect with our classes and workshop opportunities
Support local choreographers and dancers in the
     development, rehearsal and production of new work
Rent studio space 
Invest in a quality, portable PA system for
     site-specific work
Admin costs – the least glamourous bit - but oh, so integral! Recording, archiving, keeping all of
     the paperwork in order for contracts, classes, workshops, events, arts grant applications and general marketing is a necessity
     that takes time and money.

We
have many super fun perks for donating - please check them out on the left and learn a little more about our fabulous supporters and perks donors below.Your Impact
Your donations will help us
to grow local contemporary dance.  We are sure that the arts enrich our quality
of life and make our communities better places to live so we have worked tirelessly
for the past five years to engage with our local community, providing opportunities
to create, perform, enjoy, explore and experience contemporary dance.We have done over 100 performances –  most of them free and family
     friendly, almost all at regional
     venues and festivals.  This is an extraordinary feat for so new a company!  We have offered over 400 classes and over 100 education and outreach activities, such as the Adopt-a-Class program, My Moves youth workshops and guest choreography in area schools.  We have created 15 new dance works by local artists and taken on 6 awesome youth apprentices,  providing them training
     and choreographic opportunities. We frequently work in partnership with area galleries, such as the MacLaren Art Centre and the DIY Collective and often collaborate with local artists, musicians and dance artists. We have hosted guest workshops which brought
     internationally recognized dance artists to the area, including many who
     had their start here in Barrie such as Mairead Filgate and Robert Kingsbury. We can't even begin to express the respect and admiration we have for the dancers, artists, musicians, audience members and students we have been lucky enough to connect with in our first five years. They surprise, delight and challenge us.  We love, love, love what do and want to keep growing and going.Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a
donation, there are other ways you can support us:

Tell your friends. Share this campaign using the share tools below.
Come see us. 
     Watch a show.  Try out a
     class.  Find us here: simcoecontemporarydancers.com

Volunteer or make an in-kind donation.
Good People - Perks Donors

the Morals:  Thank you to the Morals for graciously giving us permission to use their song "Douglas Snow" in our campaign video.  Half way between Canada’s biggest city and beautiful cottage country, this Barrie, Ontario band has utilized their unique surroundings to create a style of 
ambient indie folk that combines the peacefulness of the latter with the
 tension of the former. You can find more of their very fine music here: themorals.ca
Susan Kendal is the artistic
director and designer behind Pocket Alchemy. As a textile artist she makes
comforting quilts, burp cloths and toy/soother straps and felt toys – including her popular felt
matryoshka dolls. Susan trained as contemporary dancer and costume
designer in Edmonton and Toronto. She still choreographs, teaches and
costumes as Pocket Alchemy and is based in Central Ontario.
Her work has been performed and worn at venues and festivals across Canada.
pocketalchemy.ca The sweetness of Susan's tiny matryoshka brooches cannot be denied.  Yours will have a daisy tummy.Ulana Romanish Our newest company member is a woman of many talents, one of which is creating intricately decorated eggs, known as Pysanka, using traditional
Ukrainian wax relief and dip dye methods.  An example of one of Ulana's eggs.  Gorgeousness.
Williams Farm is owned and run by
the fabulous John and Suzanne Williams and family. They produce Maple Syrup
from 55 acres of maple bush located on the farm located just south of the Wye
Marsh in the hills of Tay
 Township. In the summer
they grow up to 10 acres of Certified Organic Vegetables.  They try to leave our environment enriched by
their farming activities.  No pesticides
or chemical fertilizers are used on their land. This provides a safer,
more nutritious product and they have an abundance of insect and animal life on
the farm.  For info on the farm store, farm tours and
farmer’s market dates and locations, visit their website:  williamsfarm.ca

story:
Our Story

Halifax filmmaker and theater producer Thom Fitzgerald, with Gloria Bonelli, presents Carlo Alban's self-written autobiographical one-man-show INTRINGULIS at the 21st Annual Atlantic Fringe Festival in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

INTRINGULIS is an evocative tale of one man's outsider journey and his discovery of belonging and identity which is made universal in its telling. Alban portrays a number of immigrant characters of various ages and weaves in the folk songs - sung in his native tongue - which were the soundtrack of his childhood household.

The storytelling is poetic yet clear; unvarnished but beautiful; transparent yet layered; and completely compelling and entertaining.

The Impact

Developed by LAByrinth Theater Company over the past five years INTRINGULIS has had workshops and readings including at the Public Theater in NYC. It premiered in a LAByrinth production at the Elephant Theater in Los Angeles, and made its southeastern debut at Southern Rep in New Orleans.

Now, INTRINGULIS has been invited as the New York representative and the opening production of the Atlantic Fringe Festival. With your support Alban will polish his script before going into rehearsal with director David Anzuelo for the highly charged five performance run in Halifax September 1 - 5, 2011, in anticipation of a New York City debut immediately following the festival. 


What We Need & What You Get

Your financial support will help fund the following: rehearsal time prior to the festival, air fare and ground transportation to/from Halifax for Carlo and one other member of the production team, fees for projections and sound designers, the shipping of musical instruments and props, the building (in Halifax) of a key set piece. In essence, as a contributor you will personally play a role in developing this theater piece to its ultimate version.


Other Ways You Can Help

We ask you to share this information and our campaign widely with your various friends and networks by all methods including e-mail, Facebook, Twitter, etc. Please help us raise the funds so that we can adequately and completely bring this story to the Atlantic Fringe Festival and prepare the script for a highly anticipated New York production.

story:
.....to give beyond reason, to care beyond hope, to live without limit, to reach, stretch and dream, in spite of all fears, these are the hallmarks of divinity.........the shadow of a life lived as an initiation, a sacred way.

Kristina Colovic (concept/visuals) in collaboration with Sara Galassini (concept/solo performer), Adonis Volanakis (scholar/director), Fa Ventilato (sound artist) and Matsuo Makoto (set design/visuals) will present the Sacred Way’s first work in progress for the stage. Ms.Colovic recently completed her thesis on the current refugee crisis on the EU borders and joined forces with a creative team to explore the journey from life to death to find life again. 

The Sacred Way is an interdisciplinary collaborative project that begins with the vision of a better and more just world for everyone. It reexamines the commonly adapted exploitation of defense and security. Meaning to forward the message that not all acts of defense and security need weapons or aggression for real solutions. The Scared Way's goal is to challenge the preconceived ideas of equality and interpretations of security that claim to be defending people’s human rights and basic needs to survive.

The first phase of the project focuses on the loss of life at sea for thousands of migrants fleeing for survival and the hope of a better life. It explores the cycle of life and death and investigates the ancient Myth of Persephone and Demeter and the Eleusinian Mysteries as a way to approach the passage of the human soul in its journey from light-to-darkness to find light again. The goal of the first development phase of the Sacred Way is to create a theatrical platform that celebrates the death of the many victims and in its future stage it aims to start an on site-collaboration with the refugees and marginalized groups themselves so that they can become the advocates of the cause. The UNHCR, which stands as the official UN refugee agency, has published its 2012 review of the global trends, which shows that we are facing today a global humanitarian crises. The official report claims 7.6 million people were newly displaced due to conflict or persecution, including 1.1 million new refugees and over the year an average of 23,000 persons per day left their homes to seek protection elsewhere (either within their borders of the their country or in other countries). At the close of 2012, 45.2 million people were forcibly displaced worldwide as a result of persecution, conflict, generalized violence and human rights violations, of which 15.4 million were refugees.

We hope that the impact of the Sacred Way will further awareness and guide the project into a larger scale work that will propose solutions to the issues of security, defense and the human rights of refugees and marginalized people.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for 1,500 USD to cover the expenses of the first work in progress, this includes rehearsals fees and the cost of our team working on the production. Any monies raised will be an enormous contribution to our collaborative vision and the first stage of development. We can offer in return printed still works from the original visual imagery created for The Sacred Way.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Victoria Gregg, I am an eight grader in Key West.  I currently attend ballet classes at the CoffeeMill Dance Studio.  My focus is ballet; I am an advanced dancer and round out my dance art training with both Modern and Contemporary dance classes.  I have been dancing since I was five years old.  My first professional dance production was as a Party Child in the Nutcracker Key West, produced by Joyce Stahl.

"        ""        "

In 2013, I was Alice, in the CoffeeMill Dance Studio production of "Alice and Wonderland".

This campaign will allow me to raise the funds I need to attend the summer intensive session at Joffrey Ballet School in NYC. I dream of being a professional dancer. I work toward this dream by dancing approximately 15 hours per week by attending classes and rehearsing for performances at local events and outreach programs.  Since I am a Scholarship Student, I am aware my classes are gifts. Without the generosity of the CoffeeMill, I would not have had the training, skills or opportunity to audition for Joffrey Ballet School. The great honor of being accepted into the NYC program is more than me or my parents expected.

In order to be competitive in the world of professional dance, professional training must be acquired. Local dance classes will not be enough to get me where I need to go.   Joffrey Ballet School has that training and atmosphere combined with a facility where greatness is achieved. I will be with dancers with like goals and skills, which will allow further growth and development.

What We Need & What You Get

The summer intensive cost is approximately $1500 per week.  I have enrolled for a two week session, $3000.  This price includes Tuition, housing, fees and food. School uniforms and transportation are extra. I am hoping to raise $4000. This amount should cover all costs including transportation, uniforms, chaperon fees and meals while traveling. cost:

 The two week session cost:

  • $1,199.00 Tuition
  • $998.00 Housing Fee for two weeks
  • $125.00 Resident Fee
  • $75.00 Performance Fee
  • $450.00 Meal Plan
  • Uniform price has not been published.  However, leotards are approximately $35.00 each uniform shirts and shorts are required for other classes and are estimated at approximately $25-35 per item.  Estimated need 5 of each, I don't know when I will have time to do laundry.
Ballet and Pointe shoes will also be needed. I have ballet shoes but I am guessing I will need two pair of pointe shoes.  I wear Russian Pointe shoes, the cost per pair is about $90-$100 per pair.

What am I doing to help with this goal? 

I have secured and performed at a St. Patrick's Day Celebration,

I am raising money by contacting local businesses for donations, I have several bake sales planned with my family's help and we will be having a yard sale.  Additional performances are also a goal, they are my favorite and the St. Patrick's Day performances went well.

If I exceed my goal, I will be adding week(s) on to my current registration at Joffrey Ballet School.  The intensive is a seven week program and I would like to stay 5 or 6 weeks. But, I have to raise the money, my parents won't consider the additional weeks on their own because that would be about $8000.00. My Mom, two Brothers, Dad and Stepmom would be pretty upset if I spent that much family money on myself.

If I don't reach my goal, the money will be used for next year's ballet intensive and a my current scholarship program. 

All donations will be applied to my dance education.

The Impact

My dance teachers and all of the professionals I have danced for have told my parents that I am talented. This is what I love and where I excel.  My parents have been as supportive as financially possible but I need your help to continue toward my dream. 

Other Ways You Can Help

No donation is too small.  Every dollar is important.  If you can help me on my journey, I thank you from the bottom of my heart. If you cannot donate, please take the time to share my link and story with your friends and family.

story:
The Friendship(s):
 
Stephanie Zaletel and Jordan Saenz met 5 years ago at California Institute of the Arts.  They immediately felt connected by a similar spirit, sensitivity, and edge.  Their passion for music and movement led to numerous successful artistic collaborations.  Stephanie and Jordan have danced together, lived together, traveled together, but never set a show together.  This performance will be their first choreographic collaborative effort since graduating.
 
"Sto Jo Show" features collaborative efforts by:
Stephanie Zaletel
Jordan Saenz
Lindsey Lollie
Chelsea Yarnell
Celeste Cancel
Michelle Sagarminaga
Louis Lopez
Michael Lockwood
Daniel Eaton
Evan White
Cooper Wolken
Andrew Munie
Steven Van Betten
 
 
The Sho:
 
"Sto Jo Sho" will be a series of four pieces (two from each choreographer) melding worlds of live/recorded music, room/audience manipulation, articulate physicality, and thematic references to trauma to explore a deeper sense of friendship, and growth. 
 
February 16, 2013
Pieter Performance Space
8:30pm
 
The Budget:
 
Renting Pieter Performance Space: $200
Lighting Operation/Equipment: $300
Rehearsal Space (2 choreographers/2months): $600
3 Live Musicians (original compositions): $400
5 Dancers (2 months for rehearsing): $700
Transportation/Per Diem: $300
 
The budget for this project is $2500.
 
Professional-level performance art is essential in every community.  It encourages creative thinking and imagination. We believe that it also plays an important role in mental health and happiness.  Compensating artists (especially young emerging ones) validates their effort and creates worth beyond the intrinsic value of the art itself.
 
Your support is greatly appreciated!
 
 
The Why:
 
Humans share the same anatomy, yet each of us experiences the world differently.  This is especially evident in the arts.  Exposing an audience to creativity through music and dance allows for a non-verbal exchange of information.  Ideas, emotions, and memories are intangible entities that can be communicated through live art.  From a common experience (the performance) different interpretations may emerge for the performers and the audience.  However, mutual participation in the event creates a connection.  It reminds us that we are all relatable, complex, and beautiful.
 
WITH YOUR HELP, WE CAN MAKE ART HAPPEN!
 
 
Love and Thanks,
Steph and Jo

story:
WHAT

"However long it takes to reach each other's shores."

-Karl Jensen, All This We're Each Forced Into; Private Painful Insight

YEAR OF THE SNAKE is a work conceived by three bay area artists: composer Jason Hoopes, choreographer Peiling Kao, and writer/visual artist Karl Jensen. The three elements that make up Year Of The Snake include the choreography, a physical record of the music (available November 15th), and a book compiled of writing and imagery composed specifically for this work (also available November 15th).

Year Of The Snake is a metaphor for “cycles of self-transformation”. In an age of hyper-competition and dependent convenience, we lose sight of the personal process and power of self-transformation, and what it takes to enter the process. What it takes to enter the process has much to do with Empathy.

Empathy is a practice. We have to do it for it to be. This requires vulnerability, which requires strength, through courage. These things are in turn built upon positive learning experiences, even as we accept that learning includes an element of trauma; transformation is traumatic. 

Self-transformation concerns the application of the Will upon processes which are already in motion, and always have been. We die. Birth, death - same door. Knowing this, what do we see? Knowing this, what do we want? And what are we doing about it? We have a chance to participate in the shaping, the form, of our own transformation. But it is something we each experience alone or not at all. Such solitude is traumatic. Empathy is the Will acting to harness the inward power of Solitude and send it outward, opening toward, defining space, leaving useful room, useful because empty. Sometimes we practice Empathy in front of a mirror; be gentle with yourself as you shed skin.

We are reaching out to you, and you may choose to reach back in many forms, all valuable. To financially support this project is not only to help pay theater fees, promotion costs, CD and book duplication costs, and travel, but also (and most important) fees for three professional dance artists and twelve musicians. 

As personal perspective changes, the traumatic shedding of old skin, and the acceptance of new forms of understanding, provide useful lessons for compassionately ushering in needed societal progress. You never have a finite number of chances to become, and your becoming helps others do the same. You're not invited. You're inside. It is not as important to get the message as it is to send it. You are invited. This is the spirit of this work.

Thank you for listening. 

WHO

Jason Hoopes is a bassist, composer, and teacher living in Oakland, CA. His work as bassist with several progressive bay area bands includes Jack O' The Clock, Fred Frith Trio, Eat The Sun, Dominique Leone, The Atomic Bomb Audition, powerdove, and Satya Sena among others. Jason has composed music for modern choreographers Molissa Fenley, Alyce Finwall, Sophia Leiby, and others as well as Peiling Kao, with whom he's performed since 2009. His work for dance has been performed both nationally and internationally. He holds a MA in composition, and MFA in Performance & Literature, from Mills College.

Peiling Kao was born in Taipei, Taiwan, and has been a freelance dancer for 16 years. After graduating from Taipei National University of the Arts in 1996 with a BFA in Dance, Peiling worked as a full-time teacher at Cloud Gate Dance School in Taiwan. She has studied technique training in ballet, contemporary, various forms of modern dance, Chinese Traditional Dance, Chinese Martial Art, Tai- chi, improvisation, and contact improvisation.

In 2007, Peiling was awarded the Taiwan-England artists’ residency, hosted by the Independent Dance based at Siobhan Davis Studios in London;in 2010,Peiling finished her MFA in Choreography and Performance at Mills College, receiving an E.L Wiegand Foundation Award for excellence in performance and choreography.  In 2012, she awarded Isadora Duncan Dance Awards in category of Outstanding Achievement in Performance for the collaborative work entitled Terra Incognita: Revisited.  Peiling was also awarded an Artist in Residency (AIR) at Shawl-Anderson Dance Center in the Fall 2012.  

Since moving to the US, Peiling has taught dance at Mills College, Austin Peay State University, and Chinese American International School as a visiting artist. Peiling’s work has been presented at Austin Peay State University, The Garage and the Luggage Store Gallery in SF, and Temescal Art Center and Mills College in Oakland.

Peiling currently dances with Molissa Fenley and Company, Shinichi Iova-Koga’s InkBoat, and Katie Faulkner’s Little Seismic Dance Company. Among the artists/dance professionals that she worked with are: Mary Anthony, Susan Rethorst, Brenda Way, Sonya Delwaide, Sean Curran, Ross Parkes, Hwai-Min Lin (Founder of Cloud Gate Dance Theater), Men-Fei Lo, Min-Shen Ku, Susan Van Pelt, Anne Bluethenthal, Nancy Lyons, Nina Haft, Christy Funsch, and Alyce Finwall. 

Karl Jensen is an Oakland based writer and visual artist, and is the founder of Vasculiterra Books. His stories have been published in numerous national literary journals and magazines, and he has dropped out of just as many colleges across that same, broad nation. He has held the distinct honors of work as a grave digger, ditch digger, security guard, assembly line laborer, house painter, librarian, land title examiner, and in construction, in demolition, for banks on Wall Street, for bars in Arkansas, as a movie extra in India and as an English teacher in Bangladesh. His writing and aesthetic are informed by and are a result of these and other such rewarding and prestigious careers. He currently works in San Francisco with at-risk youth, and is interested in the possibilities at the intersections of Public Health and Literature, Social Change and Art, Dance and Urban Community.

DETAIL + THANKS

The goal we've set for this public funding campaign comes with a list of spending priorities. 

The first thing we want to be sure we can do is pay the artists who helped us bring this work to life. We enlisted the aid of fifteen trained and professional local artists. They've all been so generous. Contributions will be proritized toward paying these people.

After artist fees, the next significant expense is the rental fee for the venue. Monies from ticket sales will also go toward this cost. Due to limited seating for thus far only a 3-day run, ticket sales alone will not cover our expenses. This is why the goal we've set here is just below the actual cost to us; it is intended to buffer income from tickets. To offer a modest thank you, the pieces of work outlined in the next financial priority are available as "perks" in this campaign.

The next financial priorities are the production costs for the musical record, the book of original text, and imagery. Year Of The Snake presents three pieces of work composed around the same theme(s). In addition to Peiling's choreographed performance, Jason has produced a physical and digital record of his hour-length score, intended to be available as a stand alone work. The seeds of this work are really found in Karl's writing, and he has produced a book of original writing and imagery composed specifically in tandem with Peiling's and Jason's visions. For perspective, the cost of music production alone will reach $2000.

Please note: The "perks" are set up in a range relationship. For instance, donate between $10 and $49 and receive the first "perk", donate between $50 and $75 and receive the second, etc.

You may also choose to decline "perks" and to donate anonymously. You may donate any amount you wish.

Please email us at yearofthesnakeoakland@gmail.com to leave a web link with us to promote on our website along with your name, in thanks. (We do reserve the right to use discretion when approving web links). 

Thank you for listening. 

IMPACT

There are so many artists all around the world making such important work. Why support this project? That's only answerable by you. We all invest energy in many forms where ever we feel it will be best used. 

To invest in our work is to invest in sincere and sober efforts to engage Empathy as a practice. This is something present in all three of our work trajectories; to strip away cleverness and entertainment, and touch what is pulsing just beneath the surface, what we all share. Think of an enemy - yes, them too. 

Many technological forces we've created in the world isolate and dislocate us from each other, through the guise of convenient access. Empathy is one of the early casualties. We want to invest in its practice and value. We're all here. Cycle. Self-transformation. You have power. You are not alone in your aloneness. Neither am I in mine. 

Thank you for listening.

SUPPORT IN MANY FORMS

If you are unable to contribute financially, you may choose to help us spread the word. Please feel free to use the Indiegogo "share" features and tell your friends and family about the project. We must transform alone, but no one expresses work like this alone. 

As you share this project funding campaign with loved ones, please tell them also that they are seen and accepted.

Thank you for listening. 

Jason, Peiling, Karl
story_txt:
WHAT
"However long it takes to reach each other's shores."
-Karl Jensen, All This We're Each Forced Into; Private Painful Insight
YEAR OF THE SNAKE is a work conceived by three bay area artists: composer Jason Hoopes, choreographer Peiling Kao, and writer/visual artist Karl Jensen. The three elements that make up Year Of The Snake include the choreography, a physical record of the music (available November 15th), and a book compiled of writing and imagery composed specifically for this work (also available November 15th).
Year Of The Snake is a metaphor for “cycles of self-transformation”. In an age of hyper-competition and dependent convenience, we lose sight of the personal process and power of self-transformation, and what it takes to enter the process. What it takes to enter the process has much to do with Empathy.
Empathy is a practice. We have to do it for it to be. This requires vulnerability, which requires strength, through courage. These things are in turn built upon positive learning experiences, even as we accept that learning includes an element of trauma; transformation is traumatic. 
Self-transformation concerns the application of the Will upon processes which are already in motion, and always have been. We die. Birth, death - same door. Knowing this, what do we see? Knowing this, what do we want? And what are we doing about it? We have a chance to participate in the shaping, the form, of our own transformation. But it is something we each experience alone or not at all. Such solitude is traumatic. Empathy is the Will acting to harness the inward power of Solitude and send it outward, opening toward, defining space, leaving useful room, useful because empty. Sometimes we practice Empathy in front of a mirror; be gentle with yourself as you shed skin.
We are reaching out to you, and you may choose to reach back in many forms, all valuable. To financially support this project is not only to help pay theater fees, promotion costs, CD and book duplication costs, and travel, but also (and most important) fees for three professional dance artists and twelve musicians. 
As personal perspective changes, the traumatic shedding of old skin, and the acceptance of new forms of understanding, provide useful lessons for compassionately ushering in needed societal progress. You never have a finite number of chances to become, and your becoming helps others do the same. You're not invited. You're inside. It is not as important to get the message as it is to send it. You are invited. This is the spirit of this work.
Thank you for listening. 

WHO

Jason Hoopes is a bassist, composer, and teacher living in Oakland, CA. His work as bassist with several progressive bay area bands includes Jack O' The Clock, Fred Frith Trio, Eat The Sun, Dominique Leone, The Atomic Bomb Audition, powerdove, and Satya Sena among others. Jason has composed music for modern choreographers Molissa Fenley, Alyce Finwall, Sophia Leiby, and others as well as Peiling Kao, with whom he's performed since 2009. His work for dance has been performed both nationally and internationally. He holds a MA in composition, and MFA in Performance & Literature, from Mills College.

story:
A Tribal Il Trovatore! 

Virago Theatre Company brings another passionate opera featuring professional singers to the East Bay, performing just 4 performances of Verdi's masterpiece Il Trovatore at the majestic Elk's Ballroom in Alameda! 

Set in a tribal, medieval world, Visionary Director Ellen St. Thomas, Conductor Robert Ashens and celebrated Set Designer Jean-Francois Revon bring a striking new collaborative voice to Il Trovatore. 

Set Designer Jean-Francois Revon with an early look at the Il Trovatore set, a medieval world created first in a series of 3D designs by Revon. This will be followed by a month of building and detailed painting by Debra Cramer, supervised by Virago Resident Technical Director Gary Quinn. Projections will complete this stunning design. 

The superb leads, all opera singers working at professional venues in the Bay Area and beyond, include Virago Resident Musical Artist Eileen Meredith as Leonora, Alex Boyer as Manrico, Elizabeth Baker as Azucena, and Jo Vincent Parks as Count di Luna.


Elizabeth Baker as Azucena, Alex Boyer as Manrico, Eileen Meredith as Leonora and Jo Vincent Parks as Count di Luna, Virago's Il Trovatore

Virago's Il Trovatore will mesmerize audiences with its scorching tale of the vengeful gypsy Azucena, her son Manrico, his romance with the noblewoman Leonora, and his rivalry with the Conte di Luna.  Our stunning cast carries the opera from its spectacular opening, through the famous Anvil Chorus, to its jaw-dropping finale!


Our vision for this thrilling, innovative production is a full orchestra, filling the theater with Verdi's glorious score. We ask your help in securing these talented musicians. 
$5000 allows us to hire the musicians we need for our orchestra, please give today! 
We are a 501 c 3, all donations are tax deductible. For more information about Virago, please visit our website, www.viragotheatre.org


Elizabeth Baker as Azucena

www.viragotheatre.org

story:
Who We Are

The Eggmen are a newly established altruistic Street Theatre Company who work Nationally & are aiming to work internationally developing new pieces of work that aim to challenge perceptions of street art & the world we live in. The company directors have a strong track record of developing quality street acts for such companies as Hope St Ltd & the Hope Street Feast Festival, Conflux Scotland & the Surge festival as well Tate Liverpool, The Tall Ship festival.


What we are doing

The Eggmen are creating an inclusive street theatre project using various skilled & unskilled young people from different backgrounds within Liverpool. Our aim with this project is to inspire a new generation of street performers, whilst raising their social political knowledge & empowering them to have their own voice on current affairs. Additionally the presence of the performance will draw attention to Physical Fest 2014.

We will be teaching the groups we are working with the fundamentals of street theatre, it’s applications as performance & entertainment & also its historical uses as a form of sharing of knowledge & opinion. Using the theme of remonstration we will create three different street acts that will be developed by the groups & performed on the streets of Liverpool.


Why we need your help

We will be working with over 50 young people from 3 different groups & your contributions will go towards creating exciting & performance worthy props and costumes. Your contributions will guarantee that every member of our young company will be able to participate to their full artistic potential. The money will allow them to be creative without restriction and will also allow us to make a contribution towards the designers who are currently donating their time for free.  


Where the money goes

We are looking to raise £500 to supplement our initial budget. The money will contribute towards;

* The design and construction of props.

* The design and tailoring of costume for each member of the groups.

* Transport for the groups to the performance.

* Any rehearsal or research materials needed.

* Contributing towards the fee of the designers.

Please see right for all our fabulous perks!


The Impact

The money raised shall help inspire a new generation of performers that would otherwise not have the opportunity to perform in this medium. Your money will enhance the materials and design of the project and give the kids confidence in their product. This will lead to a better performance standard and confidence in themselves as practitioners. We have ran these types of projects before and we have found that having a decent budget for the materials improves the quality of the work. It gives them confidence in the the act but also the team surrounding them. It also gives them an experience to a professional standard which is good preparation for a future career in the arts. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everybody can contribute financially but that doesn't mean we love you any less. So, if you cannot give us your hard earned cash please share this link to people you may think can help. If you are local come down and support the groups on the performance days.

Thanks for taking the time to read our pledge, 

Stay tuned, videos to follow!


The Eggmen!!

story:
Our mission is to promote the growth of contemporary dance in the city of Tulsa through collaborative performances and educational opportunities for the community.

We were founded in 2008 with only two dancers, Founding Artistic Directors, Jennifer Alden and Valeria Cordero (Cordero has retired, succeeded by Michael J. Lopez). Now we have more than 20 dancers including a junior company made up of dancers ages 9-14. We have backgrounds in ballet, jazz, modern, contemporary, hip hop and aerial dance. In fact—we are the ONLY aerial dancers in North East Oklahoma! ["Swing" by for class sometime!] 

PDT loves to collaborate with local artists of various genres including stage combat, installation artists, video artists, actors and visual artists. We perform six-ten pieces annually, including full-length productions. We have recently enjoyed performing at 25 local elementary schools as part of the Arts & Humanities Council of Tulsa's Harweldon Institute program. We are a fairly unique dance company because we all have day jobs and then rehearse at night! We believe in burning both ends to produce amazing results! [really we just believe that this integration of the real world into the theatrical affords us a unique perspective which fuels our choreography with relatable stories and themes].

THIS CAMPAIGN! We are so excited to have the opportunity to tour our production of "Virus" in Ashland, Oregon! We have been invited by the "Ballet in the Park" series to perform this piece and work with local dancers. The performance will be at the Butler Band shell in Ashland’s acclaimed Lithia Park as part of the Revival of “Ballet in the Park.” It is important for us as performers to get experience outside of our comfort zone and see what different areas of the country can teach us. We believe that this enriches us and pushes us further in our dance. 

WITH YOUR HELP we can travel to Oregon and share this piece with locals there, and give our dancers touring experience. WITH YOUR HELP we can afford plane tickets! [You wouldn't want us to WALK all the way there now would you?] Once we get there, we've got a great package of performing and teaching—what more could we ask for? [plane tickets] We are so blessed for this opportunity and couldn't ask for anything more. [except plane tickets] So thank you for reading all of this and if you take just one thing away from your reading experience today [hitchhiking is dangerous] please let it be that the arts are important. [and plane tickets are too]

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $5,000 to fly our beautiful dancers to Oregon [and home again].

We will give you so much cool stuff! See Below!

If we do not reach our full goal, the amount we do raise will go to fly as many of our dancers as the cash allows. The rest will have to walk.

The Impact

We know it doesn't seem like much—but this trip is the INAUGURAL touring experience for us!  You can be one of the GROUND-BREAKING donors! We hope to tour more in the future and this will get us started.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are short on cash, we understand. [we are too!] So we simply ask that you contribute in another way. Please help promote this campaign to all of your richer friends and then guilt them into contributing. Guilt is really the strongest motivator. We also accept flight miles if you would like to donate those! Wine, luggage, cars, teapots, hair nets, peanut m&ms, etc. We're not picky. [plane tickets or cash is the best though]

story:
Almost 10 years on stage !

My dear friends and fans, 

In 2015, I will celebrate my 10th year of being a Burlesque Performer, under the name Miss Anne Thropy. I have seen many places, performed on prestigious stages and met wonderful people - and it all started with my passion for old hollywood glamour, feathers and showgirls, which fueled my desire to recreate beautiful burlesque shows, and make people dream.

This year, I have decided to travel as much as I can - because let's face it, I'm 30 now, and you never know what life could bring you, so I don't want to waste any more time before doing what I love the most.


Where's my Money Tree ?

As a passionate showgirl, I always tried to create the most beautiful shows and costumes - more feathers, more crystals, bigger dresses... And of course, this comes at a high price !

As I haven't found yet the miracle formula to turn stones into gold, I will NEED YOU, my friends and fans, who have been supporting me since the beginning, to help me raise funds to cover my travel costs.

I am lucky this year to have been selected to perform at some of the best Burlesque Festivals : 

- Munich Burlesque Festival

- London Burlesque Festival

- Boylesque Festival Vienna

- Perth Burlesque Festival

- Edinburgh Fringe Festival

All expenses combined (flights, hotels, and of course extra luggage) are over 3000€, so I decided to set a 2500€ goal, which would help me greatly.

 If you love me so, so much, and we exceed this goal, the rest of the money will be used for new costumes, and of course, more travels ! :)



Thank you for your love and support !

I would like to thank all the wonderful people who have been sharing my life in the past 10 years : family, friends, performer friends (some of you I can consider family, Loulou D'Vil, Lada Redstar, Lou on the Rock's, I love you !), burlesque producers, photographers, costume designers, corset makers, milliners, and all those people who helped me look fabulous.

Also, a big Thank You to all the people who came to see my shows, all those friendly faces in the crowd that I'm always happy to see - you make me a very lucky woman !

There are little things that you can always do to help me : 

- Come say "hi !" after the shows !

- Check my website www.missannethropy.com

- Join my Fan page on Facebook 

- Like my Profile on the London Burlesque Festival website and help me get additional press coverage !

- Spread my campaign and help me live my Dream ! <3


Keep DREAMING !


Love always !

Miss Anne Thropy
story_txt: Almost 10 years on stage !My dear friends and fans, In 2015, I will celebrate my 10th year of being a Burlesque Performer, under the name Miss Anne Thropy. I have seen many places, performed on prestigious stages and met wonderful people - and it all started with my passion for old hollywood glamour, feathers and showgirls, which fueled my desire to recreate beautiful burlesque shows, and make people dream.This year, I have decided to travel as much as I can - because let's face it, I'm 30 now, and you never know what life could bring you, so I don't want to waste any more time before doing what I love the most.Where's my Money Tree ?As a passionate showgirl, I always tried to create the most beautiful shows and costumes - more feathers, more crystals, bigger dresses... And of course, this comes at a high price !As I haven't found yet the miracle formula to turn stones into gold, I will NEED YOU, my friends and fans, who have been supporting me since the beginning, to help me raise funds to cover my travel costs.I am lucky this year to have been selected to perform at some of the best Burlesque Festivals : - Munich Burlesque Festival- London Burlesque Festival- Boylesque Festival Vienna- Perth Burlesque Festival- Edinburgh Fringe FestivalAll expenses combined (flights, hotels, and of course extra luggage) are over 3000€, so I decided to set a 2500€ goal, which would help me greatly. If you love me so, so much, and we exceed this goal, the rest of the money will be used for new costumes, and of course, more travels ! :)Thank you for your love and support !I would like to thank all the wonderful people who have been sharing my life in the past 10 years : family, friends, performer friends (some of you I can consider family, Loulou D'Vil, Lada Redstar, Lou on the Rock's, I love you !), burlesque producers, photographers, costume designers, corset makers, milliners, and all those people who helped me look fabulous.Also, a big Thank You to all the people who came to see my shows, all those friendly faces in the crowd that I'm always happy to see - you make me a very lucky woman !There are little things that you can always do to help me : - Come say "hi !" after the shows !- Check my website www.missannethropy.com- Join my Fan page on Facebook - Like my Profile on the London Burlesque Festival website and help me get additional press coverage !- Spread my campaign and help me live my Dream ! <3Keep DREAMING !Love always !Miss Anne Thropy

story:
Our Story

We are Perpetro Independent Color Guard, a competition color guard based out of Vallejo, CA. More importantly, we're a group of friends who have been spinning and teaching color guard together for years and it's always been a dream of ours to start an Independent Guard here in Vallejo. We were successful in 2012, our first year out and we're back this year! We had a rocky start with most of our original members not returning, but we didn't let that stop us. Now all we need is to raise the funds in order to keep creating our competition show and make it to Western Championships in San Diego and WGI FINALS in Dayton, Ohio. Yes, extremely ambitious, but we're really hungry to perform and we've been working hard to get to this point. We have a crazy talented set of spinners/ dancers from all over Northern California as well as a top notch, world class staff and we're all really excited to show you what we can do! 


Perpetro: To complete, accomplish, and perform.


The Impact

By getting the funding we need to continue, we wouldn't just be making many of our own dreams come true, we'd also be providing our home town and the many talented performers here in Northern California with another place to continue their passion for color guard, dance, and the performing arts after high school and for years to come.


What We Need & What You Get

We've listed our need for a MINIMUM of $600 so anything and everything will help! And if we exceed this goal, we will be even more grateful for your kindness and support. With the funds we raise, we'd be able to put it toward paying off insurance and competition fees, purchasing a performance floor (mat), poles and flags, uniforms, and plane tickets for our trip to WGI FINALS in Ohio. Please take a look at the sidebar for more information on donation amounts and their corresponding fun incentives for helping us out! :) And to make some of these incentives more affordable, we suggest splitting the cost with a group of friends!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please add us as a friend on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/perpetro.independent) so that you can stay up-to-date with our other fundraisers (if you're local) and with how our season is going! We'd also really appreciate it if you shared our campaign link on your social networking pages as well so that we can reach as many people as possible. Thank you so so sooooo much for your help!

story:
Our audiences are bored with the theater of reassurance, which shows the same old exhausted ideals.  We all like the ideals but we want a radical transformation of presentation. We want change! Catchy Name Theatre received 85 script-submissions for our project from the US, Canada and Mexico.  We have selected 

  • American Broskies by Chase Yenser 
  • Wild Geese by Ron Burch.  

Edward, Scott, Nate, Randy and Jim read Chase Yenser's American Broskis March 14th.  The play is fast-paced with committed characters on a collision course.  We sent Chase Yenser a video of the table-read and wish to continue development with a view to producing it in the Bay Area.  

Did you know that tickets sales cover only a fraction of the costs of producing a play? Join us in creating a new theater experience.  No donation is too small!

story:
My name is Lindsy Bissonnette, I am a double major in Acting/Directing Theatre, and Communications, and this fall I will be a senior. When my best friend and fellow Theatre major, Benjamin Hill asked me to help him put on the show The Last Days of Judas Iscariot, naturally I said YES! Currently I am the producer, an actor and designer for this show, and wearing this many hats for the production has been difficult when we lack a big part: Funding.

You may be wondering "who the heck are these kids"? And that is a perfectly appropriate question. We are a group of collegiate level actors, directors, designers, cinematographers, and theater aficionados from Rhode Island, that we have assembled to put on this amazing production, we are going by the name Mad Hat Theater (in the name of hopefully our OWN theater one day!) we are a non-profit, bunch of passionate theater hooligans who are super passionate about what we do. We have come together to put on one show before many of us continue on to grad school. We are natural-born story tellers and when we find a story to tell we simply must see it done. Thus is the case with Stephen Adly Giugus’ masterpiece "The Last Days of Judas Iscariot".

I would like to take this time to explicitly warn you, this is not "A Christmas Carol", this is a political show with profanity, racism, and more audaciously…questions. Was Judas at fault? Did he betray Jesus? Is there a heaven full of only good and a hell full of only bad? While this show does not attempt to answer any of these questions , it does bring up some wonderfully haunting points, not only about biblical characters, but even closer to home: does forgiveness matter if we cannot forgive ourselves?

This production means a lot to Ben and to me. And the fact that now we are, after all of these months of planning, so close to beginning actual production, it is a truly incredible feeling. This is a play about second chances, about forgiveness, about doing what is right, not because it is easy (because it is not) but because that is what HAS to be done. This show examines the life of a well known "criminal," Judas,  and analyzes every move he has made in order to show us something because, we? We are not unlike Judas.

So now... What will we do with the funds? GREAT QUESTION! Here, allow us to answer:
-Purchase the rights to the script
-Pay for our rental space (we rent it for December-January for rehearsals, tech week and performance week(s))
-Pay to rent out locations to film
-Purchase scripts (not cheap for 30+ people!)
-Purchase/Rent costumes, hair/wigs, makeup, accessories, set pieces, props, scenery
-Rent video equipment for the filmed portions of the production such as cameras, tripods, sound equipment, reflectors etc
-Rent equipment to actually SHOW the film such as: projector, cords/cables, projector screen, dolly and whatever else is necessary to show the filmed portions!
-Pay for our cast and crew on film (as we will be filming for several LONG days we will need to rent a vehicle to transport all of the people and equipment, pay for meals, gas, and pay for any other help we need)
-Purchasing products such as posters, programs, tickets, T-shirts, DVDs, etc

Our team is absolutely awesome! We have cinematographers, sound people, light people, editors, and designers. And all of those important people have staff to help them with their equipment, so as you can see, it can become very expensive very quickly!

We would also like to hire our photographer Alex to take stills throughout the filming process and to also take photos during the show! But he doesn't come cheap either.

Not to mention, it goes to all of you! When wonderful people like you donate to humble productions like ours, we want to repay you in rewards! And we shall! We have some wonderful rewards like T-shirts, signed programs, tickets, props and more!

story:
Send in the clowns...

If you don't already know us, we are two theatre artists Ita Fitzmahony (Ita is real person, not the skull ;-) and Carol Walsh. Ita is the director and co-creator of the show and I, Carol, am the clown, creator and writer. We met back in 2008 when we were working on a very non-clown project. However, quite quickly we realised we had a shared passion for the red nose and have been working and training together since. 

Over a year ago, I nervously approached Ita about creating a brand new clown show. We had just finished our Clown through Mask training and I really wanted to create something based on what we had learnt. Thankfully, Ita said yes. What began as a 10 minute cabaret piece about a clown who performed some of the most famous moments in Shakespeare developed into the show that is now called OutRAGEous Fortune. The show is about a clown, Dolores, who is completely obsessed with Shakespeare. Her ultimate dream is to perform on stage at the Globe Theatre. Of course, life doesn't quite go according to plan... Last year we presented a first draft in Smock Alley Theatre as part of Collaborations Festival. We got a really great response and now we want to do it again... but this time even better. 

Since that experience, Dolores clown has taken on a life of her own... She's been harassing me to continue to tell her story and to bring it to as many people as possible. For that purpose, we are launching a crowdfunding campaign to help us bring Dolores back to Smock Alley Theatre for three nights this April, 12th -14th. Your support would really help us to elaborate and fine tune the show, develop our following and present it to other theatre professionals. We have both loved working on this show and it means a lot to us both personally and professionally to make and present the best version of it we can.

More about us:

I am a clown and theatre maker.  At the age of six, I had the first inkling that I wanted to be a clown and aside from a few detours have pursued that path.  I've studied at Lispa, a physical theatre school based on the pedagogy of Jacques Lecoq, and also with the brilliant Sue Morrison in Clown through Mask. For the last 6 years I have worked creating, performing and facilitating clown based performances and workshops.

Ita is a performer, writer and great storyteller. She has trained in the Gaiety School of Acting and with the two world renowned clown teachers Philippe Gaulier and Sue Morrison. Recently, Ita wrote and performed in her own one woman show, Fabulous Females.  She has also performed in numerous short films and plays in Dublin and further afield.

Dolores' Dowry

So, to put the show on Dolores needs to bring a dowry. €800 worth of a dowry to be exact. What exactly will this go towards I hear you say:

  • A percentage will go towards the venue costs.

  • 5 days worth of rehearsal space (we have another five arranged with the support of Fringe Lab).

  • Photography,  poster design & Print.

In return, aside from being eternally grateful, we will be offering some great creative rewards including messages of thanks, selfies, postcards and even performances personally from Dolores. There will also be some discounts on tickets and workshops. 

This great stage of fools

What is the value of clown and this show today?

The clown expresses all aspects of themselves with authenticity - all their joy, rage, sorrow, beauty, disappointment... They share their vulnerability, their beautiful imperfections and humanity while maintaining a certain playfulness about their life/ predicament. By doing this, and connecting with the audience in this truth, they give them permission to recognise and express their own humanity. Now more than ever people need to be truly seen and acknowledged. This is the role of the clown.

OutRAGEous Fortune is about ambition, enthusiasm and the desire to live our dreams. It's also about the frustration and disappointment we feel when things aren't quite going to plan. In a world that sometimes only seems to value perfection and worldly success, Dolores gives a voice to our struggles in a really fun, honest and entertaining way.  

Nothing will come of Nothing

What if you can't donate right now? Don't worry, we totally understand. What you can do is help share this campaign or details of the show the show itself.  And of course most importantly come along and see us in April. Whatever way you can support us we are very grateful.

story:
Short Summary

Silver Kite Community Arts, LLC designs and facilitates intergenerational arts programs for retirement communities, senior centers, schools, and other non-profit organizations.

Our Indiegogo Campaign will raise funds to support our Intergenerational Theatre Company in its development and tour of an original production of "Wheel." 

Starring a cast of 7 people in 7 different decades of life, the production explores life cycles, transitions, and travels based on the life experiences of the members of the cast.

"Wheel" will premiere at the George Center for Community in Seattle on February 19 & 20, 2016.

Help Support "Wheel!"

We are seeking $7,000 to support our Intergenerational Theatre Company production of "Wheel."  The funds will be used in the following way:

1.  Actor / Artist fees:  $500 per actor x 7 actors = $3,500

2.  Production Costs (costumes, transportation, printing, space rental):  $1,750

3.  7 free performances for the community:  $250 (cost of the performance) x 7 performances = $1750

If our full goal of $7,000 is not met, we will use the funds raised to provide as many free or discounted performances of "Wheel" as possible.

If we exceed our goal, we will use the additional funds to support our next Intergenerational Theatre Company production which will begin rehearsal in March 2016!

The Impact

Our Intergenerational Theatre Company premiered its first show, "A String" in June 2015 with an all-women cast (ages 16 - 73).  "A String" was inspired by the life stories of its six cast members and was enjoyed by over 500 people at the George Center for Community, hospitals, retirement communities, and senior centers in the Seattle area.

We received a smART Ventures grant from the Seattle Office of Arts and Culture to provide 5 free (or discounted) performances of "A String."  The funding was wonderful, but we are not eligible for the grant again this year.  In order for us to bring our show to venues who cannot afford to pay us to perform, we are turning to Indiegogo.

We hope to reach at least 750 audience members in the Seattle area with our performance of "Wheel!"

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, please consider helping by...

1.  Spreading the word to friends about Silver Kite and our campaign
2.  Join our Mailing List
3.  Like our Facebook Page
4.  Follow us on Twitter
5.  Follow us on Instagram
6.  Check us out on YouTube
5.  Come and see our performances

story:
Help Bring Mythical Tales to Life

This winter, WAVE Productions mounts an epic piece of performance art produced by Sophia Carbonell and adapted/directed by Nikki Rosengren. Music, movement, and text combine to tell the story of Pandora, a woman who found both love and evils in the world.

This entirely student produced play needs your help to create the world Pandora explores. A donation of any size will be used to build all technical elements from costumes to set pieces. Donations are tax deductible, and donors will receive a special thanks in our program. Any questions can be addressed to our fundraising director at cquinn@u.northwestern.edu.

Thank you very much, and we hope you can make it to the show!

    Watch the Story Unfold February 11th - 13th

    Norris Louis Room
    $5 Students | $10 Adults

story:
English version below

 

Resumen

Somos la Red de Artes Vivas, una entidad sin ánimo de lucro que desde hace más de 7 años crea plataformas para hacer posible que los artistas colombianos más arriesgados imaginen, creen, investiguen, es decir: hagan su trabajo.  

Este año haremos la cuarta versión de nuestro festival-encuentro Pliegues y Despliegues 2017 en Bogotá  y necesitamos de tu ayuda. Con tu colaboración será posible seguir tejiendo la red para hacer posibles nuestros proyectos. 

 

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Para desarrollar nuestros proyectos trabajamos en red, sumando cómplices y aliados. Este año hemos encontrado apoyo en universidades, entidades públicas, teatros, colegas, artistas y amigos.  Como sumamos recursos y los optimizamos, hacemos nuestro festival-encuentro con un presupuesto mínimo. ¡Hacemos mucho con muy poco! 

Estamos acudiendo  a ti para dar unas condiciones  adecuadas a los artistas participantes. Para ello, sólo necesitamos recolectar 6000 dólares que estarán destinados en su totalidad a la producción de los trabajos  de esta versión de Pliegues 2017.

Conviértete en uno de los mecenas haciendo tu donación y  obtendrás interesantes recompensas.

 

El impacto

Nuestro proyecto responde a una apuesta -nada fácil- de crear plataformas culturales sostenibles en Colombia. Creamos espacios para garantizar el acceso de los  bogotanos a expresiones artísticas de primera calidad y para dar espacio a los artistas para crear. Hace poco, haciendo un recuento de nuestra historia, sumábamos más de 7 años de trabajo continuo, creando temporadas, festivales, jornadas, proyectos con la ciudad, todo desde la lógica del trabajo en red. 

Riesgos y desafíos

Este año estamos probablemente en el reto más grande de nuestra trayectoria, pues las financiaciones grandes con las que contábamos, por un motivo u otro dejaron de estar.  !Estamos haciendo esta versión sin patrocinio! Así que estamos trabajando en red y estamos siendo fieles a la temática de nuestra plataforma este año: pensar lo impensable y hacer posible lo imposible.  ¡Unete a esta aventura!
  

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Si no puedes donar el dinero de la forma en que te sugerimos, puedes colaborar con nosotros de muchas maneras. Recuerda, nosotros trabajamos en red, así que puedes:

-Decirnos dónde recoger tu donación en efectivo. Escríbenos al correo redartesvivas@gmail.com

-Ayudarnos a difundir esta campaña.

-Difundir nuestras comunicaciones entre tus contactos.

-Contarnos si puedes alojar a uno de nuestros invitados en tu casa.

-Contarnos si quieres hacer alguna donación en especie: almuerzos, cenas, desayunos, impresos, prensa etc.

¡Tus apoyos serán bienvenidos!

***

Summary

We are the Live Arts Network, a non-profit entity which has been creating platforms to enable the riskiest new Colombian artists to imagine, create, research and basically, do their job.

This year we will hold the 4rth version of the Pliegues y Despliegues Festival in Bogotá, and we need your help. Your cooperation will make it possible to continue weaving this web in order to make our projects possible. 

 

What we need and what you get

In order to develop our projects, we function as a constantly growing network of supporters and allies. This year we have found support in universities, public entities, theaters, colleagues, artists and friends.  As we add resources and optimize them, we make possible our festival with a minimum budget. We do a lot with very little! 

We are seeking your support in order to give participant artists the adequate conditions to present their work. For this, we only need to collect US$6000, which will be destined in their totality to the production of the Pliegues 2017 Festival.

Become a patron of the arts by donating and you will obtain interesting compensations .

Impact

Our project has to do with the challenge –not an easy one- of creating sustainable cultural platforms in Colombia. We create spaces to guarantee Bogotá citizens access to top quality artistic expressions, and to give space for artists to create. For more than 7 years, we have been developing seasons, festivals, sessions and projects with the city, all based on networking.

Risks and challenges

This year we are facing what has probably been the largest challenge in our trajectory. The large financial support we were expecting, didn´t work out for one reason or another.  We are holding the Pliegues 2017 Festival without financial aid! For this reason we are networking harder than ever, being faithful to the utopian theme of this year´s platform: to think the unthinkable and to make possible the impossible. We invite you to join our adventure!
  

Other ways you can help

If you can´t donate money, there are many ways you can help. Remember, we work as a network, so you can:

-Help us to disseminate this campaign.

-Forward our Festival information among your contacts.

-Contact us if you can host one of our invited artists (if you live in Bogotá).

-Contact us if you can make a donation in kind: lunches, dinners, breakfasts, printed materials, press, etc.

¡All kinds of support are welcome!

Somos la Red de Artes Vivas, una entidad sin ánimo de lucro que desde hace más de 7 años crea plataformas para hacer posible que los artistas colombianos más arriesgados imaginen, creen, investiguen, es decir: hagan su trabajo.
