story:
WELCOME! 


Hippana is an international travelling theatre company from Finland, Canada, Italy and Germany. We are a new generation of theatre makers who risk uncommon adaptations of classical plays and give workshops on physical theatre. Join us to make this very special event happen! LET'S GO ON TOUR 2016! 
Palermo: May
Brussels: June
Cologne: June-July


VISION

We are thrilled to create a theatre that puts the body and the performer in the centre of the action. Before costumes, props and stage designs can exist we shape the stage with  movement. Our theatre is meant to speak visually and therefore be accessible for a broad audience, an audience that does not need to have a particular knowledge of literature to understand the performace. The human body is universal and as such its language. We want to transpose this language in its various forms, comic, tragic, grotesque and deliver classical plays in a fresh and accessible spirit.


MULTICULTURAL

Our company is international and therefore multilingual. 

This is a challenge and at the same time a chance to create a borderless theatre which is ready to adapt to the local particularities. An ongoing challenge for the actors of the Commedia was to study the humans, their language, forms of expression, sorrows and hoys before playing so they could confront their audience with an image of themselves. By these means they were able to entertain and criticize at the same time.

Likewise our productions shall keep their international character and, at the same time, pick out specific regional elements. These elements enrich our physical play which is rooted in a variety of theatrical forms of expression such as Mime, Object Theatre and Physical Storytelling.


STYLE

Tragicomedy delivers us the base. The laughter, created through pointed comic, Slapstick and Grotesque caracters opens spaces in the audience that make a receptive ground for the hidden tragedy. Our theatre is meant to communicate a profound human experience, that reduces the physical gap between audience and stage to a minimum.


MOLIÈRE AND THE COMMEDIA

Why Molière? How study and adapt a text in 4 languages?

The text is the literary base for the ensemble. In the creation it is worked dramaturgically by the actors, it is stretched, torn apart, rewritten and worked to serve the necessity of a multilingual adaptation. The Miser / L'Avare/ L'Avaro / Der Geizige/ Saituri has become an image of a society, in which the fear of material loss has become a dominant factor in how politics and public opinion are shaped.

Our wealth is built on sand. The panic of declining life standards threatens this structure as we witness the closing of borders and societies, generating mistrust and hatred.


THE MISER

Harpagon's household is a microcosm and a mirror of a social reality. His regime is one of fear: a very clever tool, cold-blooded and calculated. Costs-in-Use are being weighed up and whoever needs too much is sorted out. Harpagon's servants work for him out of poverty, they come from everywhere. They have fled, they are lost and do not even understand themselves. The patron feeds them what is leftover from the meals and makes it clear he could destroy all hopes for a better existence by snapping his fingers. In this ambiance, hungriness and emotion grow rapidly until they explode in a storm of despair and love. What remains?


METHODS

In our methods of creation the ensemble is influenced by the pedagogy of J.Lecoq, applied through Saidi Lassaad at his school in Brussels.

The Finno-Canadian-Italian-German troupe had the opportunity throughout the period of two years to study with teachers and students to create a common vocabulary of movement. This language is permanently refined and enhanced in the creation period. All members bring in new experiences and methods from abroad such as singing, rhythm, acting techniques, dance, juggling...

Improvisation and daily physical exercise are the base for the common creation. Between us we exchange roles from students to teacher to generate more knowledge.


MASK

The mask is an essential element and tool for the actors. Through the manipulation of body and voice, the mask gives important material in the creation of the characters. Meanwhile it allows the actors to play 2-3 different characters in one play if needed. Maskmaking and research is a further, vital element of the troupe.


PUBLIC

As performers we assume our responsibility towards the audience, we are the hosts, if we play in theatres, schools, or refugee homes. 

As we are playing we create a moment of collecitivity and discourse. We are inspired by the virtuose musicality of the Commedia dell'Arte, which used strong physical play as a key performative element. At the same time the Commedia has always been a european phenomenon, which as a wandering and travelling art form, knew no borders. We want to keep the libertarian spirit and mobility. Therefore we construct our pieces with a minimum of technique and set design, relying on the expressivity of our bodies and voices.



WORKSHOP: Body Talk

An immersive theatre workshop which incorporates multiculturalism and multilingualism in finding a common physical language.

Our goal is to encourage individual physical expression as we move towards an open intercultural exchange.

Although each individual comes with a special color, a cultural backround and a way of speaking, the human body is universal. We all share this reality. In investigating how the body moves, we find not only what makes us different, but what makes all too human.

Hippana teaches specific theatre games and exercises that enhance communication and acting skills between students.

The workshop includes:

Warm-up: Fun and interactive body and voice warm-ups

Physical Comedy: Exploring the worlds of Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton.

Voice: Playing with the tones, vibrations, intensities and differences in language.

Movement: Physical training for theatre and performance.

Mask: Finding the body of the mask


WHAT WE NEED FROM YOU

-Travelling Costs: 2000 €

-Web-site: 500 €

-Poster and marketing materials: 200 €

-Costumes: 300 €

-Accomodation on the road: 1000 €


WHAT YOU GET

Depending on the amount, you shall receive a standard format of our orignally designed poster, leather keychains made by Hippana, free tickets to see the show, a DVD of the show, handmade comedy masks, a personal workshop or some surprise!

It is our first time using crowdfunding and we all wish for the best.

Thank you all for your future support!


OUR TOURPLAN 2016


02.06.2016 St. Augustin

04.06.2016 Nümbrecht

11.06.2016 Brussels

15/16/19.06.2016 Wildeck

23./24.06. Hildesheim

28.06.2016 Düsseldorf

08.07.2016 Kassel

15.07.2016 Berlin

16.07.2016 Friedensfelde

17.07.2016 Zollbrücke

21.07.2016 Köln  




Hippana keeps its right to deny under certain circumstances supporters.

story:
UPDATE: WOW!!!

We never expected to reach out goal so quickly. Thank you, thank you, thank you to  everyone for all the amazing support.
But we're not done yet :)
The price we set for this campaign ($3500) was the bare-bones budget version of our show. Now we are setting our sights even higher. If we can raise another 1000$ we can PAY OUR ACTORS for their incredibly hard work.
 
To be perfectly transparent:
750$ would be allocated for stipends for the actors and writers.
200$ would be added to our set budget
and the left over 50$ is set aside to pay for indiegogo fees.
 
*********************
 
The NOW Collective is a new theater company that provides a collaborative environment for emerging artists to explore new and challenging work. Apartment Complex is a collaboration between 5 writers, 14 actors and 1 director.
 
If you are unable to give, please support us by following us on twitter, instagram, facebook, and by sharing this campaign :)
 
@nowcollective
http://www.nowcollective.org
 
Apartment Complex, at TBG Studio
312 west 36th Street, 3rd Floor
Friday January 13th @ 7
Saturday January 14th @ 3, 7
Sunday January 15th @ 7
Friday January 20th @ 7
Saturday January 21st @ 7
 

Why support Apartment Complex?

It's no secret that New York City is an ever changing beast. We are trying to represent this change. Often times it feels like the only thing that stays the same are the buildings.

And, in NYC, not only do we live next to each other, but we also live on top of each other, under each other, and around each other. We live concurrently to each other - the day we move out of an apartment is sometimes the same day someone else moves in.

Too often we find ourselves rushing through the day with no awareness of what any of these folks (our friends, our roommates, our neighbors) are going through.

Join us as we take the time to explore what, exactly, we are missing. 

In Apartment Complex, we follow not one person or one family, but one apartment as it changes residents.

By helping us realize our vision you're ensuring that new, exciting, thoughtful, art continues to thrive in a city whose only constant is change.

 

We need your help to bring Apartment Complex to life!

Putting on a play in New York City is expensive work, which is why we need your help! When you donate to this production, every cent will go directly into the production. Here is a general breakdown of how the funds will be used:

  • Space rental:$ 1,500
    • Writers Labs
    • Rehearsals
    • Performances
  • Set, Props, Costumes: $1000
  • Marketing: $200
  • Insurance: $500
  • Other production costs: $300

 

The Artist Involved

Charlotte Grady (Director) - Charlotte is a New York City-based actress from Orlando, Florida. She recently completed the Acting Apprenticeship program with The Barrow Group Theatre under the artistic direction of Seth Barrish and Lee Brock; along with TBG, she has worked with TheAlphaNYC Theatre Company, Stag & Lion Theatre Company, and Box Wine Theatre. She recently completed filming on Red Flight Pictures' We Were the Night.

Sean T.  McGrath  (Writer/Actor) - Often described as "The jewel of the world" (Mother, 1989), Sean Thomas McGrath was born and raised in the humble hamlet of Pearl River, NY, a short train ride from the greatest city in the world, where he spent most of his days. Sean packed up his life and took off for London (the other greatest city in the world), where he gained his Masters Degree in Theatre from the esteemd Rose Bruford College.

Adrian Burke (Writer/Actor) - Adrian Burke is an actor, director, and improviser based in New York City. He is a house performer at Reckless Theatre in Chelsea where he improvises every Thursday with his teams MINGLE and DEATHWISH. He recently completed an acting apprenticeship at The Barrow Group Theater Company. He has performed at New York Theater Workshop, The Barrow Group, Dixon Place, The Brick Theater, The Paradise Factory, and many more. 

Sam Evans (Writer/Actor) - Sam Evans is a NYC based actress, improviser and writer from Philadelphia. Sam performs weekly with Too Big of a Dog and The Original Cast at Reckless Theatre. NYC Theater Credits include: The Barrow Group, UglyRhino, Fresh Ground Pepper, Austrian Stage, Traveling Lantern, DreamStreet, Shakespeare in the Pub. Regional: Williamstown Theatre Festival, Huntington Theatre, Central Square, Lyric Stage, Boston Playwright's Theater, Theatre on Fire. Sam's writing has been produced by The Barrow Group, UglyRhino, the SHRTWV Play Festival and at Reckless Theatre. 

Kasey Lee Huizinga (Writer/Actor) - Kasey Lee Huizinga is a Brooklyn born and raised actor, writer, and singer. She has been seen onstage at The American Theater of Actors, Judson Church, Dixon Place, and The Davenport Theater. Northwestern University, Maggie Flanigan Studio. Proud member of the 2015-2016 Barrow Group Apprentice Company.

Jennifer Ward (Writer/Actor) - Jennifer moved to New York City to train with Seth Barrish and Lee Brock at The Barrow Group as a 2015-2016 Acting Apprentice. In May 2014 Jennifer earned her B.A. in Theatre Performance from the University of Missouri-Kansas City. Some of her favorite work in Kansas City includes performing at the KC Fringe Festival every summer, training with KC Improv, and performing with the undergrad and graduate actors at UMKC. 

McKenna DuBose (Producer/Actor) - McKenna was born and raised in South Carolina. She graduated from the College of Charleston with a BA in Theatre with concentrations in Performance and Costume Design and Technology. She just completed the 2015-2016 Apprentice Company at The Barrow Group. NYC credits include Daisy in "Wanda, Daisy & The Great Rapture" (Exquisite Corpse Company), Grey/Claire in In The Pipeline (TBG Apprentice Company), Kelsey in the web series "Kelsey", and Costume Designer for Across the Park (Araca Project).

Andrew Dobbie (Technical Director/Actor) - Andrew Dobbie an actor and technician based in New York City, and raised in Dallas, TX (so, you know he has some southern charm).  He just completed a year long apprenticeship at The Barrow Group, and is traveling back and forth from New York City to Glasgow, Scotland to take short courses in voice and acting.

Morgan Bartholick (Actor) - Morgan Bartholick is an actor/singer/musician, originally from Port Angeles, WA.  Morgan has been seen in shows at The Secret Theatre, Musical Theatre Factory, and The Players Theatre, to name a few. Recent credits include Annas in Jesus Christ Superstar and Margaret Mead in HAIR. Morgan is a member of the 2015-2016 Apprentice Company at The Barrow Group Theatre Company and School, studying with co-artistic directors, Seth Barrish and Lee Brock.

Justin Andrew Davis (Actor) - Justin Andrew Davis is a professional NYC-based actor, writer, and sweets-eater. He recently wrapped his first feature film as lead Alex in writer/director Brian DiLorenzo's "Myth," which is slated to premiere in 2017. Currently, he is in the middle of writing and producing his first short film, and hopes to shoot it by mid-2017. In between performing, writing, auditioning, and working, Justin can be found trying to resist his sweet tooth and wishing he owned a dog. 

Dan DeCarlo (Actor) - Dan DeCarlo has done the  following acting things, in no particular order: performed at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, completed the TBG Apprentice Program, co-starred in the pilot for the CBS sitcom, Courting Alex, graduated from The Second City Training Center, Chicago and some other stuff.

Therese Dizon (Actor) - Therese Dizon is an east coast based actor whose recent credits include Mara (The Topography Between, Fringe NYC) and Lauren (Completeness, West of 10th). She just completed an apprenticeship with The Barrow Group Theater Company and can be seen next in De Profundis, an original work by Ran Xia as part of the Midtown International Theatre Festival. 

J.W. Harvey (Actor) - J.W. Harvey is a shapeshifting creative in New York. A longtime writer & former Chemical Engineering major, he began acting and modeling to explore new characters and emotional depths, repackaging his experiences in words for the reader to unwrap. Aspiring to the sweet-spot between right-brained and left-brained, he candy-coats deep intellectuality with shiny commercial ribbon, creating artistic layers that all audiences can consume.​

Ann-Kathryne Mills (Actor) - Ann-Kathryne studied acting and jazz voice while earning her undergraduate degree at Columbia University. Additionally, she has trained at HB Studio, The Barrow Group, and currently studies at Upright Citizens Brigade. She most recently held research and policy positions at Dance Theatre of Harlem and Theatre Communications Group, where she focused on various arts advocacy initiatives.

Alex Mollica (Actor) - Alex Mollica is a actor-singer living in Manhattan. He was last seen in Once Upon the Bronx at the Manhattan Repertory Theatre. Alex also wrote, conceptualized and produced his own cabaret, "Doing It My Way," at New York's Duplex Theater. Alex is an alumnus of Marymount Manhattan College, where he earned a B.A. in Theater Performance and Musical Theater. Alex was a 2015-2016 apprentice at The Barrow Group, where he studied under master teachers Seth Barrish and Lee Brock.​
story_txt:
UPDATE: WOW!!!We never expected to reach out goal so quickly. Thank you, thank you, thank you to  everyone for all the amazing support. But we're not done yet :)The price we set for this campaign ($3500) was the bare-bones budget version of our show. Now we are setting our sights even higher. If we can raise another 1000$ we can PAY OUR ACTORS for their incredibly hard work. To be perfectly transparent: 750$ would be allocated for stipends for the actors and writers.200$ would be added to our set budgetand the left over 50$ is set aside to pay for indiegogo fees. ********************* The NOW Collective is a new theater company that provides a collaborative environment for emerging artists to explore new and challenging work. Apartment Complex is a collaboration between 5 writers, 14 actors and 1 director. If you are unable to give, please support us by following us on twitter, instagram, facebook, and by sharing this campaign :) @nowcollectivehttp://www.nowcollective.org 
Apartment Complex, at TBG Studio312 west 36th Street, 3rd FloorFriday January 13th @ 7Saturday January 14th @ 3, 7Sunday January 15th @ 7Friday January 20th @ 7Saturday January 21st @ 7 Why support Apartment Complex?It's no secret that New York City is an ever changing beast. We are trying to represent this change. Often times it feels like the only thing that stays the same are the buildings.And, in NYC, not only do we live next to each other, but we also live on top of each other, under each other, and around each other. We live concurrently to each other - the day we move out of an apartment is sometimes the same day someone else moves in.Too often we find ourselves rushing through the day with no awareness of what any of these folks (our friends, our roommates, our neighbors) are going through.Join us as we take the time to explore what, exactly, we are missing. In Apartment Complex, we follow not one person or one family, but one apartment as it changes residents.By helping us realize our vision you're ensuring that new, exciting, thoughtful, art continues to thrive in a city whose only constant is change. We need your help to bring Apartment Complex to life!Putting on a play in New York City is expensive work, which is why we need your help! When you donate to this production, every cent will go directly into the production. Here is a general breakdown of how the funds will be used:
Space rental:$ 1,500
Writers Labs
Rehearsals
Performances


Set, Props, Costumes: $1000
Marketing: $200
Insurance: $500
Other production costs: $300
 The Artist InvolvedCharlotte Grady (Director) - Charlotte is a New York City-based actress from Orlando, Florida. She recently completed the Acting Apprenticeship program with The Barrow Group Theatre under the artistic direction of Seth Barrish and Lee Brock; along with TBG, she has worked with TheAlphaNYC Theatre Company, Stag & Lion Theatre Company, and Box Wine Theatre. She recently completed filming on Red Flight Pictures' We Were the Night.Sean T.  McGrath  (Writer/Actor) - Often described as "The jewel of the world" (Mother, 1989), Sean Thomas McGrath was born and raised in the humble hamlet of Pearl River, NY, a short train ride from the greatest city in the world, where he spent most of his days. Sean packed up his life and took off for London (the other greatest city in the world), where he gained his Masters Degree in Theatre from the esteemd Rose Bruford College.Adrian Burke (Writer/Actor) - Adrian Burke is an actor, director, and improviser based in New York City. He is a house performer at Reckless Theatre in Chelsea where he improvises every Thursday with his teams MINGLE and DEATHWISH. He recently completed an acting apprenticeship at The Barrow Group Theater Company. He has performed at New York Theater Workshop, The Barrow Group, Dixon Place, The Brick Theater, The Paradise Factory, and many more. Sam Evans (Writer/Actor) - Sam Evans is a NYC based actress, improviser and writer from Philadelphia. Sam performs weekly with Too Big of a Dog and The Original Cast at Reckless Theatre. NYC Theater Credits include: The Barrow Group, UglyRhino, Fresh Ground Pepper, Austrian Stage, Traveling Lantern, DreamStreet, Shakespeare in the Pub. Regional: Williamstown Theatre Festival, Huntington Theatre, Central Square, Lyric Stage, Boston Playwright's Theater, Theatre on Fire. Sam's writing has been produced by The Barrow Group, UglyRhino, the SHRTWV Play Festival and at Reckless Theatre. Kasey Lee Huizinga (Writer/Actor) - Kasey Lee Huizinga is a Brooklyn born and raised actor, writer, and singer. She has been seen onstage at The American Theater of Actors, Judson Church, Dixon Place, and The Davenport Theater. Northwestern University, Maggie Flanigan Studio. Proud member of the 2015-2016 Barrow Group Apprentice Company.Jennifer Ward (Writer/Actor) - Jennifer moved to New York City to train with Seth Barrish and Lee Brock at The Barrow Group as a 2015-2016 Acting Apprentice. In May 2014 Jennifer earned her B.A. in Theatre Performance from the University of Missouri-Kansas City. Some of her favorite work in Kansas City includes performing at the KC Fringe Festival every summer, training with KC Improv, and performing with the undergrad and graduate actors at UMKC. McKenna DuBose (Producer/Actor) - McKenna was born and raised in South Carolina. She graduated from the College of Charleston with a BA in Theatre with concentrations in Performance and Costume Design and Technology. She just completed the 2015-2016 Apprentice Company at The Barrow Group. NYC credits include Daisy in "Wanda, Daisy & The Great Rapture" (Exquisite Corpse Company), Grey/Claire in In The Pipeline (TBG Apprentice Company), Kelsey in the web series "Kelsey", and Costume Designer for Across the Park (Araca Project).Andrew Dobbie (Technical Director/Actor) - Andrew Dobbie an actor and technician based in New York City, and raised in Dallas, TX (so, you know he has some southern charm).  He just completed a year long apprenticeship at The Barrow Group, and is traveling back and forth from New York City to Glasgow, Scotland to take short courses in voice and acting.Morgan Bartholick (Actor) - Morgan Bartholick is an actor/singer/musician, originally from Port Angeles, WA.  Morgan has been seen in shows at The Secret Theatre, Musical Theatre Factory, and The Players Theatre, to name a few. Recent credits include Annas in Jesus Christ Superstar and Margaret Mead in HAIR. Morgan is a member of the 2015-2016 Apprentice Company at The Barrow Group Theatre Company and School, studying with co-artistic directors, Seth Barrish and Lee Brock.Justin Andrew Davis (Actor) - Justin Andrew Davis is a professional NYC-based actor, writer, and sweets-eater. He recently wrapped his first feature film as lead Alex in writer/director Brian DiLorenzo's "Myth," which is slated to premiere in 2017. Currently, he is in the middle of writing and producing his first short film, and hopes to shoot it by mid-2017. She just completed an apprenticeship with The Barrow Group Theater Company and can be seen next in De Profundis, an original work by Ran Xia as part of the Midtown International Theatre Festival. J.W. Harvey (Actor) - J.W. Harvey is a shapeshifting creative in New York. A longtime writer & former Chemical Engineering major, he began acting and modeling to explore new characters and emotional depths, repackaging his experiences in words for the reader to unwrap. Aspiring to the sweet-spot between right-brained and left-brained, he candy-coats deep intellectuality with shiny commercial ribbon, creating artistic layers that all audiences can consume.​Ann-Kathryne Mills (Actor) - Ann-Kathryne studied acting and jazz voice while earning her undergraduate degree at Columbia University. Additionally, she has trained at HB Studio, The Barrow Group, and currently studies at Upright Citizens Brigade. She most recently held research and policy positions at Dance Theatre of Harlem and Theatre Communications Group, where she focused on various arts advocacy initiatives.Alex Mollica (Actor) - Alex Mollica is a actor-singer living in Manhattan. He was last seen in Once Upon the Bronx at the Manhattan Repertory Theatre. Alex also wrote, conceptualized and produced his own cabaret, "Doing It My Way," at New York's Duplex Theater. Alex is an alumnus of Marymount Manhattan College, where he earned a B.A. in Theater Performance and Musical Theater. Alex was a 2015-2016 apprentice at The Barrow Group, where he studied under master teachers Seth Barrish and Lee Brock.​

story:
ABOUT

Neville Dance Theatre, a Manhattan based contemporary dance company now in their 11th year, presents a fall season of world premieres.  Our innovative production brings four new works, five new artistic collaborations with choreographers, costume designers and technical artists and a company of twelve exceptional dancers to the stage in a diverse program exploring thematic concepts, movement ideologies and reflections about the world in which we live and the human condition. Our program includes world premiere choreographic commissions of:

 

EXPOSED

By choreographer Brenda R. Neville, incorporates hand held lights and explores our increasing sense of overexposure and loss of privacy in an online world.  

 

 

BLESSED

Also by Brenda R. Neville, transports us to an ethereal realm in a quartet for two couples to music by Karl Jenkins and recorded by 2Cellos.

 

EPIDERMIS

By Ursula Verduzco, is a duet for two women which explores our hidden selves and begs the question. Show your Epidermis and lie to me, you are not who you portray.

 

BRAHMS' DOUBLE CONCERTO

By Billy Blanken, is a neo-classical work set to and inspired by Brahms's intricate score.

 

“Ambitious and provocative...Neville’s choreography is original and inventive.  See a Neville Dance Theatre production the minute you can.  You will have your senses awakened and your mind stirring.”   - Liv Cummins, freelance writer

 

 

What We Need

The amount of work, effort, personnel and COSTS that go into bringing artistic ideas to life and to audiences are many. Our previous fundraising initiatives for this project have been successful, with support from individual donors, corporate sponsors Art for Life and Education, PhysioWellness and Freed of London along with program advertisers, equalling approximately $4,000. Your help is needed to raise additional funds for costs such as: 

  • Studio rentals $1,280 (sixteen 4/hour rehearsals at $20/hour)
  • Venue rental $1,220 for two performances
  • Artist compensation $1,200 (12 dancers at $100/performance day)
  • Payment to designers: videographer ($350), photographer ($800), costumer ($700)
  • Production costs $500 (for props/lights)
  • Marketing and promotion $1500 (PR, postcards and advertising) 

 

What You Get

Our campaign is a special invitation for you to be an active and proud part of this production and a chance to get more directly involved with Neville Dance Theatre and the arts. You'll also receive acknowledgment and, depending on your giving level, special rewards for your participation, including program and online 'thank you' listings, NDT collectibles, and opportunities to be a part of our process by attending performances and exclusive backstage access.

 

Our Commitment

Neville Dance Theatre has been creating and presenting innovative and influential dance in the New York area for over ten years.  From full length ballets, concert works and thematic shorts, our company commits itself to exploring innovative new approaches and ideas in regards to choreography, movement styles, narrative themes and production elements. Our endeavors help further the development of dance as an important universal means of expression, communication and art form, and is shared with audiences of all ages and nationalities.

We are 100% committed and invested in making this production happen and to continuing our mission of bringing the artistry and joy of dance to others through this project and many more to come. All funds raised (no matter the campaign outcome) will go directly towards expenses for this production.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are currently unable to make a donation, please consider helping by:

  • Getting the word out!  Tell your friends and co-workers about our show and campaign and SHARE via the social media buttons above.
  • Coming to the show! Performances are November 5th at 3pm and 7:30pm at the Actors Fund Arts Center in Brooklyn, NY.  PURCHASE TICKETS HERE 

 

Neville Dance Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Neville Dance Theatre must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Thank you for your support!

story:
This year's show

This year Scrappy Shakespeare is producing one of Shakespeare's greatest tragedies, Macbeth. Taking inspiration from the spooky but fun styles of Tim Burton and early Jim Henson films, our production will be fun, inventive, and family-friendly. Join us at the Denny's Plaza for any of our 10 FREE performances, all at 7:30 pm on the dates below:
June 23 - 26
June 30 - July 1
July 7 - 10 

What's Scrappy Shakespeare?

Scrappy Shakespeare is a company that was founded on the idea that if you want to see something done, you use the resources you have and dive in head first. Last year six professional theatre artists decided that they could produce the first public, free, outdoor Shakespeare play in Spartanburg with only themselves as the team behind the entire production. We were six artists with a strong shared work history--we shared a vocabulary, a level of passion, and an excitement for the new and the challenging. So the six of us designed, directed, produced, and acted in a production of A Midsummer Night's Dream staged at the amphitheater outside of USC's George Dean Johnson, Jr. College of Business and Economics.

This year we're back with our second production: Macbeth. We've also moved to a new location, the plaza at the Denny's Building, to create greater visibility for our production.

In keeping with our company aesthetic, this year's production is sure to be fast, fun, and family-friendly.

More than just a production...

It may sound strange to say that you're contribution could change professional theatre, but we believe it could.

There are very few professional acting opportunities in Spartanburg, though we have many training programs at our local colleges producing quality actors ever year (our company is almost entirely made up of them). We are seeking to change that by offering quality theatrical opportunities that go beyond acting in a show and gives the company the experience of creating and producing a performance from beginning to end.. Your contribution ensures that our company can continue to grow and offer more and more of these opportunities to our local artists.

Professional theatre isn't something that only happens in big cities, it happens everywhere. All it demands is a group of artists who are dedicated to creating quality work and the means to compensate them for their time. With your help we are redefining "professional" to include artists who value living and working in smaller cities like Spartanburg.

Keep us free!

We think it is of great importance that we are able to offer our work to the public free of charge. Your donation ensures that we raise our money from those who are able to contribute without having to create a threshold for our audience. This means the greatest accessibility to every citizen of Spartanburg.

But, I don't have the money to give...

No worries! Just help us spread our story! It takes support in all different ways to make a show like this work. The best thing you can do is tell people about this campaign and about the show. We hope to see you and your friends at one of our performances!

story:
Myths, Legends & Questions: 

three new works for screen and stage  

 

 Doppelgänger Dance Collective's second evening length program is an interdisciplinary concert blending dance, theater, live music, and a dance-film.

This concert comprises three world premieres and newly composed music, featuring new choreography by  Rhode Island based Heidi Henderson and Andy Russ, and Boston based choreographer Alissa Cardone.  Russ directs a dance film inspired by the myth of Narcissus and Echo, Henderson builds a post-modern dance piece collaborating with cellist Adrienne Taylor, and Cardone creates a new work blending Butoh and postmodern forms with music composed by Nate Tucker.

Accompanying the concerts in both Providence and Cambridge this spring,  DDC will host workshops, masterclasses, Q&A's and panels with the artists.

In this campaign, we ask for your support in funding the creation of these new choreographic works for our 2016-2017 season and help us bring them to a stage near you.

Season 2 = Indiegogo #2 

 

ABOUT US  (AND OUR MISSION)

Doppelgänger Dance Collective (DDC) co-founded in 2015 by dancers Shura Baryshnikov and Danielle Davidson, fosters the creation and performance of original, contemporary choreographic work for duet performance. Compelled to dance together from the start, they conceived of a performance project that framed or captured this shared duality, their immediate bodily complicity. DDC is the tangible result of these dialogues and showcases a commitment to the inclusion of live music in performance and to the creation of interdisciplinary works. They offer choreographic commissions to a diverse group of artists each season.  DDC is committed to public accessibility and service to the community, through mentoring and teaching opportunities, as well as informal showings and presentations. 

 

WHAT SETS DDC APART?  

DDC has taken the traditional dance company model and turned it inside out.  In our case, as Artistic Directors and dancers, we commission the choreographers, plan the performance season, and produce the performances.  Rather than relying on a single choreographer or artistic director, we are building performance opportunities for ourselves and for the community.  It is a DIY-Dance model.

 

THE BENEFITS  

Choreographers, musicians and other art-makers are given the opportunity to collaborate with skilled, mature performers and to have their work produced by DDC.

New England audiences (and beyond!) see new works by multiple art-makers juxtaposed in one dynamic dance program.

The New England creative community benefits from the engagement of local choreographers, musicians, and performers.

 

THIS PROJECT  

Myths, Legends & Questions, DDC’s second, evening-length concert featuring three new works for screen and stage, will be presented in the spring of 2017 in Providence, RI and in Cambridge, MA. 

April 12 - 22 at AS220's Black Box theater in Providence, RI.  

May  19 - 20 at The Dance Complex, Cambridge, MA

 

THE PITCH

Please help us to fund this project. We have received a number of generous grants and corporate sponsorships but still need $8000 to fully fund artists fees, costume design and fabrication, lighting design, film shoots, and more.

Your assistance will help make this possible.  We have numerous contribution levels with a number of fun perks.  From social media shout outs, DDC t-shirts, personalized surprise packages, tickets to shows and more, we will be sure to say a heartfelt thank you for your contribution.

Thank you in advance for your interest and investment!  

 

Doppelgänger Dance Collective is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Doppelgänger Dance Collective must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

We have received a number of generous grants and corporate sponsorships but still need $8000 to fully fund artists fees, costume design and fabrication, lighting design, film shoots, and more.Your assistance will help make this possible.  We have numerous contribution levels with a number of fun perks.  From social media shout outs, DDC t-shirts, personalized surprise packages, tickets to shows and more, we will be sure to say a heartfelt thank you for your contribution.Thank you in advance for your interest and investment!   Doppelgänger Dance Collective is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Doppelgänger Dance Collective must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Hello There!

Allow us to introduce ourselves: we’re Three, A Performance Group. But more specifically, we’re Gabi, Jenny, Matthew, Yolanda, and Michelle, and it’s lovely to meet you! We put together this little group for one purpose: theatre. After graduating from the theatre program at the University of New Mexico, we came together to support each other in our artistic endeavors. 

Michelle and Jenny have been hard at work since September adapting Shakespeare’s Hamlet into our newest work: Hamlet; or My Thoughts Be Bloody. The script is now ready for its premiere but we need funding in order to support this project with a set, costumes, props, music, and other details to bring this script to life!

What We Need & What You Get

Our ultimate goal is to reach $800. This will ensure coverage of all the essentials for which we have accounted, such as advertising, costumes, and props, but also to cover unseen issues and costs.

As a huge thank you for all your love and support, we want to make sure you get some fun perks in return! These include hugs, free tickets, or special invitations!

Even if we don’t reach our entire goal, any funding we can get will help.

Why Hamlet? Why Now?

We all know and love Shakespeare’s classic Hamlet. Even if you were one of the less dutiful students in high school and skipped on this ubiquitous required reading, we still pick up on these references in our culture. “To be, or not to be?” is widely quoted, written into comics, or referenced in countless scripts, books, and cartoons. And it’s only one of many classic lines that we quote in our day to day whether we are aware of it or not. So why Hamlet? Why here and why now?

Our members, Jenny Hoffman and Michelle Lawson, began this process with two ideas: 1. They wanted the script to be adapted into a three person show and 2. What if Hamlet was actually mentally ill? In fact, what if his mental illness extends into the fact that the plot of the classic tale of Hamlet is actually only happening in Hamlet’s head? From these two points, they allowed the language to flow into this new adaptation. What became of this new story was beyond anything either could imagine. It eventually evolved into a story of mental illness in our society today. Those who suffer from these diseases are not only plagued with their invisible symptoms, but with stigmas, lack of support, or well-meaning friends and family who believe these illnesses can be wished or loved away. This is why Hamlet’s story needs to be told now.

Show Dates and Locations

Hamlet; or My Thoughts Be Bloody
By William Shakespeare
Adapted by Jenny Hoffman & Michelle Lawson

Tricklock Performance Laboratory
110 Gold Ave SW
Albuquerque, NM 87102

April 21-23, 2016

Thursday 7:30pm
Friday 7:30pm
Saturday 2:00pm & 7:30pm

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute monetarily, here are some ways you can help out:

Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or your social media of choice!

Comment, like, and share content on our page. With lots of activity comes more exposure in the Indiegogo community!

Simple word of mouth can never go wrong!

Come see the shows! We'd love to see your smiling face (or scowling face, but we'll leave that up to you!)

Thank you in advance for your investment of love and support through this process! 

You guys are the best!

story:
Be A Part of An Indianapolis Premiere!

Many people have dreamed about being able to produce the cult musical of CARRIE ever since it's premature closing on Broadway in 1988.  Then, 25 years later, the musical's authors (Michael Gore, Dean Pitchford, and Lawrence D. Cohen) took their favorite telekinetic teen out of hiding, dusted her off, rewrote, and reworked the material in order to debut her Off-Broadway at the Lucille Lortel MCC Theatre in 2012.  This production even spawned a World Premiere cast recording!

Now, the dream of directing this musical has become a reality for Director D. Scott Robinson and his award-winning team of designers at Buck Creek Playhouse, located just southeast of downtown Indy at 11150 Southeastern Avenue.

What We Need & What You Get

Based on Stephen King's popular novel, putting the story of Carrie White on stage requires a multitude of special effects.  We are hoping to raise $1,500 to purchase or rent various pieces of equipment in order to make this (quoting from one of the songs) a "night you'll never forget."

We aren't the only ones getting something out of your donation!  Donate to our 501(c)(3), and you will not only receive a deduction on your taxes, but a lot of other cool items (depending on the amount of your gift).

The Impact

Your donation will make a tremendous impact on the arts in Indianapolis and the volunteers involved with this historical production!  The members of the production team of CARRIE: THE MUSICAL have been awarded multiple times for their work on stages throughout the greater Indianapolis area.  This production is sure to be a sure-fire hit! (Did you notice the "Carrie" fire joke there?)

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that everyone might not be able to contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!  Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Please use the Indiegogo share tools to post our efforts on your Facebook, Twitter, blogs, and other social media.

Thank you!

story:
Teatro del Aire

TEATRO DEL AIRE es una compañía independiente de teatro hispano radicada en la ciudad de New York, fundada en 2014 por el actor y director cubano George Riverón.

Su principal línea de trabajo es la producción de espectáculos teatrales en español, de autores clásicos y contemporáneos; además de investigar, desarrollar y experimentar los medios expresivos del actor y la renovación del lenguaje escénico.

TEATRO DEL AIRE busca la integración al teatro de otros géneros creativos y/o artísticos.

Somos Teatro del Aire:

  • George Riverón (actor, productor y director artístico y general de Teatro del Aire)
  • Yunier López (actor y director)
  • Sebastian Stimman (actor, bailarín, director y coreógrafo)
  • Indira Romero (actriz y directora)
  • Sandra Chaviano (producción y relaciones públicas)
Nuestras primeras producciones, fueron merecedoras de los más importantes premios teatrales para el teatro hispano, en los Estados Unidos: "Últimos días de una casa" (Premio HOLA 2015: Outstanding Solo Performance, New York./ Premio ACE 2014: Mejor Actor Visitante, New York./ Premio ATI 2014: Mejor Actor de Monólogo, New York./ Premio ATI 2014: Mejor Dirección de Monólogo, New York./ Primer Premio del Festival Monologando Ando 2013, New York.); "La Reina Virgen" (coproducción con Teatro TEBA) (Premio ACE 2015: Mejor Producción de Teatro de Época, New York./ Mejor Actor Protagónico: Raul Rivera./ Mejor Coactuación Masculina: Daniel Ojeda./ Mejor Coactuación Femenina: Rita Ortiz./ Mejor Actriz Secundaria: Kathy Tejada./ Mejor Vestuario: Antonio Reyes y George Riverón./ Mejor Iluminación: Anny Gomez. Premio ATI 2015: Mejor Director Nueva Estrella: George Riverón./ Mejor Actor Secundario: Daniel Ojeda./ Mejor Vestuario: George Riverón y Antonio Reyes.) y "La Boca" (Premio ACE 2015: Mejor Actor Unipersonal. New York./ Premio ACE 2015: Mejor Musicalización: Indira Romero. New York./ Premio ATI 2015: Mejor Actor Monólogo. New York./ Miami Hispanic Theater Awards: Actor Revelación. Miami./ IV Festival Internacional de Teatro de Pequeño Formato Miami 2014: Mejor Actor en un Rol Protagónico. Miami./ Festival Internacional de la Escena Gay Miami 2014: Mejor Actor. Miami.)

GENIOS: Lorca y Dalí, de Julie De Grandy.

Estreno mundial

Las similitudes y diferencias entre Federico García Lorca y Salvador Dalí, crean una relación intensa y tormentosa cuando se conocen de adolescentes. Relación que sobrevive al tiempo y que, esta vez, llega contada por la pluma de una de las dramaturgas cubanas del exilio más prolífica: Julie De Grandy.

Nuestra propuesta teatral, recrea el mundo onírico visual de los dos genios, estableciendo un diálogo entre la palabra, la música y la belleza visual.

Pero... necesitamos de ti

Para poder llevar a cabo la realización de nuestra producción, necesitamos de tu apoyo. 

Nosotros contamos con el talento necesario para realizarla y ya estamos en la recta final del montaje y ensayos. Pero sin tu apoyo, no nos será posible tenerla lista para el estreno, pautado para el 19 de junio, dentro de la programación del V Festival de Teatro Hispano del Comisionado Dominicano de Cultura en Nueva York. 

Dentro del Festival, tendremos una única presentación y luego programaremos una temporada en Nueva York y Miami, respectivamente. Además de llevarla a diferentes festivales y plazas teatrales de Latinoamérica.

Necesitamos de tu apoyo para poder cubrir los gastos de producción de la puesta (vestuario, escenografía, publicidad, renta de la sala donde haremos temporada, etc), además de los boletos y hospedaje para poder llevarla a Miami y Bogotá, Colombia (donde hemos sido invitados al Festival de Teatro Rosa), entre otros países.

¿Nuestra meta?: $4000. Si logramos alcanzarla, les estaríamos inmensamente agradecidos. Si la superamos, se multiplicarían nuestras fuerzas y deseos de seguir haciendo Teatro.

Hacemos Teatro porque lo amamos y no podemos vivir sin hacerlo.

story:
Hi everyone! 


Thank you so much for coming to my page! As you may or may not know, I have been spending the last few years working on getting my Bachelor of Fine Arts in Theatre from the University of Arkansas. I have developed an extreme passion for live performance and I have been working as hard as I possibly can to learn the skills necessary to be a part of professional performances. I have been focusing mainly on acting, directing, and stage management but have done everything from working on costumes to lighting designs. This summer I am happy to announce that I will be taking a huge step toward my goal as I will be putting on my first professional production. I will be directing, casting, and co-designing a comedy/drama called Nothing is the End of the World  by Bekah Brunstetter. 


In order for our show to take place, it will take a decent amount of financial backing. Here are just a few of the things that I will have to raise money for in order to make this production a reality...


1. Performance and Script Fee- In order to put on a show, I must pay the playwright royalties for every single night that we have an audience view the performance. I also have to pay her and her publishing company for the scripts for the actors, myself, the designers, and the stage manager.

2. Actor's Wages- It is very difficult to get good actors to be a part of a show if you are unable to pay them well. Obviously it is very tough to have a good show without strong actors. I will have a cast of 8 for this show and the more funds I raise, the more they get for their time and work. We will have a four week rehearsal period and actors will be called almost every day for as long as four and a half hours until the opening night. This is a huge time commitment and it is essential that I raise enough money to make it worth their while.

3. Costumes- Having good costumes is vital to helping an actor develop his/her character. It is also very distracting to the audience when the costume do not fit the show or actors on stage. 

4. Props- Certain props are non-negotiable for allowing the action on stage make sense. Most of these will have to be purchased. 

5. Space Rental- Although I will do my best to reserve the rehearsal and performance spaces for free, this may not be an option.

6. Crew Wages- The crew of this show will be minimal but imperative. I will have a sound designer/engineer, lighting designer, costume designer, make-up designer, and master electrician. I will also have a stage manager that will be with me at every rehearsal handling everything from note taking my direction and stage movement to calling the light and sound cues during the performances. 

7. Playbills (programs)- These will give the audience members the actor's and crew's bios as well as recognition to supporting patrons.


These are just a few of the many expenses that I will have for this show. I have budgeted everything and come to the conclusion that I will be able to put on the show effectively if I raise $2,500. Although I hope to raise more, this is the minimum that I need in order to pay my actors and crew appropriately. Everything that I raise additionally will go directly to the cast and crew and will help us to put on an even better show.


By donating to this project you will receive recognition in our playbill that every audience member will receive upon entering the theatre. If you would like to donate under a company name then the company will be listed with their logo as an official sponsor in our Playbill and on every advertisement and poster that is put up all over the cities of Fayetteville, Springdale and Rogers. In addition to this you will receive my personal gratitude and have the satisfaction of knowing that you are the reason for one of my dreams and life goals coming true.


Thank you so much for reading and donating to this project! I cannot wait to get started on it and I hope to see every one of you very soon to give my personal thank you and to let you know how it all goes!

story:
Suits for Success, Inc. (SFS) is a non-profit organization registered as a 501(c)(3) whose mission is to empower individuals on their journey toward self-sufficiency through professional development services.

121- 125 Newark Ave., 3rd Floor

Jersey City, NJ 07302

T: 201-395-0202 F: 201-395-0005

Marilynm@suitsforsuccessinc.org

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise money by holding a Zumba Wellness Event on Saturday February 28th, 2015 from 10:00 am - 12:00 pm, at the Mary Bethune Community Center - 140 Martin Luther King Drive Jersey City, NJ.  If you cannot make it that is ok Please feel free to be one of our virtual sponsors!!!!!!! Feel free to donate as much as you feel fit.  We really appreciate your support!!!  
We are in desperate need of general operating funds and so much more!  Here at Suits for Success Inc.  We suit well over 2, 000 individuals each year and continue to provide valuable pre and post employment services even after the suiting.  We help so many people be able to feel confident enough to go in and interview for whichever job they would like.  In a time when so many people need help we are here to empower, support and strengthen our clients.  Please help us in our mission to continue to guide individuals on their journey towards professional development. 

Risks & Challenges

Although we receive some government funding, times are very tough and non profits often struggle to stay afloat.  We are still here serving our community and we would like to be able to provide even more services to those whom may be in need.  Our efforts continue to reach higher and even greater heights and we would like to stay right here so that we can serve even more people in need.  We are all about focusing on strengths and increasing our clients' self esteem and confidence levels. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

     You can volunteer your time and come in and help us !

T: 201-395-0202 F: 201-395-0005
Marilynm@suitsforsuccessinc.org 
  What We Need & What You GetWe are trying to raise money by holding a Zumba Wellness Event on Saturday February 28th, 2015 from 10:00 am - 12:00 pm, at the Mary Bethune Community Center - 140 Martin Luther King Drive Jersey City, NJ.  If you cannot make it that is ok Please feel free to be one of our virtual sponsors!!!!!!! Feel free to donate as much as you feel fit.  We really appreciate your support!!!  We are in desperate need of general operating funds and so much more!  Here at Suits for Success Inc.  We suit well over 2, 000 individuals each year and continue to provide valuable pre and post employment services even after the suiting.  We help so many people be able to feel confident enough to go in and interview for whichever job they would like.  In a time when so many people need help we are here to empower, support and strengthen our clients.  Please help us in our mission to continue to guide individuals on their journey towards professional development.     Risks & Challenges
Although we receive some government funding, times are very tough and non profits often struggle to stay afloat.  We are still here serving our community and we would like to be able to provide even more services to those whom may be in need.  Our efforts continue to reach higher and even greater heights and we would like to stay right here so that we can serve even more people in need.  We are all about focusing on strengths and increasing our clients' self esteem and confidence levels.      Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  You can volunteer your time and come in and help us !

story:
The Other Theatre Company is excited to announce its production of Anna Deavere Smith’s Twilight: Los Angeles, 1992

We are a 501(c)3 not-for-profit theatre company in Chicago dedicated to telling stories about othered populations and their allies. Our inaugural season opens with this powerful play about race in the United States.

In 1991, four white police officers brutally beat Rodney King, a black man, at the end of a high-speed chase in Los Angeles. In 1992, those same officers were acquitted of the beating, despite damning video evidence witnessed around the world. Outrage and chaos followed. 

A solo performance transformed into a play for multiple actors, Twilight captures fragments of this especially volatile moment in 20th century US race politics. Some referred to the direct aftermath of the acquittal as the LA riots. Others challenged that mainstream name for the explosive events, calling them rebellions, uprisings, or disturbances. Each name imagined a different story with different stakes. The LA uprisings became a flashpoint for conflicting perceptions of relationships between race, ethnicity, class, power, violence, and resistance—both in LA and the US as a whole. The play’s vivid verbatim dialogue introduces us to many people Smith met while conducting interviews about the uprisings.

But why flash back to 1992 Los Angeles in 2015 Chicago? The Other Theatre Company wants to revisit Smith’s riveting play now, in what many US activists have called “The Ferguson Moment.” The passionate protests against the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson have drawn much-needed (though still not enough) attention to the injustice bodies of color have often suffered at the hands of law enforcement. While the events of Ferguson 2014 and Los Angeles 1992 are not the same, considering them together allows us to analyze systems of injustice as we make connections across time and space. In both LA and Ferguson, what outsiders might have perceived as relatively isolated events were actually the result of old, entrenched systems of power and privilege. Twilight is ready for a dialogue with The Ferguson Moment and for a dialogue with the realities of Chicago and so many other locations here and abroad, past and present. 

In the Chicago of today, our questions are many, and Twilight helps us ask them. How can we as citizens respond to the reality that not everyone has the luxury of viewing the police as protectors? How do people react when they feel like their lives don’t matter? How do people make sense of violence they witness firsthand? How do we elevate the news sources that center marginalized voices? How do we make connections across moments without erasing the differences between them? How can we force systemic change where change is so urgently needed? 

Join The Other Theatre Company in January and February for a moving meditation on identity, power, and perception that’s as relevant today as it was more than two decades ago.

The Other Theatre Company needs your help! Every dollar raised will go toward the following:

Paying our director, stage manager, actors, designers, and technicians

Buying materials for our set, and construction costs

Rent for our space at the Chopin Theater in Chicago

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some of you might not be in a position to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools! Send our link to everyone you know!

Thank you for helping The Other Theatre Company make our world a better, more just place to live in!

story:
Scorrere per Italiano:

Who are we?

Open FLR was born in 2013 out of the passion and creative output of a group of professional dance practitioners, each of which honed their skills and nurtured their careers abroad. From this enthusiasm this association creates contemporary dance workshops, choreographic seminars and performative events in Florence (Italy).

In an attempt to respond to the lack of professional opportunities for local dance artists, OpenFLR laid the foundations for a long-term project as an exchange platform in which European contemporary dancers can interact and exchange skills with recent graduates and young Italian professionals.

What is the project?

The series of activities held in 2013 and 2014 encountered a fertile ground for development and exchange. Open FLR hosted over 60 teachers, dancers, and choreographers from different countries and areas of the contemporary dance world, culminating in a Summer Choreographic Intensive held in July 2014 that presented and premiered three brand new commissions by Natalia Horecna, Edan Gorlicki and Riccardo Meneghini.

Participants and organizers agreed on the strong potential of this event and therefore want to invest in a new edition for 2015.

As such, the aim of OpenFLR is to offer an educational professional opportunity, with high professional standards, for a very accessible cost.

Participants will spend fourteen days together in a dance lab led by three internationally acclaimed choreographers Joeri Dubbe, Keren Rosenberg and David Hernandez.  The first two days will consist of technique classes and workshops to allow the dancers to meet the choreographers and vice versa. On the third day the participants will be divided in three different groups and start a new creative process with one of the choreographers. 

Every day will start with a technique class (either Gaga or Countertechnique®) open to participants and other professional dancers.

Open FLR will provide the space for each choreographer to experiment and investigate their practice. By working with the dancers five hours a day, they will create a work in progress to be presented at the end of the Intensive. This will be a fantastic opportunity for young professionals to experience and dive into a choreographic process, to learn different practices, to be creative and collaborate with established choreographers. A brief but unique professional experience!

Why should you support it?

In our present economic and historical context it has become increasingly hard to foster educational and personal growth as an artist. A professional dancer is usually obliged to use their own funds to travel abroad to find work or take part in auditions. To dance professionally requires constant training to maintain mental and physical stamina and alertness, to be prepared for opportunities as they arise, and therefore a deep knowledge of our bodies and an ability to remain current with the trends, styles, and forms of an ever-changing discipline is essential for success.

The participants (Italian and international) demonstrated great interest and enthusiasm for the activities organized by OpenFLR. Many of those present felt eager to contribute their own knowledge and experience creating a new network that transcends the traditional networks of the contemporary dance scene.

With your support Open FLR would be able to expand our reach to make this experience open to any dancers no matter their back rounds or stage in career development. The presence of more diverse group will enrich the experience for everyone supporting their practice, travels and accommodation in Florence.

‘The organisers of OpenFLR took their passion and tried to disseminate their sense of generosity throughout the participants. They were very open and available and created an amazing platform for people from different countries to meet and come together to share their dance knowledge in a spirit of collaboration that is not limited by economic of social conditions. It has been an unforgettable and precious journey for me, I feel richer as a dancer and as a person. Two weeks away from home travelling alone from Hong Kong to Europe for the first time has been a very important moment in my life, a turning point’

by Vivian Luk Wai (OpenFLR participants and student of the Academy of Performing Arts Hong Kong)


Chi Siamo?

Open FLR nasce nel 2013 dalla passione e forza creativa di un gruppo di danzatori professionisti, ognuno dei quali forma e sviluppa le proprie abilità tecniche e artistiche all’estero. Con questo entusiasmo l’associazione comincia a creare seminari di danza contemporanea, laboratori coreografici e spettacoli di vario genere a Firenze (Italia).

Per rispondere alle scarse opportunità professionali offerte ai danzatori locali, OpenFLR pone le fondamenta per un progetto a lungo termine creando una piattaforma di scambio in cui studenti e professionisti italiani abbiano l’opportunità di interagire e scambiare competenze con professionisti della scena europea.

Che cos’è il progetto?

La seria di attività tenutesi nel 2013 e 2014 ha trovato un terreno molto fertile e curioso allo sviluppo e scambio formativo e professionale. Durante questo periodo, Open FLR ha ospitato oltre 60 persone fra insegnati, studenti coreografi provenienti da paesi e aree della danza contemporanea molto differenti, culminando con un Laboratorio coreografico estivo nel Luglio 2014 che ha presentato 3 commissioni inedite create da Natalia Horecna, Edan Gorlicki e Riccardo Meneghini.

Gli organizzatori e partecipanti concordano sull’enorme potenziale di questo progetto e perciò sulla necessità e voglia nel proseguimento delle attività nel 2015.

L’obiettivo di OpenFLR sarà offrire un’opportunità professionale e formativa di alto livello ad un costo accessibile.

I partecipanti passeranno insieme 14 giorni (6-19 Luglio 2015) in un laboratorio coreografico condotto da tre coreografi di fama internazionale Joeri Dubbe, Keren Rosenberg e David Hernandez. Durante i primi due giorni i coreografi condurranno dei brevi workshop per conoscere i partecipanti e viceversa. Il terzo giorno i partecipanti saranno divisi in tre gruppi per iniziare il processo creativo con uno dei coreografi. 

Ogni giorno inizierà con classi tecniche (Gaga e Countertechnique®) aperte anche a professionisti.

OpenFLR offrirà uno spazio, fisico e creativo, ad ogni coreografo per sperimentare e investigare il proprio lavoro. Collaborando con i danzatori per cinque ore al giorno, creeranno un lavoro in progress che sarà presentato alla fine del laboratorio.

OpenFLR costruisce così una fantastica opportunità, diretta a studenti e giovani professionisti, per partecipare, esplorare e sperimentare in un processo coreografico, per imparare e riconoscere differenti metodologie, per essere creativi e collaborare con coreografi riconosciuti nel mondo della danza contemporanea europea. Una breve ma unica esperienza professionale!

Perché sostenere iI progetto?

Il momento storico ed economico attuale non favorisce purtroppo la formazione e crescita personale di un danzatore. Oggi un professionista della danza è obbligato a viaggiare spesso a proprie spese per trovare occupazione, prendere parte ad audizioni e formarsi. Questa professione richiede un constante e continuo training, per essere pronti ad ogni situazione, per avere una conoscenza approfondita del proprio corpo e una flessibilità e apertura artistica al passo con i tempi, data la disciplina che evolve continuamente; l’aggiornamento e versatilità diventano perciò competenze fondamentali per un successo professionale.

I partecipanti dell’edizione precedente, Italiani ed internazionali, hanno dimostrato grande entusiasmo ed interesse per le attività organizzate da Open FLR. La maggior parte dei presenti è riuscita a contribuire appassionatamente con le proprie esperienze e competenze creando una rete di scambio profonda che va ben oltre una semplice rete di contatti.

Con il vostro sostegno Open FLR potrà aprirsi e raggiungere un maggior numero di partecipanti, indipendentemente dalla loro origine, estrazione sociale e livello professionale. Potremo offrire ai partecipanti un supporto economico per sostenere le spese del viaggio e alloggio che faciliteranno la presenza di un gruppo multiculturale e con diverse competenze professionali. Il vostro contributo renderà l’esperienza più ricca e stimolante per i partecipanti come danzatori, artisti e cittadini europei.

‘Gli organizzatori di OpenFLR hanno utilizzato la loro passione condividendola generosamente fra I partecipanti. Si sono dimostrati aperti e disponibili e hanno creato un’incredibile piattaforma per partecipanti di diversi paesi ad incontrarsi e condividere la loro esperienza e conoscenza in uno spirito di collaborazione non limitato da condizioni sociali o economiche. Per me è stato un percorso incredibile ed indimenticabile, mi sono arricchita come danzatrice e persona. Due settimane lontane da casa viaggiando da sola per la prima volta da Hong Kong all’Europa è stato un momento molto importante nella mia vita, un momento cruciale.’

Di Vivian Luk Wai (partecipante di Open FLR e student dell’Accademie di Arti Performative di Hong Kong)

story:
UPDATE (3/24/15)!

Hey everyone – THANK YOU for your support through the first months of Cycle 3.  So far, we’ve thrown a JAMBOREE featuring all the artists of the Cycle and workshopped Emily Kaplan’s new play, Stan, at Dixon Place – check out the trailer and some pictures from the performance in the gallery section. 

And the crazy part is… we’re just getting started! There’s more theater just around the corner!

                 

Tickets to this weekend showcase of two new projects are COMPLETELY FREE – so if you are planning on attending (the RSVP link is coming soon – hold your horses!), please consider making a donation here in lieu of a ticket purchase as a way of supporting their work.  There are some cool perks and fun ways of interacting with our artists, too!

Allow us to introduce ourselves...

We’re The Brewing Dept., a group of 20-something theater-makers (actors, composers, clowns designers, devisers, directors, dramaturges, playwrights) who’ve been making a meaningful impact on the way theater’s made in our home town, New York City.  We’ve promoted emerging artists, committed to and delivered long-term (multi-year!) creative and financial support in development of their work, and fostered a community that enables exploration, creativity, and artistic sustainability.

This year is going to be very, very different:

Two years of successfully working in this way has brought TBD to the brink of a radically new era in its programming.  For the first time in our history, we have a wealth of work refined by a long-term process and ready to be fully produced AND a wealth of crazy-talented artists with projects that need and deserve TBD’s developmental process.

We're asking for your help to raise the $8,000 needed to cover the costs of originating, developing, and showcasing the six new pieces of theater (six!) that make up the backbone of our programming this spring.

Why these projects?

Because we’re passionate about the artists behind them.  

TBD’s long-term commitment to developing new pieces of theater means that we’re open to – and almost expecting – the nature of those pieces to radically change over their life with us.  So when TBD takes on a project, what we’re really doing is committing to an artist in pursuit of something they care deeply about.  The artist’s passion for their project makes us passionate about enabling its creation.  

TBD was created out of a passion for theater-making; we seek (and have been sought out by) fellow artists as passionate about their work as we are.

The new work of Cycle 3:

Expense breakdown:

For the development side of our work this year, here's how our $8,000 are divided:


Coming soon to Cycle 3...

Later in Cycle 3, The Brewing Dept. will continue its work on projects begun during Cycle 2, producing fully realized visions of HamletGhosts, created by Cody Holliday Haefner, and Othello, edited and directed by Thomas Kapusta and featuring Jenny Vallancourt.

developmental process.We're asking for your help to raise the $8,000 needed to cover the costs of originating, developing, and showcasing the six new pieces of theater (six!) that make up the backbone of our programming this spring.Why these projects?
Because we’re passionate about the artists behind them.  
TBD’s long-term commitment to
developing new pieces of theater means that we’re open to – and almost expecting – the nature of those pieces
to radically change over their life with us. 
So when TBD takes on a project, what we’re really doing is committing to
an artist in pursuit of something they care deeply about.  The artist’s passion for their project makes
us passionate about enabling its creation.  
TBD was created out of a passion for theater-making; we seek (and have
been sought out by) fellow artists as passionate about their work as we are.

The new work of Cycle 3:

Expense breakdown:

For the development side of our work this year, here's how our $8,000 are divided:





Coming soon to Cycle 3...
Later in Cycle 3, The Brewing Dept. will continue its work on projects begun during Cycle 2, producing fully realized visions of HamletGhosts, created by Cody Holliday Haefner, and Othello, edited and directed by Thomas Kapusta and featuring Jenny Vallancourt.

story:
What’s the Deal?

Brandon and Shirley desperately want to reconnect, but when he asks her for "mammary intercourse" things quickly go awry in this bawdy farce about lovers, friends and the misplaced faith we can have in them. 

Looking for Fun(Bags) is coming to you from Up Top Theatre Company at the Minnesota Fringe Festival, the largest non-juried fringe fest and the third largest fringe fest in the USA.

Up Top Theatre, meanwhile, is a collective formed by some close friends who met at the Commonweal Theatre Company in little ol’ Lanesboro, Minnesota. Now in the big bad Twin Cities, we want to create theatre that speaks to our generation- the good, the bad, and the ugly.

This campaign is to raise some funds to do just that. This will be the premiere of a play two years in the making: from living room read-throughs to public readings and numerous workshops, Looking for Fun(Bags) is finally receiving its first fully staged production!

However, we need YOUR help in making it happen! We care about what theatre should be able to achieve and we appreciate that it takes a little bit of money to make it happen. Together we can say something to the people and shed light on our 21stcentury world!

What We Need & What You Get

What we are asking for is $1000, which in the grand world of theatre, is a spit in the bucket. Where would it be going, you ask?

  •  $350 will go towards the rental of the performance space and all the registration/ application fees for the Minnesota Fringe Festival.
  • $300 will be reserved for the marketing of the show and that includes printing the programs, posters and postcards.
  • $100 will go towards the set and props. There’s a lot of food in this show- exploding beer cans and fortune cookies galore!
  • $170 for miscellaneous bumps along the way. 
  • $80 for driving reimbursements. 

Now to the fun part- your perks! Depending on what you share, perks include fortunes from a cookie, a signed prop from the show, and even a dinner date with the creative team!

Now what happens if we don’t reach our ENTIRE goal? Well, the show must go on and we will have to still pay for the associated fees AT LEAST.

The Impact

  • Looking for Fun(Bags) is one of those plays that gives us a seemingly surface story, but is full of heart and morality. Laced with sexual politics and the tricky waters we as young people often have difficulty navigating in our hook-up, bootylicius culture; the plays asks what if the guy doesn’t get the girl and what if the girl refuses to play into some lurid immature male fantasy?
  • Fortunately, Up Top Theatre has some experience in bringing projects like this to the stage. Co-producer, Vincent Hannam, has successfully helped launch projects such as Sharknami: The Musical? at the Orlando Fringe Festival and the short film, The Fool, featured at the New Filmmakers Festival in NYC. In fact, Looking for Fun(Bags) had its own staged workshop at the Bad Theater Festival in NYC.
  • Up Top Theatre knows what it takes to make good theatre and we promise that you will see nothing short of our best efforts. We humbly ask you for your support.

Risks & Challenges

  • Risks involved in this fundraiser are those inherent in all fundraising. What if we don’t reach our goal? All we can say is that we’re good at adapting and the show will go on; but it won’t be the show we have set out to present to you.
  • A challenge that might arise is the fact that we are but one show in a festival laden with equally worthy productions. That means there’s going to be a lot of fundraising happening and we have to work our tails off for just a little slice of that pie.

Fortunately, as stated before, Up Top Theatre is not new to this game and we have a strategic plan of attack to set us apart.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • First off, we have to thank you enormously for your time and if, after all this, you want to help but simply don’t have the means (hey, we’re artists- we get it) then you can still help us out by:
  1. Getting the word out and making some noise about our campaign!
  2. Come to the Minnesota Fringe Festival July 30th- August 9th, take a seat and enjoy Looking for Fun(Bags)!
