story:
"The best thing about Pittsburgh is that you can make an idea happen, no matter how weird it is" -- unattributed

What is the Lovelace Puppet Festival?

This outdoor puppet festival in a plant nursery celebrates the legacy of puppeteer Margo Lovelace and supports local artists. Last year the festival featured unique and unexpected performances from 7 incredible troupes. The captivating atmosphere that the artists created using original, handmade puppets is unlike any performance you have seen before. The 2nd annual Lovelace Puppet Festival will be even better, with more performances, a broader audience and even more puppets!

The event will be held at Weather Permitting, 510 Maryland Avenue, Shadyside from 5 - 9p on Sunday July 19th. Come enjoy the imaginative artwork of Pittsburgh's gifted and outlandish puppeteers. These artists are a part of the artistic fabric of our city. This event can only exist in Pittsburgh. 

...BUT we need your help to give them the support they deserve and make this event happen. CHIP IN PITTSBURGH!

This is about the performers

Every dollar donated goes directly back into paying the puppeteers and operational costs. The more generously you give, the better we can make the event. We want the biggest, most extravagant and exciting shows imaginable in this year's Lovelace Puppet Festival. If we reach our goal that money can be directly invested in helping our performers make the best puppets you have ever seen. 

  • Puppeteers' Fees
  • Puppetry Workshop
  • Promotions
  • Production
  • Post-event Cleanup (trash bags, cleaning supplies etc)

Get to Know the Performers!

4th Wall Puppets
Cargaux of Puppets
Cheryl Capezzuti
Giant Puppet Dance Club
Light Bright Beautiful Puppetry
Miko Miko
Mugwort Forest
Puppets in Performance 
Small St. Acro Bats (From the makers of Teleportaterz! the Musical)
The Sunset Experiment 

No one does puppets like Pittsburgh 

Every time we host this event, we get more interest from local artists and learn more about the community of brilliant puppeteers that exists in our city.  This event creates visibility for these artists and gives you access to their work. Let's face it, when else do you get to see a puppet show in a plant nursery? 

These artists are continuing a tradition of eloquent puppet theater that was pioneered by Margo Lovelace and her contemporaries. When you donate to this campaign you make sure that locals get payed for their great ideas. You are supporting a community of puppeteers that is unique to Pittsburgh. Thank you!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you can’t contribute financially that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Offer to volunteer!
  • Bring a puppet to the event!
  • Join the Facebook event, come out on July 19th, and have a great time!

Why the Lovelace Puppet Festival Now?

We're doing this for Margo. She is an incredible woman with an astonishing capacity to love. Her contribution to the city of Pittsburgh can still be seen today in the fond memories of all those she touched with her work. To this day she is as imaginative, caring and genuinely lovely as ever. 

In 1964 Margo Lovelace bought 5888 1/2 Ellsworth and renovated it to make the Lovelace Marionette Theater. Out of these humble beginnings, Margo created a unique theatrical experience that is a treasured memory for anyone who grew up attending Lovelace Puppet shows. From the 60’s to now the 5800 block of Ellsworth has changed significantly from the street lined with abandoned buildings that Margo moved into. The theater was an integral part of the neighborhood’s development, until The Lovelace Theater’s puppet collection was donated to the Pittsburgh Children’s Museum in 1985.

Margo drew people to the area and shared with them the “Magic of Puppetry.” Believing that people are “starved for beautiful fantasies, but afraid to admit it,” she offered this missing dose of whimsy to anyone who came to her productions.

Ironically the intimate characteristics that made Margo’s theater so important to its patrons also made it forgettable. Margo's productions were never televised, and her playbills were handmade for each performance. The Magic existed in fleeting breathtaking moments archived only in the hearts of the audience. Without a paper trail, the Lovelace Theater's story has not been shared with 2015 Pittsburgh.

And thanks to you it will be...

story:
Hello from the hearts and minds that make up the Nesting Cast and Crew! 

We are an independent group of theatre artists in Portland, OR. Our goal is to create something authentic, innovative, scary, immersive, and entertaining. Nesting stemmed from a desire not only to experiment in the art of theatre, but also to explore the nature of fear.  Fear is a universal experience that can motivate us or cripple us; we're interested in exploring the moment that exists between hearing a noise in a dark room and deciding to enter that room anyway.

Who are we?

Nesting is helmed by Joel Patrick Durham (Director/Creator) and Natalie Heikkinen (Producer/Proptress).  Nesting is collaboratively being written by David Bellis-Squires, Alwynn Accuardi, and Joel. There are our amazing performers Alwynn Accuardi, Rose Procter, Nathan Crosby and Murri Lazaroff-Babin. Our talented production team consists of Will Gebo, Corey McCarey, Kaia Maarja Hillier, Andrew Bray, Taiga Christie, Tyler Buswell, Clara-Liis Hillier, Kathleen Kelly, and Lexie Quandt.

What is Nesting?

Nesting is a story which follows and explores the fears of three friends who move into a house in Portland together. Their new home (and new housemates) begin to influence their everyday lives, making their worst fears manifest and playing on their deepest guilty secrets. What's really going on in this house, and who's responsible?

One of the unique aspects of Nesting is that the story takes place over 2 nights of theatre. We will be performing Episodes 1 & 2 for half of our showtimes and Episode 3 & 4 for the other half; catch the first and second episodes on the same night, then come back tomorrow (or the next week) for the thrilling conclusion. Those who love to binge-watch Netflix can get their live theatre fix.

Nesting will be presented at the extremely intimate Shoebox Theatre (2110 SE 10th Ave, Portland, OR 97214), opening March 4th 2016, and will run until March 26th.

As a semi-improvised show (the main plot line is scripted but the actors discover and create dialogue), Nesting will be a different experience for each performance. That means new jokes, new stories, and new ways of unraveling the mystery might appear each show!  We want to thrill you and leave you asking juicy questions, but we need your help to make this happen!

What We Need & What You Get

Have we piqued your fancy? Do you want to help? Awesome!  Here's the situation:

Since we're an independent production, all money that we raise goes directly to the people and materials we need to make this show incredible!  We're looking at the cost of renting a theater for rehearsals and performances; paying our designers, director, actors and writers; and we're in need of set, costumes, and prop materials.  We have the optimism and the passion, but we knew we would need to reach out and ask for help from the community.

We've applied for the RACC Project Grant (fingers crossed!) and we have some very wonderful friends who have agreed to sponsor certain budget items.  However, in order to make this production what it really deserves to be, we need a bit more help!

So we've set our Indiegogo goal at $5,000!  Can you help us reach it in 30 days?

Whether you spread the word by posting to your FacePage or donate a little cash, ANY help you can give is super valuable.

If you have room in your budget to donate some funds, anything from $1 up will result in your name listed on our website as well as on display in the lobby of the theatre, and grant access to behind-the-scenes photos and videos!

If you can spare a little more, we have some fun perk packages to show our gratitude.  Here is a little sampling.

Donating $15 will get you your choice of a digital download of The Nesting Theme composed by Andrew Bray, OR a waterphone text alert download.

Donating $25 will get you the full mobile package! A download of a waterphone text alert, The Nesting Theme ringtone, AND a high quality Nesting background image for your mobile device.

Donating $85 will get you a glossy 8x10 promo photo print photographed by Kathleen Kelly (KKelly Photography). (Here are some ideas and inspirations for our shoot)

Donating $100 will get you a “WHAT’S IN THE BOX!?” Mystery Package, personally curated and assembled by members of the "Nesting" Cast & Crew. Every box is unique! What will be in yours?

Donating $300 will get you a Mystery Package, personally curated and assembled by the "Nesting" Cast & Crew, a glossy 8x10 promo photo print photographed by Kathleen Kelly (KKelly Photography), 2 opening weekend tickets and a download of the "Nesting" Theme by Andrew Bray.

Donating $500 will get you an invite to view one of the many films that helped inspire "Nesting", with the cast and crew. Snacks and beverages provided! (Only 5 available)

OR

Donating $500 will get you an invite to a private evening of Karaoke with the Nesting Cast and Crew. Snacks and beverages provided! (Only 5 available)

Donating $1000 will get you an original 11x14" acrylic painting on canvas, inspired by your favorite horror story, be it movie, book, tv show, or urban legend, done by Natalie Heikkinen! (Only 5 available - Here's a sample of her work)

Donating $2500 will get you...?  So mysterious, that even the perk description is a mystery! We'll have to chat about this. We're on the edge of our seat with this one!

The Impact

We want to thrill you, but we also want to keep innovating. We believe theatre should be accessible to everyone and entertaining as hell!  We want to continue to create entertainment that's fun to watch and fun to make.  There are hundreds of young, talented artists in Portland, OR who are looking for opportunities to exercise their creativity; when the opportunities can't be found, we believe in creating them!  We are so excited and thankful for our production team that is willing to dive into this project. These are passionate, local, energized and professional theatre artists who do what they do because they want to make unique, authentic theatre that resonates with a younger audience. We care about our community and we care about you.  Feel free to come to the show and let us know what you think and what you want to see in the future!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Share this campaign! Share our Facebook event! Come to the show!  Tell your friends!  Come usher for us! We're absolutely not complete without you.  If you need any more information or are interested in volunteering, contact us at Nestingpdx@gmail.com

Nesting opens on March 4th, 2016 at the Shoebox Theatre in SE Portland.

Video concept, shot and edited by Kathleen Kelly

story:
Theatre is about play. It’s about getting a group of people together and tapping into our child-like desire to create—to try new things and see what works and what doesn’t. For this reason and more, we decided to supplement our education in the Department of Theatre and Dance at the University of Texas by putting what we have learned in the classroom to practice and producing a play ourselves.

So we have gathered a small group of cohorts to play with us and put on this show! In Gruesome Playground Injuries, Rajiv Joseph takes us on an intriguing thirty-year journey of friendship, nostalgia, attachment, love, pain and maybe a little healing. Ultimately, the play shows us snapshots of Doug and Kayleen’s (Dougleen’s) friendship as their lives collide time and time again in surprising and often destructive ways, leaving them to investigate both their emotional and physical scars.

One of our goals in embarking on this project is to put on this play limiting ourselves to use only what we had immediately on hand, in our own homes or things we could borrow. This can be seen as both a practical means of keeping a low budget but also as an artistic challenge and a means to investigate our own memories and scars. Ultimately, Kayleen and Doug represent all of us as human beings. We hope this project to be a way for all of us—creative team, cast and audience—to learn more about ourselves. To investigate the ways we have injured or been injured as well as the way theatre works in our lives as either artists or consumers. Hopefully we will all end up better at the end of it!

If any of this interests or speaks to you and you feel so moved, please help support our project by giving whatever you can! At the very least, we hope you will join us in Austin and partake in this experience with us! Our performance dates will be May 5 & 6 in the Winship Drama Building on the UT campus. Thank you for your support and feel free to spread our project to your friends and families!


This production was created by a collaboration with these artists: Addie Arnold, Will Douglas, Kelley Henry, Gage Robinson & Kylie Zeko

Video credit to ABM PHOTOGRAPHY

story:
After 5 sold out shows in 2013, Solskrit returns with Roarrr - a Bollywood experience where live theater meets digital entertainment. 


Performing 5 shows at the Mexican Heritage Plaza, San Jose, CA from March 7th, 8th & 9th - March 9th, 2014


Plot

Roarrr a fantasy fiction musical takes place in a far away Land called Kavasa, a land that guarded a sword which unfolds a great power. The “Sword of Lighting” was hidden in a tower outside the Palace of the King. The sword had the power to turn any human into an immortal being and the kings of Kavasa were chosen to remain the protector of the sword.

The Evil ones waited with greed, to lay their hands upon this great power, but the nearer they came, the farther it went. The warriors of Kavasa were taught never to retreat, never to surrender, and always to give their last breath defending the sword. Will Evil possess the land and attain its power? Will the King be able to defend and protect Kavasa, against the natures of Evil?

Risks and challenges

We need your Support

“All our dreams can come true, if we have the courage to pursue them.”- W Disney
Over the last 10 years, I have nurtured a very definite vision of how Indian Musical Theater should take its place in the bright lights of Broadway, without any compromise in the quality of production or experience. And now, along with the Solskrit Core Team we are ready to present the next step in our plan, and we would like to invite you to come along for the ride!! Announcing the next level of production: Roarrr! A King Lost in Time, coming to you in March 2014.

I have been very fortunate in the support we have received over the last few years from our team. We were also very lucky in the financial investment of our enthusiasts last year, Thank you so much for believing in us!

This past year has been spent on hours of research and planning, because we wanted to fulfill the promises made. We hope to further our dream of creating a visually stunning Bollywood musical where live theater meets digital entertainment. A high end production, which will showcase a three dimensional world, an amalgamation of high definition 3D spaces, Interactive Animation & Visual Effects, lavish detailed artwork, exquisite sets & costumes.

Solskrit needs funds to pay for the artists and computer engineers creating the detailed and interactive set designs. The company needs to pay talented designers and tailors to incorporate Indian fabrics and textiles into costumes ready for American fantasy.

Each contribution helps us bring the production closer to the high quality that Indian Musicals deserve.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read our story. And please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any questions about the project.
 
You can help us by supporting this campaign. Any amount is a good amount!!! You can also help us by sharing this page!

Thank you everyone for being with me until here.

Support will cover the following Costs

To bring this larger than life Bollywood Musical production to the Bay area and to give it a Broadway feel this year we are taking it a notch up by having more than 150 LED screens and custom built movable sets. The musical will have more than 120 performers and backstage workers. All the money we raise will be used to produce a high quality digital Broadway experience that will involve

  • Solskrit needs funds to pay for the artists and computer engineers creating the detailed and interactive set designs.
  • The company needs to pay talented designers and tailors to incorporate Indian fabrics and textiles into costumes ready for American fantasy.
  • Contribution towards production costs for rehearsals, theater rental and equipment
  • Marketing initiatives.


From our photo shoots

Press and media coverage

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3N2gXHTzipU

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OZT5UvrN6Js

Covered by India west

Covered by India currents

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Like us on Facebook
  • Tell your friends about our show :)

story:
Thank you so much for considering a donation to Only Child!  Here’s more info on our project and budget:

Who We Are:

Only Child aims to expand the scope of aerial theatre and increase audience awareness of the genre. We seek to invigorate artists and audiences with our genre-bending poetic athleticism and theatrical approach to aerial arts. Only Child produces original aerial theatre and collaborates with other theatre and dance companies interested in integrating aerial into their work. www.onlychildaerialtheatre.com

ASYLUM is created in collaboration with:

Director: Nicki Miller
Assistant Director: Amanda Goble

Cast: Sloan Bradford, Nicki Miller, Kendall Rileigh, Samantha Sterman, Craig Whitehouse

Projection Photography and Design: Carrie Firestone
Music Composition: Walken Schweigart (and others)
Sound Design: Laura Sisskin-Fernandez
Costume Design: Juanita Cardenas

Production Intern: Emily Hursh
Media Intern: Ayla Weisz

The Project History:

April 2013: The idea for ASYLUM is born
July 2013: Workshop Performance of a 12 minute version of ASYLUM at Circus Warehouse in Constellation Moving Company's "Off the Air" Workshop Series
January 2014: ASYLUM receives Brooklyn Arts Council Community Arts Fund Grant
March 2014: The Muse Brooklyn signs on as ASYLUM's co-producing venue
May 2014: ASYLUM rehearsals begin

June 26, 27, 28 2014: ASYLUM full-length performances at the Muse!


ASYLUM is set in the 1970s when mass closings of psychiatric hospitals across the U.S. were underway.  Created in collaboration with the cast and designers, this show is a mix of devised theatre and aerial/circus choreography. Our source material includes Nellie Bly's 10 Days in a Madhouse, Emily Dickenson's poetry, Michael Foucault's Madness and Civilization, Bradley Lewis' essays, Christopher Payne's Asylum, Darby Penney and Peter Stastny's The Lives They Left Behind, and writings by the Icarus Project to name a few.  We've translated the knowledge we've gained through our research into an artistic conversation between projected photographs, aerial movement and voiceover to tell the story of four patients deemed unfit for society and an over-extended nurse making their way through a crumbling system.

Why Donate to us?

NYC has an abundance of plays, circus, and dance, but in combining these forms into aerial theatre we aim to add dimension to the city's rich cultural scene.  We think you will find this relatively new form visually exciting and emotionally compelling.

This project intends to shed some light on the complex issue of stigmatizing mental healthcare in the U.S. and provide insight into the personal lives of those who are in treatment.

Brooklyn Arts Council's grant covers only 15% of our project budget.  We need help to generate the rest, and that's where you come in...

On the micro level:  We need your help to cover basic production costs.

On the macro level: Your investment in this project is a demonstration of your interest in the evolution of devised aerial and acrobatic theatre.  This genre is defining itself through hours and hours of research, experimentation, play, sweat, tears, and sore muscles. The only way we can improve our process, strengthen our infrastructure, and progress this art form is if the artists involved can financially commit the time.  By donating to this show you are allowing us to use this artistic process to grow as a company, as aerial theatre makers, and as a new voice in the New York aerial community. 

Where your money goes:

Only Child strongly feels that artists should get paid for their time and creative work.  Our team is quite large, and we intend to compensate all of our collaborators with modest stipends.  Our cost breakdown is as follows:

Artist/Design Team Fees: 30%
Venue Rental: 20%
Aerial and Technical Equipment: 20%
Promotional Materials: 10%
Costume and Prop Materials: 10%
Other: 10%

Only Child is grateful to have affiliations with many wonderful and generous artists and spaces in NYC, and we are working with them to keep production costs low and production value as high as possible.  Production value helps illuminate the message of the show and enrich the artist and audience experience alike.  Please help us provide as fulfilling an event as possible!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Come to the show!
  • Spread the word and encourage others to come with you!
  • Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram (@onlychildaerial)
  • Talking about circus arts, aerial, or theatre? Tag us! We want to build the conversation about this art.

story:
"Energizing…a blindingly bright black comedy…[what makes] the unsettling and exhilarating new play from Mr. McDonagh…so gripping as theater is how narrative art becomes the play's and the character's very life blood." —NY Times. 


The Pillowman centers on a writer in an unnamed totalitarian state who is being interrogated about the gruesome content of his short stories and their similarities to a series of child murders. The result is an urgent work of theatrical bravura and an unflinching examination of the very nature and purpose of art.

WHY WE NEED YOU: Putting on theatre isn't a money making venture. We're hoping to raise around $1,000, which will cover expenses for Lights, Sound, Set, Costume and Makeup. 

WILL THE SHOW HAPPEN IF YOU DON'T HIT YOUR GOAL? Yes it will! But getting $1,000 would do wonders for our ability to fund the rest of the costs and present the best possible version of this play.

story:
We are Fujiwhara, a theater company. 

About us: Writer/Director Moze Halperin first approached Actor/Director Anna Eisley in 2013 to perform alongside him in his play Kisses From Fujiwhara, which premiered at the Catalyst Festival at Dixon Place. In it, Moze asked Anna to play a paralytic/partially mummified drag queen whose grasp on the English language is limited to one repeating song – strangely, this wasn't too unpleasant an experience, so they decided to continue working together. 

They – fine, enough, we – are proud to announce our latest project – a play that sort of takes place in an art gallery, sort of in a mall, and sort of on an invisible train-track. This play is a spin on immersive theater, wherein characters are displayed as works of art on pedestals making audience members incidental gallery goers. Up until now, all our theatrical undertakings have been scripted before rehearsal processes. For this project, however, we thought a different approach may be more beneficial. The dialogue, set in a mall, will partially be developed with the actors in actual retail setting. The script will be formulated through assorted improvised sessions. We hope to couple the resulting hyper-naturalistic dialogue with heavy physical strictures, essentially disembodying the speech. Without a visual context or gestures that help convey dialogue or make it "organic," what will the exchanges in the mall environment – where social identities can be yanked from shelves, hangers and mannequins – sound like? All of this is framed within the context of an unseen but looming, quintessentially "American" traumatic event, whose collision with the mall scene evokes an unsettling map of the shared roots of American excess and propriety. 

Our debut production will be performed at The Woods Cooperative in Ridgewood, Queens – where we both live and aspire to contribute to a burgeoning performing arts scene. Our aim, after this piece, is to continue Fujiwhara performances that, after this Indiegogo nest-egg, will be financially self-sufficient. The small funding bump we're asking for is crucial to our project – to pay for rehearsals, a week's rent at the Woods Cooperative, and to create a set resembling the interior of a gallery. We realize experimental theater is no cash cow, but it is both emotionally and intellectually sustaining for us, and entirely indispensable in this sense; hopefully what we bring to the community will reciprocate the same sense of emotional, intellectual and even comedic fulfillment. We can't do it without a little help. 

We're looking for: 

$400 for rehearsals

$700 for sets

$700 for the performance space

$300 for lighting

$200 for makeup / costumes

$200 for advertisement

We so appreciate any contribution, and fully understand if you simply don't have the funds – merely spreading word about this project is an amazing help. 


Starring:

Annie Schenzel

Ava Dweck

Alex Birnie

Julia Cavagna

Yasmeen Jawhar

Elena Vann

story:
We reached our goal!

Stretch Goal

Thank-you so much to everyone who has helped us reach our goal of $700. We are so humbled by the amount of support, financial and otherwise, this project has received so far. 
But we're not stopping yet. We still have 20 days left in our campaign-- so, we've decided to set stretch goals to help us make "Two" even better of a show.

At $850 - We can build our set!

We will have all the extra money that our set designer needs to build his vision from scratch. 
At $1,000 - We can pay our artists!
All of our production costs-- costumes, sets, and print media-- will be 100% covered, which means we will be able to pay our student artists directly from box office revenue.  

Photo by Kate Loomer 

About the Project


“Ever wondered if out there, in a faraway universe, lives another you? This haunting new work presents two dramatically different versions of one life. Set in parallel worlds, manipulated by a chorus of mysterious figures, Two blends the unsettling surreal with the familiar hyper-real. Written by local playwright Kat Taddei and directed by Colette Habel.”


Two, a new stage-play, was an exciting challenge to write for emerging playwright Kat Taddei. The first full draft of the script was completed just this spring, for a third-year workshop at the University of Victoria, under the mentorship of award-winning playwright Charles Tidler.


At the end of her spring workshop, Kat received an e-mail from Charles encouraging her to submit the script to local producer Catador Theatre, who were seeking an original play for production at the 2015 Victoria Fringe Festival. Anxiously, Kat did so... and a week later, Two was selected!


Soon, Colette Habel, a fifth-year UVic student wrapping up her double-major in Theatre and Creative Writing, was on board as Two’s director. Together, Colette and Kat were lucky to find and cast a group of talented young people just as excited as them about bringing Two to life-- a group almost entirely made up theatre students, an amazing mixpot from the Victoria Academy of Dramatic Arts, UVic’s Phoenix, and Capilano University in Vancouver.


Two balances themes of choice versus coincidence, parallels, and gender bias. Our intention with this production is to create an honest work of art that is not only aesthetically innovative, but which also stimulates conversation.



What We Need 


Producing a full-scale Fringe show isn’t cheap-- and, as a creative team made up of mostly students, we aren’t exactly rich! However, whether we reach our fundraising goal or not, the truth is that every generous donation really will help make this project the best it can be. Here is a breakdown of our basic costs:


  • $600 Festival application fee

  • Marketing Materials (Posters, business cards, etc)

  • Advertising Space (We’ve purchased a space in the Fringe program worth $200)

  • Costumes (We have an amazing cast of 8, but it does mean more people to dress!)

  • Set pieces


On top of our basic costs, we are hoping to be able to pay our amazing and devoted team of actors and designers an honorarium for all the hours of volunteer work they are lovingly pouring into this project.


Who Are We? 


CATADOR THEATRE (PRODUCER)

Catador Theatre’s mandate is Total Artistic Freedom.We work directly with innovative playwrights to produce exciting new theatre in Victoria, British Columbia. We know it’s a lot of work getting a play off the ground. That’s why we offer total artistic freedom and support to playwrights. Founded in 2014 by playwright and lawyer Laura Simons, Catador Theatre launched with a successful run of the comedy Yule Bleed in February 2015 as part of Intrepid Theatre’s YOU Show series.


KAT TADDEI (PLAYWRIGHT)

Kat is going into her fourth year at the University of Victoria, with a major in Creative Writing and a minor in Journalism. Before she had even memorized the alphabet, Kat would wander around her house “reading” aloud from her mom’s Agatha Christie novels-- really, just making up stories as she went along. Locally, her work has been presented at the Belfry Theatre’s SPARK Festival, Epiphany Theatre’s Interplay Festival, Intrepid’s YOU Show Series, and Intrepid’s brand new queer theatre festival, OUTstages. Kat also acts as Drama Editor for The Warren Undergraduate Review and writes short fiction, which has been published in This Side of West and soon-to-be in Luna Station Quarterly. 


COLETTE HABEL (DIRECTOR)

Colette is a director, playwright and sound designer pursuing a double major in Theatre and Writing at the University of Victoria. Select sound design credits include: "Enter Vodka" (Intrepid Theatre New Play Reading Series, 2015), "Lion in the Streets" (UVic Phoenix Theatre, 2015), "Unity (1918)" (Uvic Phoenix Theatre, 2014), "Picnic" (UVic Phoenix Theatre, 2013). Colette also sound designed and directed her adaptation of "Goblin Market" for UVic's Student Alternative Theatre Company (SATCo) in 2013. Most recently, Colette was the Production Designer for Theatre SKAM's "The Lab", version 2.0. In addition to writing plays, Colette has written guest blog entries for arts organizations such as Theatre SKAM and the Belfry Theatre. Up next, Colette's devised theatre piece, "SCAPE": Victoria" about life in an urban centre, will be presented in September as an Intrepid Theatre YOUShow.

SEAN BROSSARD (SET/LIGHTING DESIGNER)

EMMA WOODHOUSE (COSTUME DESIGNER)


Show Dates & Times: 

August 29th - 8:30pm

August 31rst - 6:30pm

Sept. 2nd - 8:15 pm

Sept. 3rd - 10:15 pm

Sept. 5th - 10:45 pm

Sept. 6th - 4:00 pm
story_txt:
We reached our goal!Stretch GoalThank-you so much to everyone who has helped us reach our goal of $700. We are so humbled by the amount of support, financial and otherwise, this project has received so far. But we're not stopping yet. We still have 20 days left in our campaign-- so, we've decided to set stretch goals to help us make "Two" even better of a show.At $850 - We can build our set!We will have all the extra money that our set designer needs to build his vision from scratch. At $1,000 - We can pay our artists!All of our production costs-- costumes, sets, and print media-- will be 100% covered, which means we will be able to pay our student artists directly from box office revenue.  

Photo by Kate Loomer 
About the Project“Ever wondered if out there, in a faraway universe, lives another you? This haunting new work presents two dramatically different versions of one life. Set in parallel worlds, manipulated by a chorus of mysterious figures, Two blends the unsettling surreal with the familiar hyper-real. Written by local playwright Kat Taddei and directed by Colette Habel.”Two, a new stage-play, was an exciting challenge to write for emerging playwright Kat Taddei. The first full draft of the script was completed just this spring, for a third-year workshop at the University of Victoria, under the mentorship of award-winning playwright Charles Tidler.At the end of her spring workshop, Kat received an e-mail from Charles encouraging her to submit the script to local producer Catador Theatre, who were seeking an original play for production at the 2015 Victoria Fringe Festival. Anxiously, Kat did so... and a week later, Two was selected! Soon, Colette Habel, a fifth-year UVic student wrapping up her double-major in Theatre and Creative Writing, was on board as Two’s director. Together, Colette and Kat were lucky to find and cast a group of talented young people just as excited as them about bringing Two to life-- a group almost entirely made up theatre students, an amazing mixpot from the Victoria Academy of Dramatic Arts, UVic’s Phoenix, and Capilano University in Vancouver. Two balances themes of choice versus coincidence, parallels, and gender bias. Our intention with this production is to create an honest work of art that is not only aesthetically innovative, but which also stimulates conversation. What We Need Producing a full-scale Fringe show isn’t cheap-- and, as a creative team made up of mostly students, we aren’t exactly rich! However, whether we reach our fundraising goal or not, the truth is that every generous donation really will help make this project the best it can be. Here is a breakdown of our basic costs: 
$600 Festival application fee 
Marketing Materials (Posters, business cards, etc)
Advertising Space (We’ve purchased a space in the Fringe program worth $200)
Costumes (We have an amazing cast of 8, but it does mean more people to dress!)
Set pieces 
On top of our basic costs, we are hoping to be able to pay our amazing and devoted team of actors and designers an honorarium for all the hours of volunteer work they are lovingly pouring into this project. Who Are We? CATADOR THEATRE (PRODUCER)Catador Theatre’s mandate is Total Artistic Freedom.We work directly with innovative playwrights to produce exciting new theatre in Victoria, British Columbia. We know it’s a lot of work getting a play off the ground. That’s why we offer total artistic freedom and support to playwrights. Founded in 2014 by playwright and lawyer Laura Simons, Catador Theatre launched with a successful run of the comedy Yule Bleed in February 2015 as part of Intrepid Theatre’s YOU Show series. KAT TADDEI (PLAYWRIGHT)Kat is going into her fourth year at the University of Victoria, with a major in Creative Writing and a minor in Journalism. Before she had even memorized the alphabet, Kat would wander around her house “reading” aloud from her mom’s Agatha Christie novels-- really, just making up stories as she went along. Locally, her work has been presented at the Belfry Theatre’s SPARK Festival, Epiphany Theatre’s Interplay Festival, Intrepid’s YOU Show Series, and Intrepid’s brand new queer theatre festival, OUTstages. Kat also acts as Drama Editor for The Warren Undergraduate Review and writes short fiction, which has been published in This Side of West and soon-to-be in Luna Station Quarterly. COLETTE HABEL (DIRECTOR)Colette is a director, playwright and sound designer pursuing a double major in Theatre and Writing at the University of Victoria. Select sound design credits include: "Enter Vodka" (Intrepid Theatre New Play Reading Series, 2015), "Lion in the Streets" (UVic Phoenix Theatre, 2015), "Unity (1918)" (Uvic Phoenix Theatre, 2014), "Picnic" (UVic Phoenix Theatre, 2013). Colette also sound designed and directed her adaptation of "Goblin Market" for UVic's Student Alternative Theatre Company (SATCo) in 2013. Most recently, Colette was the Production Designer for Theatre SKAM's "The Lab", version 2.0. In addition to writing plays, Colette has written guest blog entries for arts organizations such as Theatre SKAM and the Belfry Theatre. Up next, Colette's devised theatre piece, "SCAPE": Victoria" about life in an urban centre, will be presented in September as an Intrepid Theatre YOUShow.SEAN BROSSARD (SET/LIGHTING DESIGNER)EMMA WOODHOUSE (COSTUME DESIGNER)Show Dates & Times: August 29th - 8:30pmAugust 31rst - 6:30pmSept. 2nd - 8:15 pmSept. 3rd - 10:15 pmSept. 5th - 10:45 pmSept. 6th - 4:00 pm

story:
My Story 

My name is Matt Jennings and "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" is my solo show.
  • I graduated from Cal State Long Beach University with a BA in Theater Arts in 2010.  In the past 5 years I continued to nurture myself as a actor and a writer. I've performed as principal and supporting characters in short films such as "A Marriage Of Inconvenience" and "90 Seconds To Live".  The films were featured in the LA Film Festival (2013), International Mobile Film Festival, and the Pocket Film Festival.  I  became a member of SAG-AFTRA actors union in 2011.  . 
  •  When I'm not on film I'm nurturing my skills as a writer and performer on stage.  "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" gave me a great opportunity to display both of those talents in a collection of honest words written and spoken by me for others to hear.  It is a “trekkies” coming out story told in “trekkie” fashion.  Like any Star Trek episode this show addresses a particular theme and the theme of this show is identity.  I explore what it means to be a black male with "white" tendencies, a right brain artist in a left brain family, and a homosexual christian.   

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $1,200.  This would cover the shows registration fee production costs, set pieces, marketing etc.  Feel free to donate whatever you wish, but if each of you donated just $10, it would be a long way toward making my goal. 

PERKS PERKS PERKS!!!!!!!

Here are the PERKS...

$5- A "Thank You" Email from you know who ;-) 

$10- Email and signed "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" postcard 

$20- A signed "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" poster.  You will also receive all lower cost perks!

$30- A personalized "Thank You" video.  A listing in the TUMJ program plus all lower cost perks!

$50- A magnet w/ "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" logo. Plus all lower cost perks!

$100- A coffee mug w/ "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" logo .  A listing in the TUMJ program plus all lower cost perks!

$150- A signed  "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" script.  Plus all lower cost perks!

$200- A signed T-shirt w/ "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" logo plus all lower cost perks

The Impact

  • I submitted  "The Universe Of Matt Jennings" to the NY Fringe Festival because it is a glimpse into a fanboys mind and how he processes life altering events.  With the popularity of television shows like “The Big Bang Theory” and the domination of Marvel Studios over the box office, its time to bring that audience in to the theater.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the Indegogo campaign on Facebook & Twitter!!!
  • Encourage your friends to do the same!
Thank you again for your support!!!!!

story:
Be a part of bringing a new puppetry production to life! 

The Amazing and Marvelous Cabinets of Kismet, a new full-length piece by Wit's End Puppets, opens this spring at Flashpoint as part of CulturalDC's Mead Theatre Lab Program.

The show follows Kismet, who lives in a world of cabinets and drawers.   But when a destructive force overturns his home, Kismet struggles to cope with change and to find his place in an unfamiliar world made entirely of paper.

This wordless production incorporates puppets in a variety of styles and media.  The show is created primarily for adults, but it's appropriate for audiences of all ages.

 

Why we need you

Through partnerships and generous donations, we have secured sources of free or low-cost production needs such as rehearsal space, performance space, and puppet-making materials.

Your contribution will offset our remaining costs and will make it possible for us to provide a stipend to our team of 12 artists.

You'll also get some great perks, including handmade puppets and tickets to exclusive events!

 

About Wit's End Puppets

Wit's End Puppets is devoted to telling stories through puppetry. We bring the art of puppetry to the DC community through innovative and original productions, collaboration with other artists, and educational workshops.  We have performed at venues throughout the DC area, including the Smithsonian American Art Museum. 

Visit www.witsendpuppets.com to learn more about the show, read Cecilia's regular blog posts, and sign up for our newsletter.

story:
CAMPAIGN SUMMARY

This October 18 Wasabassco will present a full theatrical burlesque adaptation of/ homage to 1933's King Kong at The Bell House, in celebration of the film's 80th anniversary. This will be the most elaborate production we have EVER mounted, with extensive costumes, props, set pieces, group numbers, and of course re-creating the great Kong himself. 

Short on time but big on enthusiasm, we’ve launched this indiegogo campaign to help raise the necessary budget to properly execute the production.

WHO WE ARE

Since its birth in 2004, New York based Wasabassco has produced finely-curated burlesque and nightlife events throughout New York City and across the nation, bringing their singular extravaganzas to diverse and enthusiastic audiences. Named by the Travel Channel as one of the Ten Best Burlesque Shows in the world, Wasabassco provides couple-friendly, risqué entertainment featuring internationally-recognized burlesque and variety performers from New York City and around the globe.

WHAT WE NEED

Funds raised for this production will first and foremost go toward the realization of Kong himself, as it will take great expense, craftsmanship, and skill to create the illusion of the 8th Wonder of The World in Wasabassco style for the Bell House stage.

In addition to Kong, it is our aim to create environments for the Kong adventure: the original props, costumes, and set pieces - including a New York cityscape - required to bring our tale to life. 

Last and certainly not least, we must pay all of the fine performers, costumers, writers and creators involved in the show for their contributions, rehearsal time, onstage appearance, and talent.

WHAT YOU GET

We’re against the idea of begging for donations for a for-profit venture - so for the most part we are simply using this campaign to sell advance tickets and packages to the show itself. VIP tickets will include access to a pre show party and a talk from world recognized Kong expert Ray Morton.

Additionally, many friends and supporters of Wasabassco have stepped forward to offer services in an effort to see this project realized, and those incentives are included as well.

For those who want to donate smaller sums or are unable to purchase tickets to the show we are offering items and perks that we would gladly sell elsewhere as merch.

THE IMPACT

With your help we can create one of the most amazing nights of live entertainment  ever seen, an event people will talk about for years – and, with the creation of the props and costumes already achieved, a show we can repeat in the future.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please help spread the word about this show and this campaign to your friends. October 18th is fast on its way!

story:
Last year a team of us gathered in the lowly and fierce Hub 14 studio to create a new show. Months later The Atomic Weight of Happiness emerged.

I have been creating and performing dance-theatre work since 1996. As I grow up, so does the work, and more importantly the scale of the work. For The Atomic Weight of Happiness I gathered an amazing team together to make an amazing production.

It's about personal mythology and how family lore shapes us, emotional equations - trying to dissect and understand feelings, and a proposal on how to save the world. (Happiness and innovation combined are a magical mix!)

The show opened in Toronto in April 2011, then got a remount for 600 grade 7's at Theatre Direct in the fall of 2012 and now we are getting to tour it!

We're heading to the UNO Festival in Victoria at the end of May, to Ottawa in August, and later to Peterborough and Vaughn. In the interim I am working to get more touring dates and intend to be touring this work for a while. The set is incredible and needs special attention to not get busted when it travels. We need to build shipping cases for it. Once we do, we'll be able to go anywhere!

Please consider making a contribution to help us share this great show with as many people as possible.

"This one of the most energetic and creative performances I’ve ever seen." Theatromania.ca

Every little bit helps us meet the goals to get this show on the road.

For big contributions we'll send you some bling, for smaller ones we'll send you smaller bling.

If you can't help out right now but want to spread the word, please do.

 

Thanks so much!

Meagan

story:
Our Saga

If you don't already know who this Capt. Donkeyface & Mr. Ponytail is, well then you have a lot more in common with Steven Seagal than you may have thought. CDMP is a weekly improvised show at the Dallas Comedy House in Deep Ellum. The troupe is made up of graduates from the DCH training program, performing the first ever "Worst Heckle Sandwich". Our mothers named us Carley Stewart, LaShunda Newson, Theresa Pegues, Clifton Hall, Nick Scott, and Joshua Morris.
 

CDMP has been named in the Dallas Observer's 21 Best Things To Do list and has also been labeled as the DCH equivalent of the hit Broadway musical "Cats"...with a little less music. And now, we've been accepted into this year's CHICAGO IMPROV FESTIVAL! Indeed, we're gearing up for the trip to Chi-town next month. We're excited to be able to take our show to the birthplace of improv; for the chance to inspire and be inspired.

Our Hope

Our hope is that you'll join us in making this epic journey possible. Your contribution will help us cover the costs of getting our six saddles to and from the windy city. The carefully considered target amount will be put to use in airfare, lodging, food, and transportation of the public persuasion.


We hope you'll consider our passion and we offer a hug(e) thanks in advance for your support in helping us reach this goal!


Other Ways You Can Help

Take your mother's advice and share! Helping us get the word out to each and every one would be the second kindest thing you could do for Capt. Donkeyface & Mr. Ponytail.

story:
AWAKE – A new play

Expect Theatre/ Spark Collective

Playwrights & Directors: Created and Directed by Chris Tolley and Laura Mullin

Cast: Beryl Bain, Lauren Brotman, Quancetia Hamilton, Muoi Nene, Peyson Rock, David Shelley, Richard Stewart

Team: Dramaturg: Erica Kopyto, Musical Director: Andrew Craig,Choreographer: Nicola Pantin, Lighting Design & Production Manager: Arun Srinivasan, Design: Ed Hanley, Light Designer & Production Manager, Set & Costume Designer: Jackie Chau, Stage Manager: Laura Cournoyea, Organist: Richard Wilson, Fight Choreographer: Simon Fon

 AWAKE

A hit of the 2011 Fringe, AWAKE is a new theatre piece that takes you deep into the heart of one of Toronto’s most violent neighbourhoods. Set in the funeral of a victim of gun violence, AWAKE explores the ripple effect of gangs within a community. Developed over three years, the production portrays the lives of those living in an “at risk” community. The show is made up entirely from interviews with mothers who have lost sons, gang members, outreach workers, and police. The show combines verbatim theatre, dance, video, and gospel music. Expect Theatre is raising funds to produce the World Premiere of AWAKE as part of the Next Stage Festival at the Factory Theatre from Jan. 2 – 13, 2012.

Expect Theatre receives operating funds from the Ontario Arts Council that go towards this project. AWAKE has also been supported by the Toronto Arts Council. This show was work shopped at the Toronto Fringe Festival in 2011. It was the second highest grossing show out of the 155 shows presented that year.

 Impact of Support

If you assist with the production of this project, you will be supporting a unique and ambitious multidisciplinary theatre piece that delves into the root cause and effect of gun violence in Toronto. It also helps illuminate the challenges faced by some living in priority communities. Everyone has a stake in putting a stop to the growing issue of gang and gun violence in our city. We cannot stop this violence without better understanding the reasons behind it.

Production costs to be covered by this campaign include:

  • Payment of artist fees such as actors, designers and crew
  • Production costs (sets, video rental and costumes)
  • Video rental
  • Marketing and Outreach
  • Tickets for youth in priority neighbourhoods

About Expect Theatre:

Laura Mullin and Chris Tolley founded Expect Theatre in 1996. Expect is dedicated to producing cutting edge, original, multi-disciplinary productions that explore modern urban life.

One of Mullin and Tolley’s most notable productions is Romeo/Juliet REMIXED, which premiered at the 2002 Toronto Fringe Festival and was remounted in Toronto in 2004 and Philadelphia in 2005. This interactive theatrical piece earned five Dora Award nominations and received international media attention, including a feature in the prestigious New York publication, Stage Directions. One of their more recent pieces, STATIC (an interactive exploration of fear) premiered as part of Harbourfront’s 2007 New World Stage Festival and was a winner of the inaugural Harbourfront FreshGround Commissioning Program. Other work with Harbourfront Centre includes writing and directing the show One Sleepless Night for the International Festival of Authors. Additional writing credits include the CBC commissioned radio drama, The Tunnel Runners (CBC Radio 1 and Radio Canada International). In 2011 the company presented a workshop production of AWAKE at the Toronto Fringe Festival. The show was the second highest grossing show of the Fringe.

 In 2005, Mullin and Tolley founded the urbanNOISE Festival, an annual event that brings some of Canada’s top urban artists into the Jamestown community to shine the spotlight on this unique area. To date, over 10,000 people have attended this Festival that featured such performers as Drake and Jully Black. In 2009, Expect was shortlisted for a Toronto Arts Foundation Award.

 www.expect.org

 We sincerely appreciate your support for this project.

About Expect Theatre:
Laura Mullin and Chris Tolley founded Expect Theatre in 1996. Expect is dedicated to producing cutting edge, original, multi-disciplinary productions that explore modern urban life.
One of Mullin and Tolley’s most notable productions is Romeo/Juliet REMIXED, which premiered at the 2002 Toronto Fringe Festival and was remounted in Toronto in 2004 and Philadelphia in 2005. This interactive theatrical piece earned five Dora Award nominations and received international media attention, including a feature in the prestigious New York publication, Stage Directions. One of their more recent pieces, STATIC (an interactive exploration of fear) premiered as part of Harbourfront’s 2007 New World Stage Festival and was a winner of the inaugural Harbourfront FreshGround Commissioning Program. Other work with Harbourfront Centre includes writing and directing the show One Sleepless Night for the International Festival of Authors. Additional writing credits include the CBC commissioned radio drama, The Tunnel Runners (CBC Radio 1 and Radio Canada International). In 2011 the company presented a workshop production of AWAKE at the Toronto Fringe Festival. The show was the second highest grossing show of the Fringe.
 In 2005, Mullin and Tolley founded the urbanNOISE Festival, an annual event that brings some of Canada’s top urban artists into the Jamestown community to shine the spotlight on this unique area. To date, over 10,000 people have attended this Festival that featured such performers as Drake and Jully Black. In 2009, Expect was shortlisted for a Toronto Arts Foundation Award.
 www.expect.org
 We sincerely appreciate your support for this project.

story:
Our Story


Virtual Box Office was created in 2010 by a team of performing arts and IT professionals, as a fee-free service to the performing arts community, a sector that has struggled with commercial ticketing agencies who’s fees are prohibitive to smaller organizations.


Our team is made up entirely of volunteers, from a number of backgrounds, including:


  • Online Ticketing Solutions
  • Event Management
  • Theatre Production and Direction
  • Software Development
  • Retail Merchandising and Marketing
  • Data Center Management
  • Cloud Computing design and development


Whilst we hope one day to grow Virtual Box Office into a commercial entity, today it does not pay any salaries or employees. All development and costs are borne by the team.


Virtual Box Office offers fee-based ticketing to commercial organizations, which helps fund (although not entirely, yet!) development and hosting. This lets us offer free ticketing services (event management, ticket sales, product sales, marketing and other capabilities) to smaller, non-professional performing arts organizations, including:


  • Schools & Educational Institutions
  • Not-for-profit organizations and charities
  • Non-professional theatre companies
  • Community based theatre companies


Whilst our team is based in Australia (that place at the bottom of our planet!), our users and clients are global – from the US to Europe!  We really live in a small world…


Why are we creating this product? Are we mad to make it free?


Yes, in a way we are mad! Mad at other ticketing agencies and providers reaping excessive profits by double-dipping on booking fees.  It doesn’t really cost us much to host the environment (a rack of equipment, so cloud services and a bit of internet…), so today as we grow we can cover the costs ourselves…


But why do we do this? Why are we spending our valuable spare time creating this?


  • Non-commercial organizations, in particular schools and amateur performing arts companies, are being charged exorbitant ticketing rates by the industry – upwards of 7-15% of the ticket price
  • We want to see non-commercial organizations grow - and this is our way of helping! By saving these organizations money, they can spend more on developing their groups.
  • This is a great opportunity to put something back into the community!  And we can’t act or sing (not in public at least!!), so this is a great way to contribute.
  • These services help non-commercial organizations promote their shows and events to a much wider audience by reducing operational costs.
  • It reduces the budgeting need of non-commercial organization - the same fee applies for 1 ticket or 1,000 tickets - nothing!
  • We're sick of the hidden fees that have become "standard" within the global ticketing industry.
  • We hope to make a difference - particular in forcing our larger competitors to be more community spirited!


The Impact – Seating Allocation


One of the key aspects of any ticketing system is ‘seating allocation’ – the capability of organizations to create online seating plans, and let their consumers or patrons chose their ticket. 


The commercial players in the ticketing industry offer these services for an exorbitant rate, but we believe we can offer it very, very cost effectively.


The purpose of this pitch is to raise funds to develop this aspect of the system, completing a product that we believe will change the industry and help an rapidly growing number of performing arts organizations.


Most smaller organizations current manage their allocations via manual mechanisms - graph paper, notes, Excel or similar tools.  Why not give back to the community and let these organizations utilize the same tools as the big boys?


What We Need & What You Get


We’re looking to raise up to $25,000.   This will help us to cover software development costs for this project, and fund the hosting of the seating system for up to 2 years. This will allow our team of volunteers to spend more time on development and marketing the product to the community.


Even if we don’t raise these funds (any or all), we’ll still complete this project, albeit a little more slowly. 


With your help, we can bring a commercial-style product with a set of extremely rich features to a sector of the community in your country that could previously never afford this kind of service.


All donations allow your group* (or a group you nominate*) free access to Seating Allocation services via Virtual Box Office, and a listing with links on our sponsors and thank-you pages.


For any donation about $250, we will provide a branded version of the system for your group* (or a group you nominate*) - we will take your web site's look & feel and replicate it onto our system for you.


Other Ways You Can Help


Tell others about our project!  The more people that learn about us, the more we can spread the word and start changing an industry!

http://www.virtualboxoffice.com.au/

 

*Only available to non-professional performing arts organizations, such as community theatre, schools, educational institutions, charities, and not for profit groups.

story:
Short Summary

Comedian Jabari Gayle, will ask random questions to a child (age range of 3-12) and the child will give an unrehearsed response (cute, honest and innocent). Next, the child will be asked if they have any special talents, favorite songs or dance steps. Once explained by the child, they will be asked to perform that talent in front of the live audience.  This live taping has the same concepts of Art Linkletters, Bill Cosby’s Children Say the Darnest Things, and the popular program Star Search all rolled into one. The show will be an 8 series webisode that will be pitched to most major T.V. networks including, CBS, Sprout, Disney Channel, TV One, and VH1. 

 Difference between the Art Linkletter’s, Bill Cosby’s, Children Say the Darnest Things, and the popular program Star Search is that KDot Kids will:
  • Showcase Talent in a Theatre Setting
  • Provide Awareness of kid's talent 
  • Improve Confidence for children with encouragement from the community
  • Connect local small business
  • Connect talent, agencies, directors, producers and parents

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise is $1000.00 dollars to raise for the

Venue at Nova Southeastern University Black Box Theatre

  • Camera Crew
  • Director
  • D.J.
  • Web editor
  1. Receive autograph picture of the whole cast & DVD of the Best of the Best Last Laughs
  2. a DVD of the finish webisode
  3. be the first to see the guests featured on KDot Talent Kids Show with exclusive behind the scenes photos from each shooDescribe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.
  4. "Supporting Producer" credit in each episode of Last Laughs Presents KDot Talent Kids Show + Personal thank you video from the producer.

Jabari Gayle has produce the 1st show KDot KiDs Show on November 17th at the Fort Lauderdale Commedy Club and sucessfully raise $515 dollars. Also he has produce 9 comedy shows and is responsible for booking 70 comedians for the Last Laughs Comedy Contest. His track record is a sucessful one. The new project will effect the community on the whole and emproving a child confidence level.

The Impact

*Empowering each child with the necessary training to get work with agents and casting directors. 

*Helping children look the part to advance their career to the next level. 

*Building a strong support system with family, friends and the local community business by staying connected through social media. 

*Enabling local companies to reach their target markets.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer at the event on Feburary 9th 2013
  • share this at every social media such as: Facebook, Instangra, Youtube, & Twitter
  • Hve your child apart of the show
  • Donate any amount that you can

story:
The Show:

Odd Man Out Productions is presenting a new and physical version of August Strindberg’s Miss Julie at the Theatre Local in the Bussey Building in Peckham, opening on the 31st of October 2012 and running until 17 November 2012. 

Our version of Miss Julie will be highly physical, a dance of lust and power between Julie and John, representing the almost tangible tensions at work over the length of the play. This all happens while on the grounds the local community is feasting and celebrating, barging onto stage at one point. This celebratory dance will be performed by members from Southwark’s local community.

The show will be directed by Vernon Douglas who has extensive experience in the theatre and having shown work at the Royal Court Theatre and The Young Vic among others.

We need your help!

To put on the show we need your support! Your contribution will be of great help in covering our production costs, i.e. lights, costumes, props, set and artists.

Rewards

In return for your support we have a few rewards:

$8 (£5) : a beautiful e-card from John and Julie in their new hotel

$16 (£10) : a beautiful e-card from John and Julie in their new hotel and an honourable mention in our program

$40 (£25) : all of the above and a special soap from the hotel

$80 (£50) : all of the above and a wondrous washcloth from the hotel

$160 (£100) : all of the above and a drink with the director after the show

$400 (£250) : a personalised video greeting from John and Julie and all of the above

$800 (£500) : Julie’s personal whip! And a special thanks in the program as well as a meet and greet with the cast after the show

Share, share share!

If you are not able to contribute yourself, we would greatly appreciate it if you would share this page with your friends and colleagues.  Post this link on your Facebook and Twitter page to help us get the word out. You can use the various Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word.

story:
Our Story

After our initial successful run during the New York International Fringe Festival, our show has been selected for this year's FringeNYC Encore's Series. We will be performing five more shows this September at The Players Theatre in New York City!


In PARKER & DIZZY’S FABULOUS JOURNEY TO THE END OF THE RAINBOW, Vicky Luster, famed songstress of the Valley of the Balls nightclub has been shot by a mysterious man in her dressing room. Barely clinging to her final breaths, she musters enough energy to scribble, ‘SCRAM VENGEFUL MIS’ in lipstick on her vanity. Her assistant, Parker, and choreographer, Dizzy, discover not only her dead body but her cryptic message. What follows is a crazy, campy musical epic adventure as Parker and Dizzy venture out to reveal their employer’s murderer, and end up uncovering more, including dead bodies, drag queens, an evil mentor, and the revelation of the gay holy grail leading to a fabulous climactic showdown. 


If The Wizard of Oz married Star Wars but cheated with Thelma & Louise and got pregnant by the The Da Vinci Code, the baby would be this show! 


The Impact

PARKER & DIZZY’S FABULOUS JOURNEY TO THE END OF THE RAINBOW is a brand-new musical, with a book by Peter Zachari and original songs written by Damon Maida and Peter Zachari. And now we have been selected to premiere our show at FringeNYC Encores Series. We are thrilled to have this fantastic opportunity to bring these characters to New York City, and now we need your help. 


What We Need & What You Get

(We need to mount a production of this complete with costume, sound, props, musicians, publicity, the works. Your donation to this project will help make this dream of ours a reality. By contributing money to this project, you are helping the artists associated with this project to see an original production come to fruition. We have set our goal at $3000 but if we reach that, please keep giving! Every cent raised on this site will absolutely go to the funding of this production. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! Tell your friends about us. Visit our Facebook page. And please, above all else, come and see the show! We would love to see everyone there.


The Players

Peter Zachari (Playwright/Lyrics) has written Lighten Up!, which was produced off-off-Broadway, as well as Loosen Up!, Shake It Up!, Live It Up!, One Love and his newest play Parker and Dizzy’s Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow. Mr. Zachari’s directing credits include Into the Woods, Footloose, Rumors, Grease, West Side Story, They’re Playing Our Song, Return to the Forbidden Planet and Moon Over Buffalo .  As an actor, his New York credits include Street Scene (The York Theatre Company), Connections (Actors Theatre of America), 1940’s Radio Hour (The Emelin Theatre), The All-Male Importance of Being Earnest (New York International Fringe Festival), and Happy Hour (The Producers’ Club).  Regional credits include Love’s Labour’s Lost (Huntington), The Illusion, All in the Timing, Laughter on the 23rd Floor, A Christmas Carol and 4R Planet (Hippodrome State Theatre); Big River and Young Abe Lincoln (Lincoln Amphitheatre); A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum, Last of the Red Hot Lovers, Mary, Mary (Summer Theatre at Salem); The Flatlanders (Dollywood) and Fiddler on the Roof and Cabaret (Center for the Performing Arts, Gainesville).  His television credits include “White Collar,” “As the World Turns,” “The Life of Lizzie Borden,” and “Half Empty.”  He received his M.F.A. from the University of Florida and his B.F.A. from Salem State College. 


Joey Mirabile (Choreographer) has choreographed productions of Footloose, Grease and Into the Woods for Summer Theatre at Salem as well as Godspell, Cinderella, Holly Jolly Follies and Broadway Our Way. Acting credits include Company (Bobby), Grease (Danny), They’re Playing Our Song (Vernon), Footloose (Garvin), Antigone (Sentry), The Snow Queen (Jack Frost), Six Degrees of Separation (Rick), 42nd Street (Billy Lawlor). He could be seen as Nathaniel Hawthorne in Spirits of the Gables at the House of Seven Gables every Halloween in Salem. Joey is also known as “Coco of Times Square.”


Damon Maida (Music/Lyrics) is a singer and songwriter based in New York City. As a performer, he has appeared at some of New York's premiere listening rooms (The Bitter End, Symphony Space, Piano's,Triad) . Damon is a frequent co-writer and is excited to be working with Peter Zachari, composing music for "Parker & Dizzy..." When not writing songs with Peter, Damon can be seen singing with his vocal band The Perspective (www.theperspectiveband.com). Also an actor and voice-over artist, Damon's voice can be heard on a number of children's video games, commercials, and the newest "World of Warcraft: Cataclysm" video game. Damon is currently writing music for the follow-up to his debut album, "Only Child," available through CD Baby (http://cdbaby.com/cd/maida) and Apple ITunes.

story:
THANK YOU FOR VISITING THIS CAMPAIGN!  WE NEED YOU.

My name is Shaunda Miles and I am the Playwright of WHO DO YOU LOVE?  A Gospel Musical Inspired by the story of Esther.

Love, scandal, politics (it is an election year!), religion and redemption...the show has it all.

The primary source of funding for WHO DO YOU LOVE? will be individual givers, such as yourself.  This exciting event will be held June 8-10, 2012.  In the beginning, God CREATED.  We are made in His image.  He has provided us the same power to create and we believe that our art, events and work can also form and transform the world.  I want to thank you in advance for your contribution, signifying your faith in our mission, vision, and in the power of creativity.  By contributing to the production of WHO DO YOU LOVE? you help us celebrate, and spread, the Word.  You make it possible for us to provide an alternative form of entertainment that is Spirit-filled and positively life changing.  Thank you for joining us on our journey toward a NEW ERA OF GOSPEL MUSICALS. 

 

THE TEAM

Dwayne Fulton: Musical Director
Greer Reed: Choreographer
Kate Devlin: Production Manager
Angelique Stothers: Stage Manager
Lisha Logan: Casting Director
Pamela Collier: PR & Sponsorship Consultant
Chris Ivey: Videographer
Demeatria Boccella: Costume Design
Deryck Tines: Costume Design
*Featured Cast Member, PGH'S Own:  Ms. Bev Smith

 

WHAT WE NEED

We REALLY need to PAY the ARTISTS.  We also need to hire a few more artists and need to pay them also.  So far, I have been moving forward on faith, and now comes the work!  All expenses to date have been paid out of my own pocket and I simply cannot complete this task alone.  All artists and administrators deserve to be paid.

There is a saying...GOOD,FAST & CHEAP.  You can only have two of the three.  We want a GOOD (Excellent) show that we need to get done before June 8 (FAST).  So, it will not be CHEAP!

Of the $40k budget, $24k is allocated just to pay the large group of beautiful people currently volunteering their time.  Money is going to THE PEOPLE and on the STAGE!

Here are some of our expenses:

Actors: $8k

Musical Director, Musicians and Choir:$4k

Production Team (Manager, Tech Director, et al): $3k

Designers & Choreographer: $2k

Labor: $3k

Set Construction & Materials: $4k

Theater Rental: $3k

Please Note: A portion of your gift will be tax deductible.  The tax deduction is limited to the excess of the contribution over the fair market value of any items received in exchange for the donation.

A BIT ABOUT ME

I love Wilson, Perry, Ibsen, Boal, Shange, & Shakespeare!  MY LIFELONG DREAM IS TO CREATE WORK THAT BLENDS THE EMOTION & STRONG STORIES OF THE "URBAN CIRCUIT" WITH THE PROFESSIONAL PROCEDURES I HAVE LEARNED IN THE "REGIONAL THEATER!" 

During the day, I work as the Vice President of Programming & Cultivation at the August Wilson Center for African American Culture.  There, my responsibilities include developing the programming and cultivation department’s annual operating budget and monitoring SPENDING to ensure fiscal responsibility (So I will spend your money properly, if I can just raise it!). 

I am a native Long Islander, and I moved to Pittsburgh in 2010 to pursue my passion for the arts and administration.  Somehow, I graduated from my beloved Alma Matar - Dartmouth College in 1999.

In 2004, I received my master’s degree in Theater Management from the Yale School of Drama and subsequently worked for theaters across the nation, including The Goodman Theatre of Chicago, Second Stage Theatre in New York, Yale Repertory Theatre in New Haven, Connecticut and the Pasadena Playhouse and Cornerstone Theater Company - both located in California.  

I am involved in a ton of activities, but my heart is with this project and other plays and musicals I plan to write for the entertainment and education of great people like you!

demaskus is a company I founded in 2007.  It is a 501(c)3 service-oriented collective of professional artists and administrators.  We creatively represent biblical stories, adapt classical texts and produce new plays based upon biblical principles and personal testimonies.  

 

THE IMPACT

This show promises to feed your SPIRIT.  Be INSPIRED as you witness characters OVERCOME challenges and SING some good GOSPEL MUSIC.  Turn off those crazy television shows that fill you with anxiety and anger and please support a show that will provide you with HOPE, LAUGHTER, INSIGHT and a DESIRE to CREATE CHANGE in our shared society.    

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Even if you can’t contribute financially, that doesn’t mean they can’t help!

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.  Feel free to share the link!  You can utilize the Indiegogo share tools on the site.

Thank you for your time and consideration!

story:
This fall, Isaac Oliver’s Electra in a One-Piece will have its world premiere, directed by David Ruttura, beginning Thursday, October 28 and opening Monday, November 1 at 8pm at the Wild Project, 195 East Third Street, NYC.

A brutally funny modern tragedy, Electra in a One-Piece re-imagines the bloody Greek tale for our digital era. When Elle discovers that her mother has murdered her father and is burying him in the backyard, she sends for help the only way she knows how: the internet. Armed only with a video camera, she videotapes the gruesome scene and posts it on YouTube to alert her brother stationed in Iraq, inadvertently becoming an overnight YouTube sensation. Urged on by the chatter of anonymous commenters clamoring for more, Elle and her family saturate the internet with videos, stirring controversy and piquing the interest of a savvy television producer with plans for a camera-ready bloodbath.

Visit The Show Website


WELL HELLO, INDIE GOGO

We’re good company, a brand new theater company. More specifically, we’re David Ruttura and Isaac Oliver, two NYC-based theatre folk who are putting on a show for the very first time and would love your support.


PULL UP A CHAIR, ROLL UP YOUR SLEEVES & GET IN IT

This will be a rewarding and challenging ride, and we’d love to have you along.

Your pledges will make it possible for us to rent the theater, rehearse the play, build the set, acquire the costumes, and promote the production.

Supporters will receive updates about the production and exclusive rewards listed in the right-hand column. As an added bonus, any donation you’re able to make is tax-deductible.

Thank you in advance for your generosity. We truly could not do this without you.


OUR MISSION

good company is a new theater company dedicated to telling stories that engage, enlighten and, above all else, entertain. By rallying together old friends and welcoming new ones, we hope to form a community of young theater artists with strong, unique voices and equal senses of perspective and play. We strive to create an environment in which artists and audiences alike feel like they are — yes, we’re going there — in good company.


David Ruttura, Artistic Director
Isaac Oliver, Associate Artistic Director

Melanie Hopkins, General Manager

Advisory Council | Walter Bobbie, Michael Kimmel, Theresa Von Klug, Eric Schaeffer

www.goodcompanynyc.org

story:
"No More Secrets" : Using performing arts to encourage elementary school children to prevent and/or disclose sexual abuse.

Street Theatre Company is a non-profit, professional arts organization dedicated to fostering theatre, music and arts education in Nashville by producing the highest quality professional theatre performances and educational workshops, and providing artistic opportunities for young people.  Street Theatre Company bases its philosophy on the elements of street theatre: to make the arts accessible and affordable to all in the community, and select thought-provoking productions that can leave an audience enlightened.  

As part of its youth programming and community outreach, STC produces the social service play, No More Secrets.  1 out of 6 girls and 1 out of 8 boys will be sexually abused each year. Statistics show that over 89% of child sexual assault and abuse comes from someone a family knows, and only 16% of children who suffer from abuse disclose. More than ever, children need the opportunity to learn more about the prevention of sexual abuse.

No More Secrets is a musical that tells the tale of a pre-teen girl named Jenny who, for years, has been sexually abused by a trusted neighbor, and her subsequent disclosure. The play entertains while at the same time providing children with information about abuse and how they can protect themselves and others from abuse. This show addresses many of the concerns children may have about disclosing and truly connects with students. All characters are portrayed by professional actors who have been trained by counselors. The play is followed by a question and answer period where the students are invited to ask questions, and a professional counselor and school guidance counselors are available to provide additional support in the event of disclosure.

No More Secrets previously toured Nashville area disadvantaged schools, performing at 15 schools in 2009 and 10 schools in 2011, as well as offering two free public performances at a local community center.  The show has a proven track record of success with disclosures well into the double digits at the end of each tour.

The most powerful feedback came in an email from a counselor:

“I want you to know that we had 9 disclosures with 3 of them resulting in DCS calls. One resulted in the arrest of a family member that evening. Had you not visited our school, this student would have entered her summer break with the abuse likely happening on a daily basis. The student had been exposed to Safe At Last through my classroom guidance, Kids on the Block abuse program, and finally “No More Secrets”. She really related to the play and disclosed that afternoon. I can’t begin to tell you how grateful I am for your program and hope that many more of our students in Metro Schools will be able to benefit from the play. Well done!”

STC’s long term goal is to tour approximately 25 schools each year, and to continue on a rotating basis every three years to each given school, ensuring that all students see the program at least once.  If this goal is met, over 6,000 students can be reached each year. The goal for us on Indiegogo is to reach 7 schools in the fall of 2013 with enough funding so that schools will not have to pay for the program. The objective of this program is that students will leave the performance with tools to prevent sexual abuse from happening to them, or if they are already being abused, that they will disclose the abuse to a trusted adult.

The No More Secrets tour costs $675 to bring to each school.  As school budgets are perpetually diminishing, the goal is to offer this program at absolutely NO COST to schools to remove barriers that may prevent children from seeing this important social play, especially those in undeserved populations.
