story:
With only hours left, we'd like to extend a huge thanks to all our contributors:) We'd also like to note that even if we don't reach our original goal, the project will go ahead with what we have- so rest assured, any support you can manage in these last few hours will go a long way!! Thank you!


About the Project 

Verge follows four dancers as they move between the realms of ancient forest and clearcut, embodying both the ecological connections that support life in British Columbia’s ancient temperate rainforests and the fragmentation of this landscape through industrial logging.This film invites the viewer to stand, as witness and potential activist, at the epicenter of this scarred and sacred landscape.

Born out of a collaboration between Vancouver-based choreographer Anna Kraulis, media artist Leslie Kennah, and Ancient Forest Alliance activist Hannah Carpendale, Verge aims to bridge the arts and conservation movements, combining artistic expression and forest activism to create a compelling, site-specific dance film. 


Where It Came From  

In the summer of 2013, we shot an exploratory pilot film (above) on Coast Salish Territory in Stanley Park (Vancouver) with dancers Jennifer Aoki, Jennifer Dunford, Angelina Krahn and Rianne Svelnis. Excited by our findings during this exploration, we are eager to take the choreography we have been developing into some of the majestic ancient forests and extensively logged landscapes of the province.


Where It's Going

The final project will be shot over a 3-day period in July 2014, near Avatar Grove on the southwest coast of Vancouver Island. This is an area where some of the last ancient forests on BC’s south coast still stand, starkly contrasted by the expanses of stumps in nearby clearcut valleys. 

We can’t wait to bring this project to life in the awe-inspiring landscapes of BC’s coastal temperate rainforests - with your support, this can happen!

In the coming months, we will continue to develop the creative concept and choreography for the film and make travel arrangements for the production phase. We need to raise funds for the production and travel costs associated with filming in this integral remote location.

Your support will also help us to honour the efforts each of our collaborators: choreographer and dancers, director/editor, researcher, and music producer. Until this point they have all donated their time, and we would love to support their hard work with honorariums. Providing financial support to these dedicated artists will make it feasible for us to continue this type of inspiring and engaging work.

Our passionate efforts will result in the production of an 8-minute dance film that will be submitted for inclusion at film festivals and events across the country. We will also produce a 2-minute trailer to be distributed online via social media. We hope to use the short version of the project to reach a diverse audience and to increase the impact of the Ancient Forest Alliance’s campaign to protect BC’s endangered old-growth forests.

 

What We Need and What You Get 

To make this project possible, we need to cover the basic costs for our shooting in this remote location. Your contributions will also help to honour the time and dedication of our generous collaborators. Anna, Leslie and Hannah, plus a team of four dancers, will be travelling to a remote location on Vancouver Island to film the project over a period of three days. Here is what we need your help with:


$1575: Dancer and Creator Honorariums ($225 each x 7: four dancers, three co-creators) 

$225: Music Producer Honorarium 

$200: Per diem costs while traveling 

$100: Costume budget (used materials)

$750: Travel costs (vehicle rental, fuel, ferry)

$550: film gear rentals

TOTAL: $3400 


We have lots of neat perks to offer in exchange for contributions...check out the sidebar! *(note that the book and calendar ship within Canada only)

Impact 

This project does not exist in isolation - rather, it is part of a growing movement towards a deeper and more personal connection with environmental issues. By merging artistic practice with the forest conservation movement, we can draw greater attention from a more diverse audience. This artistic activism encourages people to engage with the issue in a deeper, more meaningful way. 

Verge is one part of a lifelong journey that the three of us are passionately dedicated to - using the powerful tool of art to generate positive social and environmental change. 


About the Creators 

This is the second collaborative project between Leslie Kennah, Hannah Carpendale and Anna Kraulis. We began working together after recognizing the potential impact that merging our diverse areas of expertise could have. In 2013, we collaborated on the project Water Bodies, combining dance and film to raise awareness about the cultural/historical and ecological significance of water, specifically exploring the lost and buried streams of the Vancouver’s False Creek Watershed.

Our group has been generously awarded a DanceLab research residency (2013/14) at The Dance Centre in Vancouver. Individually, we are all recognized professionals in our respective disciplines and we continue to grow a significant body of work in the arts and activism fields. The dancers we have chosen for this project are professional artists who each bring to the work a strong connection to environmental activism. We are lucky to have such a dedicated team! 


Other Ways You Can Help 

Help us spread the word! We realize not everyone is in a position to contribute financially, but you can help us by telling your networks about the campaign!

If you're interested in contributing in another way to the project (skill-wise, etc.), we'd love to hear from you! (You can leave a message in the "comments" section above)


Check out Ancient Forest Alliance’s campaign and find out how you can get involved at www.AncientForestAlliance.org 


Thank you!!!!

Where It's GoingThe final project will be shot over a 3-day period in July 2014, near Avatar Grove on the southwest coast of Vancouver Island. This is an area where some of the last ancient forests on BC’s south coast still stand, starkly contrasted by the expanses of stumps in nearby clearcut valleys. We can’t wait to bring this project to life in the awe-inspiring landscapes of BC’s coastal temperate rainforests - with your support, this can happen!
In
the coming months, we will continue to develop the creative concept and
choreography for the film and make travel arrangements for the production
phase. We need to raise funds for the production and travel costs associated
with filming in this integral remote location.Your support will also help us to honour the efforts each of our collaborators: choreographer and dancers, director/editor, researcher, and music producer. Until this point they have all donated their time, and we would love to support their hard work with honorariums. Providing financial support to these dedicated artists will make it feasible for us to continue this type of inspiring and engaging work.Our passionate efforts will result in the production of an 8-minute dance film that will be submitted for inclusion at film festivals and events across the country. We will also produce a 2-minute trailer to be distributed online via social media. We hope to use the short version of the project to reach a diverse audience and to increase the impact of the Ancient Forest Alliance’s campaign to protect BC’s endangered old-growth forests. What We Need and What You Get To make this project possible, we need to cover the basic costs for our shooting in this remote location. Your contributions will also help to honour the time and dedication of our generous collaborators. Anna, Leslie and Hannah, plus a team of four dancers, will be travelling to a remote location on Vancouver Island to film the project over a period of three days. Here is what we need your help with:$1575: Dancer and Creator Honorariums ($225 each x 7: four dancers, three co-creators) $225: Music Producer Honorarium $200: Per diem costs while traveling $100: Costume budget (used materials)$750: Travel costs (vehicle rental, fuel, ferry)$550: film gear rentalsTOTAL: $3400 We have lots of neat perks to offer in exchange for contributions...check out the sidebar! *(note that the book and calendar ship within Canada only)
Impact This project does not exist in isolation - rather, it is part of a growing movement towards a deeper and more personal connection with environmental issues. By merging artistic practice with the forest conservation movement, we can draw greater attention from a more diverse audience. This artistic activism encourages people to engage with the issue in a deeper, more meaningful way. 
Verge is one part of a lifelong journey that the three of us are passionately dedicated to - using the powerful tool of art to generate positive social and environmental change. 
About the Creators This is the second collaborative project between Leslie Kennah, Hannah Carpendale and Anna Kraulis. We began working together after recognizing the potential impact that merging our diverse areas of expertise could have. In 2013, we collaborated on the project Water Bodies, combining dance and film to raise awareness about the cultural/historical and ecological significance of water, specifically exploring the lost and buried streams of the Vancouver’s False Creek Watershed.Our group has been generously awarded a DanceLab research residency (2013/14) at The Dance Centre in Vancouver. Individually, we are all recognized professionals in our respective disciplines and we continue to grow a significant body of work in the arts and activism fields. The dancers we have chosen for this project are professional artists who each bring to the work a strong connection to environmental activism. We are lucky to have such a dedicated team! 
Other Ways You Can Help Help us spread the word! We realize not everyone is in a position to contribute financially, but you can help us by telling your networks about the campaign!If you're interested in contributing in another way to the project (skill-wise, etc.), we'd love to hear from you! (You can leave a message in the "comments" section above) Check out Ancient Forest Alliance’s campaign and find out how you can get involved at www.AncientForestAlliance.org Thank you!!!!

story:
I am a New Orleans-raised, trained professional dancer, now turned street dancer and performer.  Though I've had extensive training in ballet, salsa, flamenco, lindy hop, West African, and break dance, my direction has been to create my own genre of New Orleans-born street dance, which can be done under the umbrella terms of funk and second line street dance.  Second line is a mostly freetsyle New Orleans dance done to live brass band music, and tied to many cultural traditions similar to those of the Caribbean.  

     The opportunity has arrisen for me to perform this New Orleans style dance at a collaborative concert in New York City as part of a cultural exchange campaign.  The concert, Too Hot For New Orleans, will be funded and organized by James Demaria Productions, and is a collaboration between New York hip hop artists and New Orleans musicians.  The aim is to create a new musical genre to be sponsored, brought and shared ultimately around the world, while shedding light on the importance of the two cultures.  Mr. Demaria has filmed a documentary called Treme Life and done extensive professional photography within and for the city of New Orleans.  As a cultural enthusiast, he sees my dance as a crucial element to the making and marketing of this musical genre.  It will help to engage the listeners, define the feel of the new music, and shed light on the influential culture of New Orleans and its effects on surrounding cultures.  

     Your contributions will help to cover travel, housing, and compensation for the time and energy put into the performance. You will also receive gifts in return for your donations.  On a larger scale, allowing me to participate in this cultural exchange will help to put New Orleans culture on the global map.  While the collaboration of hip hop and New Orleans funk contributes to the progression of artistic expression and cultural unity in a big way, the preservation and development of dance only strengthens that goal.  

     To me, this concert won't be complete without dance.  Giving the audience permission to move, showing them how they can move to the new music, revving their enthusiasm, and essentially conversing with & playing off the musicians to strengthen the entire art, must happen for this collaboration to gain sponsorship and grow larger.  

Gratefully,

Elsie Semmes

985-640-6563

elsiesemmes@aol.com

Facebook: Elsie Semmes

www.easemmes.com

story:
Who We Are

Cabaret Roulette launched in November 2012 with a simple goal: to shake up the cabaret scene by throwing out old ideas, empowering audiences and challenging artists to push beyond their comfort zones. We've had two shows so far and a third is in the hopper, and the quality has been OUTSTANDING.

Each show has a central theme, chosen in advance by the audience via the Facebook fan page, followed by a live vote. Eight carefully-curated artists, representing as widely-differing disciplines and styles as possible, then have two months to create a brand new act putting their individual take on that single theme. The show is called "Roulette" because we won't know where the ball lands until the night.

The model encourages creativity and risk: with just a hint of friendly competition, the artists are inspired to dig past the obvious and the done to create something truly fresh and extraordinary. And with no discipline duplicated on the night, the audience can expect an exciting, fascinating evening of true variety.

What We Need

Out of necessity, we ran the first shows as a doorshare, splitting the remaining profits evenly between the artists - a method that thankfully has worked well but is no model for ensuring the quality of the art we're asking for and encouraging the long life of the show.

We are fundraising in order to establish a small fund from which to guarantee artist fees and reduce personal risk.  If the show does well, the ticket sales will comfortably replenish the fund and we can roll it over for use on the next show. If the show doesn't do well, the artists still get paid for their hard work and we assess the future of the show based on its commercial appeal and prospects.

Some of our dreams for the show include:

* Moving to a better night for the audience.  Right now all we can afford are Wednesdays, but this a Friday kind of show!

* Move to a monthly format, with two shows in the hopper at any given time, in order to capitalise on the momentum.

* Build on the theatre experience side of the experience, further differentiating ourselves from the crowd of burlesque shows out there.

* Longer runs!  Perhaps a tour!  Why not London's WEST END!?!

And if the show continues to do well right to the point where we decide to move on to other projects, we commit to rolling our parachute money over to another arts company in need. It's only right.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute but want to help out, "like" us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/CabaretRoulette) and help spread the word and/or come check out a show!

story:
Tucked away, high on a shelf in a San Francisco studio, neatly packed in several cardboard boxes, lays the the performance archives of choreographer Sara Shelton Mann.

—

Time is not a friend of the magnetic tape. Join us in our effort to save these performance records—let's ensure they are available for study and enjoyment for years to come! These boxes are full of media: VHS tapes (the newer stuff, as in late 80’s, early 90’s), 3/4 inch video cassette (a precursor to VHS, from the 70’s), and some V30H open reel tapes, each a 30-minute glimpse into an adventurous past.

_

GREAT NEWS! Funded by the National Endowment for the Arts, the Bay Area Video Coalition's Preservation Access Program has named Sara recipient of an award to digitize these works at a subsidized cost. Now we need your support to ensure the survival of the collection as a whole.

_

In awarding Sara a 2014 GOLDIE for Lifetime Achievement in Dance, Rita Felciano and Robert Avila, SF dance critics, wrote: “[Sara] translated concepts like “improv-based,” “collaborative,” “interdisciplinary,” and “dance theater” into vital, raucous, and highly effective performances that inspired a whole generation of artists to wander into unknown territory. The Bay Area would not be as welcoming and supportive of experimentation in dance were it not for the ongoing presence of Sara Shelton Mann.”

The digitalization of these performance works will ensure access far and wide, so the work can continue to inspire and challenge new generations of performers and choreographers across the globe.

—

With your financial support, reaching the $7,000 goal will:

- Pay the bill for BAVC for the digitization of 40 tapes  

- Digitize photographs, posters, and other related media 

 - Pay for administrative support and related fees for this preservation project.

_______________________________________

Learn more about Sara Shelton Mann:  http://www.sarasheltonmann.org

Read Robert Avila and Rita Feliciano’s full 2014 Goldie Award article: http://www.sfbg.com/2014/02/18/goldies-2014-lifetime-achievement-sara-shelton-mann

Learn more about Contraband: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contraband_(performance_group)

Learn more about BAVC: http://www.bavc.org

story:
What's the Deal?

Net is an original play by Erika Babins that will be presented at the Victoria Fringe Festival. Starring: Emma Middleton, Lucas Hall, Alysson Hall, Brittany Cairns, and Malcolm Masters. Stage manager/Production designer: Nathan Babins. Costume designer: Oriana Camporese. Graphics: Cameron Dunster

Venue: Victoria Event Centre 1415 Broad St, Victoria

Thurs, Aug 22-10pm    Fri, Aug 23- 8:15pm     Sat, Aug 24- 6:30pm

Mon, Aug 26-10pm     Sat, Aug 31- 2pm       Sun, Sept 1- 9:15

Tickets at: http://www.victoriafringe.com/tickets/

***ONE NIGHT ONLY VENUE*** Peretz Centre 6184 Ash Street, Vancouver

Sunday Aug 18- 8pm

 

What is "NET"?

Isabelle, Ashley and Sam are best friends. Isabelle’s crushing on Mike. Sam is dating Ashley’s brother, Jon, who used to – maybe – hold a torch for Isabelle. But the balance is shaken when these five friends are roped into an anniversary party for a couple twice their age.

In this modern day comedy of manners, everyone tries to make their moments count in a quest for love, friendship, and incriminating photographs.

 

Who Are These People?

ODW Productions is a brand new theatre company based out of Vancouver, BC. We aim to connect new plays with emerging actors and designers to bring fresh current projects to our audiences.

ODW Production's inagural project will be presenting a new play writen by founder, Erika Babins, at a one night only event at in Vancouver as well as a full engagement at the Victoria Fringe Festival. Our talented team includes our director, 5 actors, costume designer, stage manager/producton designer, graphic designer and marketing manager. 10 amazing new artists all recently graduated from theatre based post-secondary institutions.

 

So You're Going To Victoria, Now What?

Well first off we have to get to Victoria! And once we're there we've got some festival fees to pay as well as paying for posters and promo cards.

Our budget looks something like this:

$600- Victoria Fringe Festival Entrance Fee

$110- Promo cards (1000 of them)

$80- Posters (100 of them)

$248- Passenger Ferry Fares round trip for our Director, Actors and Costumer

$102.50- Vehicle Ferry Fare to bring our set and costumes

$280- Bus fare to and from Fringe performances for our Director, Actor and Costumer.

=

$1420.50.

 

Our goal is to cover our cost with this campaign so that ticket sales can go directly into a revenue share between all the talented artists working on this show!

 

I'm Getting Something Out of This, Though, Right?

Of course you are! 

Not only are you directly enabling theatre artists to continue to make meaningful and impactful work, you can also get some killer perks! Check out the right side of the page for all the funky stuff you can get!

 

The Big Picture

You might still be thinking: "why is it important for me to fund theatre? Can't I just go watch a movie?". The thing is, you can. But it'll never be the same as watching something live. There is an immediacy and humanity that you experience as you watch event happening live that you can never replicate through a lense .

We do what we do so you can experience it.

 

For more on the company's thoughts on funding the arts, click HERE

 

 

This All Sounds Great But I Can't Swing it Right Now...

That's ok! We get it, we're struggling emerging artists, remember? If you think this project sounds cool and you like what we're doing you can talk about us! Just open your mouth and start gabbing. If you're in Vancouver on Aug 18th or Victoria from Aug 22-Sept 1st we'd love to see you out there in the audience. If you won't be, tell everyone you know who will be!

story:
About The Show :

"I Was Loved by a Rat" is a twisted fairy tale, a dark comedy, and a humorous tragedy revolving around an ill-fated love between a lonely young woman and a chivalrous rat who share a squalid apartment. While the world of the play is surreal and whimsical, at its heart the story explores the tensions between the love and fear, desire and revulsion that underlie many of our closest (human) relationships.

This play was written by Essie Martsinkovsky while she was pursuing her M.F.A. at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, Asia, in Singapore. After a number of class workshops and a public reading with a Singaporean arts organization, she submitted the play to FringeNYC and was thrilled to learn she'd have a chance to create a fully staged version for an audience.

What We Need :

Putting on a show at FringeNYC does cost money. Here are just a few of the things that we need money to pay for:

  • Rehearsal space and studio Fees
  • Props, costumes and set pieces
  • Insurance to cover us, and insurance to cover you when you come to see the show!
  • A stage manager, a lighting programmer, and a venue manager
  • Stipends for our actors
  • Programs and postcards to promote the show
  • Fireproofing our set

We need $3475 to safely cover all the costs of our production. We know this is a big number and no donation is too small, even a dollar helps! And, if you break it down, we only need at least 139 of you to donate $25 each and we'll reach our goal in no time!

What You'll Get :

Other than the wonderful warm fuzzies of doing something good for your fellow man, and a fully realized version of "I Was Loved By a Rat" - we have lots of great swag and prizes for all of our donors big and small! Please check out the prizes at the side of the page for more details!

The Team :

Audra Arnaudon (Producer/Authorized Company Representative) majored in Film and Television and minored in Producing at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. A Brooklyn resident, she currently works in Production Management for National Geographic Television. In 2012, Audra produced "...And Then She DIES at the End!" for FringeNYC. It received a Performance award, and turned a very small profit (Yay!). Because of her successful past experience with FringeNYC, she knows she can help make IWLBAR the best it can be!

Essie Martsinkovsky (Writer/Producer) recently completed her M.F.A. in Dramatic Writing at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, Asia. While at Tisch, she acted in a variety of student films and plays, and directed a full production of her bilingual Russian/English short play "About Face." Prior to obtaining her M.F.A., she worked as an ESL teacher, a writing tutor, and mediator in small claims court, where she came across many people entangled in conflicts with their neighbors, roommates, and lovers.

Anna Strasser (Director) is thrilled to be working on this project with Essie and Audra! She currently works as the Executive Assistant at Signature Theatre Company. Prior to that she worked in the administrative offices of Lincoln Center Theater. She recently directed a one act play by Anthony Dvarskas that premiered at the Strawberry One Act Festival. She also directed Lucy Wang in "Chinese Girls Don't Swear" at the Workshop Theater in Manhattan and helped her develop it into a one-woman show which was produced by the Emerging Artists Theater. Additionally she is producing "Recipe For Success With Chef Michael Denardi" which can also be seen at this year's New York International Fringe Festival. She graduated from Oberlin College with honors in Theater. 

FringeNYC & The Future :

FringeNYC has served as a springboard to Broadway and Off-Broadway for many years, introducing the world to shows like "Urinetown" and "Dog Sees God". The festival has launched the careers of many well-known writers, such as The Office's Mindy Kaling. Basically: if you kill it at FringeNYC it can open doors. Doors you will have helped us walk through! We hope you'll support our show and the tradition of FringeNYC!

Other Ways You Can Help :

If you're in Manhattan or close by - come see our show in August at FringeNYC! The proceeds we make for the show will help us to cover some of the costs we incurred while putting on the production. We're still waiting on our venue assignment and our performance schedule, but will be posting updates here as soon as we have them!


If you can't come see the show, and you can't contribute, but you would still like to help out - make some noise for us! Use the links above (below the video) to let your friends know about our fundraising efforts!

Essie Martsinkovsky (Writer/Producer) recently completed her M.F.A. in Dramatic Writing at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts, Asia. While at Tisch, she acted in a variety of student films and plays, and directed a full production of her bilingual Russian/English short play "About Face." Prior to obtaining her M.F.A., she worked as an ESL teacher, a writing tutor, and mediator in small claims court, where she came across many people entangled in conflicts with their neighbors, roommates, and lovers.
Anna Strasser (Director) is thrilled to be working on this project with Essie and Audra! She currently works as the Executive Assistant at Signature Theatre Company. Prior to that she worked in the administrative offices of Lincoln Center Theater. She recently directed a one act play by Anthony Dvarskas that premiered at the Strawberry One Act Festival. She also directed Lucy Wang in "Chinese Girls Don't Swear" at the Workshop Theater in Manhattan and helped her develop it into a one-woman show which was produced by the Emerging Artists Theater. Additionally she is producing "Recipe For Success With Chef Michael Denardi" which can also be seen at this year's New York International Fringe Festival. She graduated from Oberlin College with honors in Theater. 
FringeNYC & The Future :
FringeNYC has served as a springboard to Broadway and Off-Broadway for many years, introducing the world to shows like "Urinetown" and "Dog Sees God". The festival has launched the careers of many well-known writers, such as The Office's Mindy Kaling. Basically: if you kill it at FringeNYC it can open doors. Doors you will have helped us walk through! We hope you'll support our show and the tradition of FringeNYC!
Other Ways You Can Help :
If you're in Manhattan or close by - come see our show in August at FringeNYC! The proceeds we make for the show will help us to cover some of the costs we incurred while putting on the production. We're still waiting on our venue assignment and our performance schedule, but will be posting updates here as soon as we have them!
If you can't come see the show, and you can't contribute, but you would still like to help out - make some noise for us! Use the links above (below the video) to let your friends know about our fundraising efforts!

story:
The Design & Craft Exhibition gives graduating (2013) students from the Design and Craft strands of the BA Theatre Practice Course at The Royal Central School of Speech and Drama the opportunity to exhibit their work to industry professionals, friends and family. It is a chance for the students to celebrate and showcase their work from their degree, as they look towards their future in the industry.

Money raised through this crowdfunding campaign will contribute to covering practical costs of display materials: paint, wood, fabrics, wires, and much more. Your contribution is invaluable to the realization and success of the exhibition.

story:
Mãh - Independent Intercultural Theatre was born in august 2013 from the will of four young artists from different countries and disciplinary backgrounds.

Mãh's theatre is a vocal, sonorous, visual and corporal experiment open to the joint effort of other artists. The group was built around the idea of trying out, sharing and exploring in the field of theatre and performance.

The first encountering happened in 2012 at the Odin Teatret (Denmark) following a collaboration around other theatrical project.

Mãh's first steps led to Who – human performance that was created in Biella, Italy.

The company's members are Isadora Pei from Italy, Meysam Kh. Farzaneh from Iran, Viviane Cammarota from Italy and Nicolas Hanny from France.


Isadora Pei is a director, an actress, a performer and a visual artist. She was a member of the theatrical research company Marcido Marcidorjs e Famosa Mimosa. She organizes multicultural events and international theatre workshops. She is also part of different teaching projects. She is part of the international group “Jasonites” created in Eugenio Barba's Odin Teatret and she often collaborates with Odin and Living Theatre Europa.

Meysam Kh. Farzaneh is an actor and play writer. He has worked on several plays with Mikhail Shahrestani as an actor, a performer, a photographer and a translator.He is a founding member of the Tourouq company from Teheran with which he is still working and producing shows today.

Viviane Cammarota is a classical and modern dancer and a performer. She studies music, visual and performing arts at the university of Salerno. Actress for the Living Theatre Europa, she collaborates with the director Gary Brackett.

Nicolas Hanny is an actor, sculptor and designer. He works with Luis Pasina, visual artist, as a creative assistant for installations and performances. With Florence Brunois, ethnologist, he contributes to workshops revolving around environment sensitivity. His corporal research includes various techniques  like : yoga, tai-chi, dance and corporeal mime.

Riccardo Ruggeri joined the company to compose "Who - Human Performance" music. A trained Jazz singer, he widened his horizons through electronic music.

Mãh's existence revolves around meetings. The company is currently planning on touring Europe to present its performance "Who - Human Performance" and share its taste and experience of research. Mãh's introduction journey will launch in march through two artistic residences and two workshops in Italy, open to artists from all horizons. Then, in April, Mãh will present "Who - Human Performance" in Italy, France, Germany and Denmark.

Your contribution will help to produce the performance "Who" and to cover the costs of transportation and accommodation for the artists as well as the rental of a vehicle to carry the set piece. 

For Mãh, art needs to step out of museums and theaters to join the revolving world's show.

With your support Mãh will be able to relay its creative enthusiasm through countless meetings and continue to create and share its dreams through numerous human encounters.

Please share this information. 

Give a chance to art!

For more details about our work, take a look at our website and our Facebook page using the following links.

story:
THE CHALLENGE
  Movies have been distributed on 35mm film for over 100 years.  Beginning in 2014, however, all major studios will be switching to digital format.  This will substantially reduce their production and distribution costs.  It will also provide a better movie-going experience in both picture and sound quality. The new digital projectors and required sound equipment are expensive -- around $60,000. The film studios have offered major multiplex theaters subsidies to make this conversion, but independent single-screen theaters like ours on Orcas Island are not eligible.  By early 2014 we will not be able to get movies that will work with our projector.

For many small theaters like the Sea View, the end of 35mm films leaves a stark choice:

Go digital or Go dark. 

THE SEA VIEW IS AS MUCH A LABOR OF LOVE AS  IT IS A BUSINESS
  Sea View theatre owner John Mount has worked for 53 years to provide a movie-going experience on Orcas Island.  John’s half-century of dedication is a labor of love. Due to our small population, the theatre barely covers operating expenses through ticket sales and concessions.  John is committed to keeping this theatre alive for the community.  He owns the building and the property and is making legal provisions to guarantee that the Sea View theatre stays a theatre.

THE FRIENDS OF THE SEA VIEW THEATRE
  When we learned of the threat of losing our theatre, a small group of concerned islanders  met with John.   Like him, we believe movie theaters are fundamentally important to the health and well being of small communities.  They’re not just a big box where you watch the latest release.  They’re a place to gather, laugh, and explore new ideas.  Especially for our youth! The theater is one of the places, like the village green, that keep the community connected.  It would be a shame to lose this valuable community asset.

A MOVIE THEATRE IN A SMALL TOWN IS VITAL FOR THE LOCAL ECONOMY
  In response, we formed The Friends of The Sea View Theatre,  a community action group to help create a vision for the future.  The goals are: exciting programming that includes independent films as well are first-run movies, matinees, and film festivals (the first is already slated for the fall of 2014).

  But we need to keep the doors open by raising the one-time cost of $60,000 to convert to a digital projector. Communities across America are saving their small town theatres, we can do it too!

  It's our hope that we exceed our goal.  Every dollar we raise over the conversion cost will go toward upgrading the theatre -- new seats, marquee and more.  We want a theatre in our community that we can all enjoy and be proud of for generations to come.

          The Sea View Theater needs your support.  We can’t do it alone!
                                            PLEASE DONATE NOW!

OTHER WAYS TO HELP:

1.  Join The Friends of the Sea View Theatre.
2.  Provide us with your service and we will exchange movie & event tickets
3.  Share this page with your friends and family

To Join "The Friends of The Sea View Theatre" please email a request to: 
                                       info@seaviewtheatre.com
